1.content:
In this world, humans and giant anthropomorphic animals have existed peacefully, but not in harmony. Not seeing eye to eye, both races have built similar civilizations, but apart from each other. However, this is about to change soon.

A small group of humans and giant anthros who dream of a world where both races can be fully integrated have started a program to get their ultimate goal started. This group has gathered some support on both sides, and one of them is a giant anthropomorphic ocelot who happens to be the superintendent of a school district. This ocelot realized that in order for humans and giant anthros to get along, they must start early. Therefore, as an experiment, he has enrolled a single human student, namely you, into one of his schools.

(If you wish to follow this storyline, please choose a number, which will reflect how many times larger the anthros are than the humans. Otherwise, choose Other)
1.title: The "Normal" Storyline

11.content: Okay, so in this universe, anthropomorphic animals average about ten times taller than humans, about the size of a small building. The next question: what kind of school are you going to?
11.title: Ten Times Taller

111.content: Ok then, so your going to go to kindergarten, but the question is, are you going to kindergarten because you are at kindergarten age, or are you older and you're being sent there because it should be safer for you?
111.title: kindergarten

choices: "I'm Roger!  Nice to meet you, human Pete!
1112.content:
You feel so humiliated going back to kindergarten. You just finished your second year of high school, but apparently, because of this crazy human/anthro integration program, your next year is going to be the alphabet and counting all over again. You feel that this is too harsh a punishment for your poor grades, even though your parents are insisting that this is an honor and not a punishment. It's not like you don't hate giant anthropomorphic animals, in fact you think they're kind of cool. You just don't like the idea of being treated like a four-year old. Surely you can take care of yourself; you're even a member of the wrestling team! Either anthros are many times more dangerous than you thought, or everyone is being far too careful in this project.

As you are dropped off, you try to think on the positive side. Well, at least the work will be easy. Hopefully, the adults will treat you like a fifteen year old instead of a toddler. You were told that this is much more of a social experiment than an academic one, and that the idea is that anthros will learn to respect humans better if they interact with them early. Heck, maybe you're just overreacting.

You walk in the door, and see a bunch of giant anthro toddlers wandering around, playing with blocks, drawing with crayons, and other typical toddler activities. They are anywhere from three to five times your height and definitely do not seem muscular at all yet. You decide to walk up to weasel child playing with a model train set. "Hi, I'm Pete, what's your name?"

The weasel boy looks at you, his eyes widen, and he shouts,
1112.title: Safety First

choices: I was just starting to enjoy it here.
11121.content:
Weasel: Haiya. I'm Roger. Nice to meet you.
You: Nice to meet you too.
The 2 of you chat for a while and become friends.
After a few hours it's time to go home for the day, and you think to yourself
11121.title: A new friend

choices: takes you to some of the other kindergarteners
11122.content: You realize instantly that being sent to kindergarten instead of a highschool was a bad idea when you hear the words leave the weasel childs mouth. You begin to run as he walks towards you, but, being so much bigger than you, he easily reaches you and picks you up. You fear for your life when he begins to sniff at you and you are afraid he might eat you, but this is not the case as he....
11122.title: "Ooh!  A new toy!"

111222.content: He begins to walk off with you in hand and you wonder where he is taking you, but you soon realize that he is going to show you to some of the other children. Hopefully one of the would realize you aren't a toy. You gulp, seeing that the weasel child is taking you to a .....
111222.title: showing you around

1112221.content: Your eyes widen when you see that the weasel child is carrying you off to what looks like a frog. When he reaches the frog, he begins talking and you can tell that it is also a boy. The weasel child puts you down on the floor and they turn away from you, whispering to eachother, occasionally looking back at you to make sure you're still there. They finish talking, and the frog child picks you up. His hands are sticky and feel really weird. You wonder where they will take you now that they have finished talking, and you realize where when they go.....
1112221.title: Frog kid

choices: A large box of building blocks
11122212.content: Peeking over the webbed fingers of the frog boy, you see that they are walking over to the toy box. Still wondering where the teacher is, you see the weasel child open the toy box and pull out...
11122212.title: The toy box

1112222.content: The weasel is carrying you towards a specific anthro. You notice that it is a...
1112222.title: other kind of anthro

11122221.content:
The weasel walks past some kids, who don't bother to look at him, and you realize he's heading for one individual in particular. You see he's approaching a young cat anthro with white fur and bright blue eyes, sitting on the floor and looking over a pile of blocks. Judging by the fact that this anthro is wearing a yellow dress, you assume it is female.

"Hey, look!" the weasel said. "I got a new toy!"

The kitten looks up, and her eyes widen as she sees you. She gets to her pawed feet and walks towards you and the weasel.

"Wow! I've never seen a toy like that before! Where'd you find it?"

You look up at the weasel and frown, still indignant at the anthro's insistence at calling you a toy, but that motion seems to cause a reaction in the kitten. She gasps, and you look over at her.

"Wait, it looks alive! Hey, it moved! Toys don't move! That's not a toy!" the kitten cried.

"Looks like a toy to me," the weasel replied. "Come on, let's play with it!"

You're about to speak up, hoping that your voice will convince the kids that you are indeed a living thing, but the kitten cuts you off.

"No, let it go! It's not a toy! Lemme see it!"

The weasel glares at the kitten, but then crouches and releases you. You step forward, wanting to put some distance between the weasel and yourself. You look back to see that he is stepping back, and then he sits down with crossed arms and a frown on his face. Meanwhile, the kitten crouches down and looks at you closely.

"So, are you a toy?" she asks.

You shake your head vigorously. "No, I'm a human! I'm here because of some exchange program or something. I'm not a toy."

The kitten looked over at the weasel and stuck her tongue out. "See? Told ya!"

The weasel glares at her, and sticks his tongue out too. "Fine. So he ain't a toy! Whatever. You can play with him if you want. I'm gonna go get a real toy."

He goes away, leaving you alone with the kitten. You start to feel a bit scared near her, and you look up at her big blue eyes nervously.

"I've never met a human before," she says. "You look cute!"

You smile up at her, realizing that she seems to I deed be gentle. "Aw, thanks. You're cute too."

The kitten giggles. And then, to your surprise, she reaches down with both paws, clasping you between them. The pads soften her grip, but it's still tight, and your arms are pinned. She raises you up to her face, and brings you to her cheek, nuzzling you against her soft fur. You smile widely as she does so, closing your eyes and enjoying the feeling.

"Can I hold you?" she asks. You nod, feeling better in her grasp than in that of the weasel from before. The kitten is pleased with your answer, and nuzzles you a bit more before holding you out in front of her face.

"You're really cool!" she exclaims as she looks you over. "You're like a little dolly, but you're alive! Mommy always told me to be gentle to little things, though, so I won't hurt you!"

You let out a sigh of relief, glad to hear that. You just hope that she really will succeed at keeping you safe, because in a setting like this, where everything was ten times bigger, danger is everywhere.

The kitten's ears suddenly perk up, and she looks over to the side. You look too, and see...
11122221.title: Kitty

choices: A large, well-dressed ocelot staring down at you
You are on your own now
113.content:
You are very nervous as you look out the back seat window of the car. In the distance, you can see the huge city; the city where your new school is. You have to wonder what your parents were thinking, sending you to a school filled with big hairy monsters. Even at your old school you were picked on, and you are convinced that it will be much worse at Eastpaw Junior High.

You remember the talk that you had with your parents before you left. They were big supporters of the whole "species integration" idea, and had agreed with some important anthro figure to send you on what they called a "big adventure". They insisted that there was nothing to be so afraid of, but what do parents know, anyway?

Up ahead, your heart pounds as your parent's car merges onto a much wider road. There is a small dotted line indicating where it is safe for humans to drive. Huge automobiles much larger than monster trucks zoom past the tiny car you are in as if it isn't moving at all. Time seems to slow down, and you feel like your going to your own funeral.

The open road shifts to busy streetways as the journey heads into the city. You look out the other window and see all sorts of giant paws lifting and stomping across the sidewalk. You try to look up, and you notice with fear that many of the anthros are looking at the tiny car oddly. As you see the school approaching, you are amazed that none of the giant anthros had decided to wreck the car.

The building is absolutely enormous: it is as tall as a thirty-story building and much wider, and yet the map of the school your were given clearly shows that the building is only three stories tall. The car stops, and you feel your heart do the same.

"Have a good first day at school, John!" your mother says before she blows you a kiss. Lifting your backpack, you hesitantly leave the false safety of the car. You notice that there is a small ramp leaning on the curb. At least you won't have any trouble getting onto the sidewalk. You walk cautiously up the ramp and stare in the direction of the school. You notice ...
113.title: The Big City

1132.content:
Looking at the school's entrance, you breathe a sigh of relief when you notice that the door is propped open. You look at your schedule, and your luck fades away: your first class, Mathematics, is on the third floor. You are still afraid that the big anthros walking around might want to bully you, so you try to stay out of their sight. Half walking, half dashing, you make it to the entrance without being seen. So far, so good.

Once inside, you quickly hide behind the propped door and return to your map. You read it over and over, looking for anything that might be an elevator. However, all there are is three staircases. This is going to be a very difficult commute every morning.

As you see the crowd of giant students growing, you decide that you will be less likely to be seen in the crowd than in the open. So, hugging the wall, you inch towards the stampede of anthros, then make a dash for the nearest staircase. You immediately want to regret your logic as you find yourself dodging big furry paws and sharp taloned feet as large as you are. Zigzagging left and right, you lose your breath when your head brushes against a dangling pant leg. You quickly disappear before the anthro noticed anything; you didn't even care what kind of anthro it was.

Finally, you reach the stairs. You hug the wall, staying in the shadows, and look at the first flight. There are twenty steps, each of which is four feet high. Catching your breath from all of the running, you toss your backpack onto the first step, then drag yourself up. You look towards the other wall and see the plethora of climbing paws start to thin. Knowing that time is short, you toss your backpack up another step and scramble after it. You do this two more times, and already you are completely and utterly exhausted. You feel hopeless now, and wish that you could have just gone to a normal school like everyone else.

Just when you thought it could not get any worse, your greatest fear is realized. Above you, you hear a voice saying, "Do you need any help, human?" You shout in fright as you see who had spoken to you.
1132.title: The Trek to Math

11321.content: You look up to see an anthro tiger girl. You are so nervous, you can't even speak! "Do you want me to carry you to class?" asks the tiger girl. You think about this for a minute. You nod, hoping she wouldn't kill you. She picks you up with her enormous paw, trying not to crush you. While holding you, she walks up the steps, asking what class you have first. You tell her Mathematics on the third floor. She says that is also her next class and carries you the whole way there. You look at the teacher to see who is teaching. The teacher is a
11321.title: Thank God She's Friendly

113211.content:
You look at your teacher and find that he's a bird anthro of some sort. You don't know what type of bird but it doesn't really matter to you. All that matters is that you get to your classes safely although it would be hard considering how small you are.

"There you are!" the teacher exclaims, "I thought you wouldn't be able to make it by how small you are. I've got a special small seat designed specifically for you." The teacher pointed to a small object placed right on top of one of the front desks in the classroom while the tiger girl places you near the small object. You grab your things out of your backpack and you begin to start jolting notes down.

"Today, we will be learning about Trigonometry. Can anybody tell me what trigonometry involves?"

An anthro paw went straight up.

"Yes Leon?" the teacher asked.

"I know what's it about. It's about being a nerd." The whole class started laughing a little. You however don't. You know a lot about trigonometry and you want to say something yet you feel that it may lower your reputation at school even though it seems already low.
113211.title: bird Anthro.

1132111.content:
You look at the anthro with a eyebrow cocked " actually it's nothing like that its actually very wonderful of course you may not know anything about wonderful things"
Everyone started looking at you including the anthro who.
1132111.title: Join the discussion

113212.content:
You are quite shocked by the visage of your math teacher, and almost fall off the friendly tiger girl's hand. The teacher had unnaturally thick lips and eyelashes, a long neck, and curly hair all over her face. You cannot tell what kind of monster she is yet, but that is not what worries you most.

"Ah, I see that the human got to class all right," said the teacher, more to the tiger girl than to you. "Very well, go ahead and put him down on a seat." The tiger girl seemed dying to say something, but instead she obeyed and set you down on the surface of a desk. You realize that you forgot your backpack on the stairs, but the tiger girl then brings her other hand to the desktop, reavealing your backpack hanging from her pointer finger. She slides off the backpack and places it down gently next to you, and she takes a seat to your immediate left.

Meanwhile, the teacher was writing down her name on the blackboard. You can see that she holds the chalk in a hoof-like hand, and you realize that she is a llama, or something similar. When she finished writing, she moved over, and you saw the words "Mrs. Paca" on the board.

"Hello, class, I'm Mrs. Paca, and I will be teaching math this year." spoke the anthro you now identify as an alpaca. "As you may have noticed, we have a human student in our school this year. Therefore, I would like to start off the year by saying that you should all focus on your own work and not let him distract you. Now, let us begin by opening our textbooks to page 3...".

Throughout math class, you cannot pay any attention to Mrs. Paca. Instead, you are very self aware of all of the huge students around you. You are aware that the whole reason that you were transferred to this school was to help anthros and humans develop a better relationship, but after you have heard the things that teacher said, you realize the extent of the problem. Even an adult was downright disrespectful; she did not even want to talk to you, and spoke of you as if you were an object, not a person!

Outside of Mrs. Paca's ramblings, you feel that the room is far too quiet. You look at the other students, and see every single one of them looking at you. Their faces are ones of disgust, as if they think you are some sort of freak of nature. You feel that had this not been a classroom, you would have been smashed to pieces by any one of them. The only exception is the tiger girl, who is also looking at you, but in a much friendlier way. You are glad that there will be at least one anthro in this school that doesn't hate you.

After a very long hour, the bell rings. All of the students get up to leave, and even Mrs. Paca packs up her tote bag. After all of your things have been put back in your backpack, the room was already empty, as if nobody wanted to share a classroom with a human. On your own again, you hop down about ten feet to the desk chair, then about fifteen to the tiled floor. You go to the giant open door, ready to get your school map out and find your second class. However, when you enter the hallway, you almost run into a thick, furry leg. You look up, and you see someone looking down at you.
113212.title: First Period

choices: Laughter: all of the other anthros are laughing at you and Melanie
Ringing: you and Melanie are late to your second classes
1132121.content:
You immediate apologize profusely to the tiger girl, hoping that she won't turn mad at you and hate you like everyone else in this school. However, looking up, you see she is not mad at all: she looks absolutely worried. Kneeling down to get a better look at you, she speaks in a very sincere way.

"Listen, human, I'm very sorry that you are going through all of this. I mean, I don't really know anything about humans or why a human is going to this school, but no one should be treated like that anywhere. I felt so bad for you; you looked so frightened in there, I thought you were going to try and run away."

Even though that you are still terrified of this girl, you start to see her as a bit more like a human now. You are too afraid to reply to her, so instead you step forward and stroke her giant paw a bit, not knowing what else to do.

"Aw, thats really sweet, human, I was sure that you wouldn't like me anymore after what happened in class." She returned by stroking you under your chin with a massive fingerpad.

Now you feel a bit more comfortable, so you gather your courage and speak to the tiger. "Thank you. Well, I never got your name ... Mine's John, by the way."

"Why hello, John, I'm Melanie," speaks the tiger anthro. Just after your first anthro friend says this, you hear an uncomforting sound.
1132121.title: Genuine Concern

11321212.content: "Oh man!" you say, not noticing you'd be late. "What class do you have next?" asked Melanie. "Science on the first floor," you say, hoping you and her have the same class, or at least on the same floor. "Sorry, but I've got class on third floor. I'm sorry I can't take you down to your class." "It's OK," you say reassuringly. "I can walk down." "Alright." Melanie turns, and runs to her class. You start to walk down the giant steps. Just when you get to the science lab, the bell rings, saying that class is over. You run and hide somewhere, avoiding the giant paws. You start going to your class, which is fortunately on the first floor. Just when you turned around, the science teaher yelled your name. You walk over to the classroom, and you see how mad the anthro boar is. "Why were you late?" asked the anthro boar. "My class was on third floor. And the steps were too big!" you reply, hoping that you would escape with a warning. "So? That's no excuse! You know what, why don't you just get to class. I'll give you only one warning." You start running to your next class, hoping to get there before you were late. Your next class was
11321212.title: Mean Science Teacher

choices: A well-dressed ocelot and Melanie are sitting at the foot of the bed
Many giant anthro students are gathered around the bed
113212121.content:
You run as fast as you can away from the anthro boar man, feeling absolutely horrible. All of your fears are being realized, and you wish you could just quit right now. However, you are far too afraid to say anything to any of the anthros right now, and just focus on getting to the other end of the hallway before it is too late.

You are very frustrated that all of the anthro kids walk at least twice as fast as you can run, and this makes you all the more fearful of getting in their way. If one of them decided to hurt you, escape would be utterly impossible.

You make it to the door in time, but there is another problem, the door is closed. The door knob is far too high for you to reach, so you pound heavily on the door, hoping somebody will open it. You do not care if you are noticed now; you fear that if you are late to health class, the teacher may not be nice enough to let you go with a warning.

Sure enough, the door swings open, but something goes horribly, horribly wrong. Since you were banging on the door when it opened, the giant wooden door rammed right into your head at forty miles per hour, sending you screaming through the air across the tiled hallway and landing in a heap on the floor. Pain dashed through your head as you heard gasps echo through the hall. Everything started getting dark as you saw giant furry faces appear high above you...

When you wake up, your whole body aches, especially your head, and your vision is blurred. You wriggle a bit, and fortunately nothing seems to be broken. You reach your aching arms onto your face and you notice that your forehead is thickly bandaged. Suddenly, you remember everything that had happened, and you cannot help but start crying. Today had been an absolute failure for you, and you are sure that you let your parents and even humanity as a whole down. The tears do help your vision to clear up, and you notice that you are in one of three giant-sized beds. You realize that you are still in the school, and judging from where you are, this is the nurse's office. You suddenly become aware of a presence in the room.
113212121.title: Third Strike, You're Out

choices: Arrange something wit another student in your classes
1132121211.content:
You look and see Melanie and a very well-dressed ocelot standing next to her. Melanie looks at you very worried, while the ocelot seems glad you woke up. You have a few guess as to who the ocelot is, as the only people in a school building that wear clothes that are that nice are usually higher-ups.

"I am glad you are awake John. I am the principal of the school, Dr. Tabbins. I heard about your unfortunate accident from Melanie." Melanie must have been the one who brought you here, and probably has been here the whole time. The principal continued, "I also was told about how your day had gone from her, as well as your science teacher. I apologize for the rough day. It is entirely my fault. This project was rushed a good deal, and I didn't have time to develop a plan to make movement through the school easier for you." You understand the situation somewhat, but the fact that they overlooked an issue like getting through the school at your size troubles you a bit.

"Well, it wasn't just the distance, Dr. Tabbins. I also had dodge the feet of everyone else. I don't think I should be walking on the ground." The principal nods in agreement.

"We could always arrange for someone to carry you around the school to all your classes. I believe there are a few students with the same schedule as you. If you want, I could switch you into all of Melanie's classes. She was the one who suggested it. It is your choice though." You think about it a bit. You know that Melanie is very nice, and wouldn't mind carrying you around. However, you feel like it might be nice to meet some other students in your class. You reply to Dr. Tabbins suggestion, telling him you would like to...
1132121211.title: Making an Arrangement

choices: the nurse tells you school is over, and you can go home.
you are in Melanie's paw, probably taking you to class.
11321212111.content: "Then, I'll get your new schedule ready," said the ocelot. He walked away. You stare at Melanie and think of a way to break the silence. Just when you were about to speak, Melanie starts rubbing your belly. This calms you, and it seems that you are about to fall asleep. Eventually, you do fall asleep. When you wake up
11321212111.title: Tiger Girl Company

choices: your staying at my house tonight.
I'm staying at your house tonight.
113212121112.content:
You wake up to a gentle nudging. As you stretch, you can feel the warm padded surface support you from underneath, and you open your eyes to see Melanie's huge head. "Well, somebody was sleepy!" she spoke. You do not hurt very much anymore, and you can tell that your head is still wrapped in a bandage, but it is not as thick as before.

"Wow, how long have I been asleep?" you ask. You look around and notice that you and Melanie are outside somewhere.

"You were out cold throughout the rest of the school day. I tell you, everyone in school was talking about that nasty spill of yours. Principal Tabbins made this big announcement over the intercom about how everyone needs to be more accepting of you."

So, you missed the rest of the school day. At least you do not have to worry about making up for the classes you missed, since your schedule will be different tomorrow now that Melanie is going to help you. Suddenly something crosses your mind.

"Wait a minute, why didn't my parents bring me home? They couldn't have ..." you stop, suddenly fearing that they too had become injured at the giant paws of anthros, or worse.

"Your parents had a long talk with the principal and I. They were very sad when they heard the news, and were very upset that you did not wake up when they were there. My folks were there too, and we all discussed what we should do. As you can see, we decided that it would be best if we spent more time with each other. This is why...
113212121112.title: Slept Through School

1132121211121.content:
"You're staying at my house tonight!" You sit up and take a good look around. Past the line of Melanie’s claws, you can see enormous expanses of green stretching away on your right and left. From your dizzying height it's hard to tell, but each seems like it could fit several football fields comfortably before they hit a fence which was easily twice the height of your house. These fields were separated by a wide expanse of gray the size of a four lane road. Shaking your head at the vertigo, you look up and see a massive structure which is twenty stories high, clearly a house. You look back at Melanie, who's looking down at you patiently:

"My parents are okay with this?" You try to keep your voice level, but the question comes out as disbelieving and incredulous. Melanie frowns at you:

"What, you don't like it?" She sounds offended, and her face takes on a menacing mean. You hastily shake your head and wave your arms, sudden fear of this building size anthro freezing your insides:

"No no, I didn't mean it like that..." Your shaky response is drowned out by Melanie's sudden laughter. Her face changes all at once to amusement:

"Just kidding. I guess if I were in your position I would ask the same question." Her claw flicks your shoulder in a comradely gesture. You nod, relieved. She moves her paw closer to her face, her other paw cupping over the side in an exaggerated motion, "Gotta learn to stop that flinch, though." She says in a conspiratorial tone, warm breath washing over you, "most of us anthros can smell fear, you know." Her playacting takes the sting off her words, and after a moment you nod hesitantly. Satisfied, she straightens up and looks around.

"So what do you think, really?" She turns around, clearly slowly for her but still fast enough to make the landscape blur a little. You still get a good, panoramic view, however.

"It’s... it’s a lot like home, actually." Indeed it is, with rows of houses stretching away down the street, (relatively) small patches of green in front of moderately-sized houses and towering trees providing shade. You can even see a mixed group of anthro children across the street drawing on the sidewalk with chalk.

"A bit bigger, though, I'd think." Says Melanie, half teasingly, half thoughtfully.

"Yeah. And also, if an Anthro showed up in my human neighborhood, they'd attract a lot more attention." Melanie chuckles appreciatively as she walks into the house. As far as you could tell, the Anthros on the block had not even noticed your presence.

Inside, the similarities continue, although there are a few subtle differences which you barely have time to notice as you are whisked through the air at Melanie's walking pace. As you walk into Melanie's living room, you spot another giant Tiger walking in through another opening, clearly Melanie's mom. You stare in awe, she's the same height compared to Melanie as an adult would be to you, but she's significantly broader. She's wearing a sweater and broad tight jeans, but it takes you a moment to realize that the outdoor movie theater sized piece of cloth she has over it is an apron.

"Hi honey!" she's says cheerily, rapidly getting closer and looming over you. Suddenly, the world starts flashing past rapidly and topsy-turvy as Melanie leans in to her mom, who is bending over, and nuzzles her on the cheek, clearly the tiger equivalent of an affectionate peck. The procedure causes you to bounce into the air spinning as Melanie remembers you at the last minute and jerks you away from her Mom's body. It prevents you from getting crushed by the massive expanse of tiger, but it does send you somersaulting with a yelp, and you're glad that Melanie's paw-pads are of the same consistency as a stack of gym mats when you come back down with a thump.

"John? Are you okay?" You blink for a moment, disoriented at the spectacle of two tiger faces hanging in space above you, one upside down. Melanie nudges your stomach with a claw for the second time in fifteen minutes, and you snap out of it. A bit shaken and dizzy, but otherwise unharmed, you get to your feet, glad that you hadn't suffered the indignity of losing your previous meal in front of these two massive figures. You wave at them to show you're okay, and they relax, much relieved. Melanie's mom gives you a warm, feline smile, and extends a claw:

"Sorry about that John, didn't mean to give you a tumble, guess I'm not used to having human guests. We haven't been formally introduced, I'm Melanie's Mother and I'm glad to see you're awake this time." You shake her claw, minding the extremely sharp end, and call back:

"Hello, no problem, thanks for having me over."

"My pleasure." She nods at you and, formalities done, turns her attention back to her daughter, "Now, dinner's going to be ready in about an hour and a half, why don't you....
1132121211121.title: A bit of a Tumble

choices: ...I got these assignments for you during school, you should do them to."
...you don't have to do any of these, why don't you take a look around?"
11321212111212.content:
"Why don't you go upstairs and do your homework?" It clearly is not a question. The world blurs once more as Melanie gesticulates, her arms opening and shaking up and down in exasperation:

"But mom, I was going to introduce John to..." Melanie's mom turns her head towards you and twitches her nose pointedly. Melanie looks over and sees you hanging on for dear life as her hand continues to move up and down. The feeling in your stomach reminds you of that time when you (ill-advisedly) got on that amusement park ride that shoots up into the air and comes down in a free fall. Melanie stabilizes her hand at once and gives you a sheepish grin:

"Sorry about that.' Melanie's mother intervenes:

"I think you'd better get used to John in private before going around in public." she says firmly, taking her daughter by the shoulder and marching her through the living room to the stairs. You are recovered enough by now to wince:

"Ooh, cheap shot." You mutter to yourself. The adult's antenna-dish sized ears twitch:

"Isn't it, though?" She says innocently, turning and smiling down at you You wince, you hadn't thought that either of the two would be able to hear you. Melanie is also looking at you in a friendly matter, although for different reasons, so you must have been wrong on both counts. Melanie's mother fixes Melanie with a stern eye and she gives in, waking up the stairs slowly. You look around, fascinated as you pass poster-sized family pictures hanging at exactly your level. In one of them, you can see a whole bunch of anthro tigers, clearly Melanie's extended family.

Reaching the top of the stairs, Melanie pauses wordlessly once more sweeping her hand around to give you a view. There's not much to see, as the airplane hanger sized hallway is sparsely decorated, with a number of doors leading off it. Melanie steps over to the second on the left and enters. She silently steps across and sets you on a giant desk. You look around. The warehouse sized room contains a large amount of stuff, with bookshelves across from you, a TV set on a low table to your left and a bed on your right.

Despite their size, you can't make out much detail about their structure, so you look around the desk itself. It is made of a dark wood, which has been heavily treated, to the point where it’s almost as slippery as ice for you. You have to move carefully to keep from slipping and falling. You speculate that ordinary wood would easily catch a tiger's claws, so they heavily waxed it. There are a number of panels and buttons on the desk, with deep holes in them where a claw could easily catch and press them in, but otherwise the desk is featureless.

Having moved closer to one such button, you had lost track of Melanie's movements as you stared at it. You are brought sharply back to awareness, however, when a large, heavy object suddenly drops out of the sky only a few feet in front of you! It hits with a thump and you practically jump ten feet into the air, heart racing. It could easily have caused serious injury to you if it had connected. Calming down, you turn and glare at Melanie, who is settling down into a chair and putting some other things you can't see on the desk. You open your mouth to say something, but once more you find yourself scrambling out of the way as Melanie opens up her textbook and the cover starts descending on your body.

"Hey!" You shout up at her. Melanie ignores you, feline face dark. You get the impression that she's sulking. You hesitate for a moment, as you don't know what she might do if she gets angry at you, but you decide to take action. You walk over to the textbook, step up onto the thick sheaf of paper and march across it. You are momentarily distracted by the sight of the pencil, which Melanie is using to mark her place. It has thick groves on the sides for her claws and its taller than you are! You set it aside, however, and march right into Melanie's focused line of sight.

After a few seconds her pencil approaches you and hesitates, You're worried that she might either ignore you or simply knock you out of the way, but she gives a sigh and drops it. She folds her hands on the book and leans down, putting her chin on them, so that her eyes are only slightly above yours. You seize the initiative:

"Look, I know homework sucks, but don't you think that this is a bit, you know, much?" you ask her. Her mouth opens, giving you a view of some very sharp teeth, but it closes again, and she just stares at you. You meet her gaze, and eventually her eyes drop.

"I'm sorry, I just wanted to show you so much stuff..." she breaks off, staring at you for a moment. At length, she straightens up, face brightening: "But hey," she waved a claw around your bandaged head, "I guess you're not really up to it right now anyway, are you?" you laugh and shake your head:

"I guess not. Some other time then." A mischievous gleam enters Melanie's eyes:

"I'll hold you to that." she says solemnly. You gulp, hoping you won't regret your words. She gently pushes you with the end of the pencil away from the center of the page and resumes reading. She stops again after a moment, however, and looks at you:

"I just realized...
11321212111212.title: Homework Time

113212121112121.content:
Melanie reaches her big paw into her knapsack and withdraws your books. Thankfully, your textbooks are not the same size as her patio sized ones. However, she then fishes out a pink notebook and rips out the first page, sliding it close to you. Written on the top in curly cursive writing are your assignments for your classes. As this was the first day of school, most of them required just reading through the textbooks. However, one class, English, required you to write a paragraph about yourself. After you do the reading, you note that Melanie is finished with her homework and just staring at you with her big eyes, the pupils curled into friendly slits.

"Um, Melanie, do you have any looseleaf paper in my size?" you ask. Half expecting her to bring out a little notebook in between her fingerpads, you groan as she rips out another huge sheet of paper from her pink notebook. "Sorry, John, but nobody would be able to read your tiny handwriting, so your going to have to just use some of mine and write big."

Your feline friend then rolls you her huge nine-foot pencil. You struggle to lift the massive wooden implement; it must weigh a bit more than you do. You carry the pencil to the of your page and start to write a foot long letter 'J' to start your name. It is grueling work, and you have to put down the pencil to put the weight off your legs for a while. You are none too pleased with the misshapen squiggle that was supposed to be a 'J'.

You turn to Melanie, who had not once taken her eyes off you. You can tell that she was immensely enjoying this show you were putting on in front of her looming face, and you feel ashamed to ask her for your help. However, she presents the opportunity herself, saying, "Looks like you need a bit of a hand with your penmanship."

You laugh at her little joke, and she picks up the eraser on her desk and removes your bug splat of a letter J. This time, she help you hold the pencil upright, and you guide her big paw through the words by pulling or pushing. It takes a lot longer than you would have liked, but you are pleased with your paragraph, and it almost looks like your own handwriting. "Well, if English class is like this, I don't even want to know about Gym," you speak.

Melanie laughs at your joke, then, in a friendly but not jokingly way, says, "Well, I have to tell you, this is the most fun I've ever had doing homework. I guess that it wasn't so bad that I couldn't show you around the neighborhood today. I'm sure you'll get the chance some other day."

"John, Melanie, dinner is ready!" calls the voice of the tiger mother from the kitchen. Picking you up in a claw, your friend carries you to the kitchen, where you notice that her mother is serving...

113212121112122.content:
"I just realized you don't have to do any of these, why don't you take a look around?" Her words sound casual, but considering that Melanie utters them immediately after scooting you across the page with her shovel sized pencil eraser, you suspect an ulterior motive. To test your theory, you casually step over the next line of text that Melanie is reading.

"What's the matter?" You call up to her, "Finding it difficult to concentrate?" Her eyes go to slits of amusement at your witticism. Her paw, however, suddenly drops the pencil and comes up from behind. She seizes you and lifts you into the air in front of her face. You give her a toothy, slightly abashed grin. She finally deems to reply:

"You are a bit of a nu... distraction." She hastily corrects herself and pauses, searching your face for signs of offence. Seeing none, she continues: A distracting Nuisance." She gives you a grin which easily outshine- and out"tooths"- your own. She turns in her chair and leans forward, setting you on the ground at her feet. It’s slightly disorienting, for a moment. Staring up along the columns of fur that are an anthro's legs is strange enough, but to see Melanie's face hovering in the sky and peering down at you between them. The wave of vertigo quickly makes you look down, hand to your suddenly dizzy head.

"Are you okay?" She asks, suddenly concerned, reaching out a paw. You wave her off:

"I'm fine."

"Don't do this if you're not up to it." She says warningly. The dizziness passes and you collect yourself:

"I'm up to it." You tell her confidently. She nods, and starts to turn away. Suddenly, a thought strikes you. "A thought just struck me." You shout up to her. She pauses in her turn, looking back down at you absently:

"What thought?" By her tone, she clearly wants to get back to her work:

"It just seemed ironic to me." You shout at her: "At home, human's cats usually get on top of their books and have to be moved. Here, it seems, the reverse is true." For a moment you fear you have offended her with the mention of her (very) distant relatives, but she laughs, nods at you warmly, but distantly, and turns back to her work. Thus proving my point you think to yourself. You set off across the floor, but before you go more than a few steps another, much different, impulse strikes you. You turn, drawing in breath to shout, but you're interrupted:

"Bathroom's across the hall, one door to the right." She sounds impatient. You blink once, twice, scratching your head, then turn and keep walking. Damn, you think to yourself, she has really good hearing. Or she's psychic. Whatever the case, she is correct. You have slept all day, after all, and it's been a long time since you have been able to go. With this in mind, you quicken your pace.

To your dismay, however, you find that the going is harder than you might have thought. For one thing, the distance is far greater (obviously) than it would have been in your own home, and your aching bladder seems to multiply the distance by another ten times. Even then, the distance isn't all that great. The real problem is the floor. Unlike in a human house, the floor isn't made of polished wood or carpet, which would catch a tiger's claws. Instead, it is a hard, grey substance, and it is filled with cracks. You suppose that the uneven surface of the floor is barely noticeable to an anthro and probably comfortable to their pads, but for you its is horrible. The cracks are the absolute worst size, too large to be easily stepped over, but small enough that spotting them can be tricky.

It therefore takes you some time to get to your destination, tripping, twisting your ankle (although not badly) and swearing. After a little while you make it into the hallway, and you pause for a breather. You take a moment to take in the sight. You had come the same way not fifteen minutes earlier, but from the ground the view is even more unreal. The hallway stretches away on either side for hundreds of yards in both directions, with small tables rising from the floor as large as small buildings and massive lights hanging from the ceiling a hundred feet overhead. Across the hall, a door rises up, looking perfectly immovable. This brings a worry into your mind, what if the bathroom door was closed and latched? You look over quickly, but you can see that it, thankfully, is standing wide open. You quickly, or rather as quickly as is possible with that horrid floor underfoot, cross to the other side and go through.

The floor here is smoother at least, with smaller cracks. Two large rectangular structures rise from either side of you. You assume one of them is a sink and mirror, since there is a lip of smooth marble past the edge of the wooden cabinet. You can't fathom what the other is, from your angle you can't make anything out about what is on top. You hurry eagerly on for a moment, then pause, remembering the open door. You move over to the wooden rectangle. It rises twelve times your height and looks like it weighs, literally, a ton. Nether-the-les, the thought of Melanie's Mom, Dad or, perish the thought, Melanie herself walking in while you are doing your business makes you at least try. You strain against it for a few moments, panting with the effort. You would have had about as much success moving one of the walls of your house. You give up after a moment, glaring at it angrily. The door just sits their.

You turn and go past the counters, and stop dead in your tracks. Rising in front of you is not a toilet, but what can only be described as a low throne, with high sides leading to a smooth, white back and a bottom which was only slightly above your head. You walk over to it and pull yourself up. You firmly [i] do not [/i] think about how this facility is used and what must have touched it as you walk over to a large covered hole which is apparently pressure sensitive, seeing as how it slides away as you approach. You do your business, and quickly scramble of the chair and walk quickly out of the bathroom. You are so intent on your escape, moving as quickly as possible across the broken floor of the hall that you are taken totally off guard by the approach of a massive tiger anthro. The first thing you know a column of fur descends in front of you and SLAMS into the floor not a foot away. The vibrations, and the shock of seeing such a large object hit the ground, cause you to become distracted, and at that moment your foot steps in a particularly vicious crack.

You are sent sprawling, tumbling for a ways before coming to a rest. Your ankle is a violent ball of pain, enough to leave you immobilized on the floor for a few moments. As you start to recover (your ankle thankfully is not broken, just sprained), you hear a voice thunder down from above:

"anything you say?"he responds stopping the paw

"Y-yeah...anything! J-j-just please dont crush me!" You plead again.

"Wellllllll....." He says rubbing his chin,"Well you know I've always wanted my very own...
1132121211121221.title: "What's this? A Human?"

choices: ...lays into the meat with unsheathed claws
1132121211121222.content:
"Hey John. Dinner's ready." Melanie’s voice thunders down as she shifts her (massive) weight on her legs, so that she’s resting on her haunches, knees splayed out. Even in the midst of your own moderate pain from the sprained ankle, you can’t help but wince. Your own bones would be creaking with that maneuver. You roll onto your back and stare at the sight over your head. Melanie cocks her head at you, grinning, and then unceremoniously snatches you off the floor, rising to her feet:

“You’ve really got to get used to being around anthros.” She comments, amused. She clearly has noticed the way your clutching your ankle, as she carefully arranges you so sitting up in her pad (there’s not enough room for you to lie down), ankle somewhat elevated. You glare at her:

“It’s your damn floor.” You shout up at her. Her face darkens, eyes narrowing:

“I thought that was you I heard swearing earlier. You better stop talking like that, or I might have to wash that mouth out with soap.” You gulp; she sounds serious and could easily do it. She has stopped, and is directing the entirety of her attention at you, her mouth in what appears to be a pursed expression. Clearly, she’s waiting for you to say something:

“Okay.” You say eventually, for lack of anything better to say. It apparently does the trick because, after a few more uncomfortable moments, she relents, saying:

“You were saying something about the floor?” her tone is neutral.

"Umm, yeah, uh, it was just..." you mumble off into incoherence. You really don't want a repeat explosion. Melanie looks at you, than rolls her eyes, sighing in exasperation:

"Look, I'm sorry; it's just that I had some bad experiences with this subject. But seriously, you've got to get over this fear thing. I'm not going to bite you in half whenever I get mad." You blanch at that image, especially as you are looking straight into her room-sized mouth at the time. She seems to realize this, and guilt flashes briefly on her face. She regards you for a moment, then:

“I’m not that intimidating, am I?” This question is coupled with such a piteous feline expression that you have to laugh at the incongruity. She brightens immediately: “See. I know we’ll break you out of it eventually. Now, tell me about the floor. Just don’t swear.” You sit there nonplussed for a moment, trying to wrap your mind around the giant mind-bending double mood swing you have just seen play out in front of you. Then you start to speak:

“Well, it’s just that the floor is cracked and uneven, making it very difficult for me to move around.” Now that the pain in your ankle has diminished, you find it easier to speak without swearing.

“Isn’t it like that at your house?”

“No!” You tell her emphatically, “We have wood, or tile, or carpet at home.” Then, seeing her blank look of incomprehension, you ask: “You do know what those are, right?”

“Of course I know what tile is!” She says indignantly, but hastily. You smirk:

“Ah, so you don’t know everything.” You say, nodding sagely. That leaves her sputtering in search of an answer, but you decide to relieve her pain, and you tell her what “wood” and “carpet” mean. She settles down on a couch in the living room (you had barely noticed the surroundings flit by) to finish the conversation:

“Okay, wood and tile are smooth and hard, and carpet is like fir, except short, hard and bristly.”

“That’s right.” She makes a face:

“The tile at school is hard enough on my claws; I can’t imagine what it would be like to have my claws caught in something like that. You humans, however, have such soft feet, it’s probably comfortable.” She reaches forward with a claw and carefully strokes the bottom of one of your foot with the smooth side. She’s right, the paw you are sitting on is as tough as leather compared to your skin. Suddenly, your stomach growls. Loudly. You haven’t eaten all day, after all, and there are some very interesting smells coming out of the kitchen. Molly laughs:

“Well, someone’s hungry.” You blush, and try to cover your embarrassment:

“What’s on the menu? It isn’t raw meat, is it?” you ask unwisely.

“Does your family eat unripe bananas and insects picked off each other’s bodies?” she retorts. You shake your head, duly chastised. “Then don’t assume we keep the same eating habits as out evolutionary precursors either.” Molly stands up and takes you into the dining room. Once there, you are confronted with the sight of Melanie’s dad, even taller than Melanie’s mom and broader still, sitting at the table with a number of sheaves of papers in front of him, scribbling furiously with a pen. Before he notices you and Melanie, you see Melanie’s mom walk in with a number of plates and pointedly seize a stack of papers to be replaced with her burden. Melanie’s dad glances up in annoyance which quickly turns to sheepishness as he sees the plates, then spots Melanie:

“There you are!” He bounds to his feet and moves over to Melanie, smiling and looming over her (and even more so you). Melanie prudently moves her hand away as she nuzzles her dad for a moment, you are thankful to skip a repeat performance of summersaults. Melanie’s dad turns his attention to you:

“Hello John, my name is Zacharius Prusten. Nice to meet you.” He extends a claw, which you shake. He probably could have shaken your entire body up and down with that one claw. Introduction made, Melanie sets you down on the table and the three tigers get to work. They are obviously practiced, and the meal quickly takes form. The table is already set for the anthros, but they do have to arrange your place. It is, thankfully, human sized (although, from their slightly odd proportions, not human made) utensils and plates which you receive, but they are set on top of what looks like a bottle cap and you end up sitting on what suspiciously resemble a thimble.

Melanie’s mom then brings in the food, centering around a massive hunk of meat, expertly prepared and glazed which rises above your head, and clearly comes from an animal which is proportioned to the anthros. You privately resolve to never go anywhere near an anthro zoo, as Mr. Prusten…
1132121211121222.title: First Dinner at Melanie's

choices: Melanie's family has a reasonable shower substitute.
Melanie's family cleans like true felines.
11321212111212222.content:
Mr. Prusten hacked and slashed furiously at the huge slab, carving out large chunks of meat that could each feed an army. You are repulsed by the display, which Melanie notices. "Haven't you ever seen meat being carved before, John? You'd think you were a herbivore by the look on your face!"

"No, that's not the problem, it's just your father's claws..."

"Oh, don't worry about that, I'm sure they're perfectly clean."

Although that was not what you were worried about, at least you don't have to worry about getting food poisoning on top of accidentally getting rendered. However, the carving is done, and Zacharias starts serving heaping portions to his family. Of course, he gave you a relatively small portion, which was still nearly the size of your head. "As our guest, you can have part of the tenderloin, John," spoke the huge father, showing his huge pointy teeth that could theoretically have your dinner stuck between two of them.

Not very concerned about what kind of animal the meat comes from, you start digging along with the rest of the tiger family. The food is delicious; it is like beef, but gamier and leaner. The meat is seasoned with tasty spices very thoroughly, and it is not too tough nor overcooked. You don't know how you do it, but you manage to eat the entire plate of meat before you.

You feel stuffed now, and the tigers also look full and content. Melanie very daintily wipes a few dozen pounds of meat off her face with a napkin, then says, "Thanks for the dinner, Mom and Dad. Can John and I be excused?"

You are a bit annoyed that Melanie is excusing you, but since it's not very likely that you can get off the table yourself, you dismiss your anger. Melanie's parents allowed her to pick you up and leave the table to go wash up.

"Wow, your parents sure are good cooks," you say to your feline companion. "What kind of meat was that, by the way?"

"Zebu," says Melanie. Seeing your confused face, she adds, "It's like an ox, but larger and a bit less heavily built."

You nod, but something new is starting to get to you. Melanie's parents said that you had to 'wash up', but Melanie is a tiger anthro, and tigers, being a part of the cat family, clean themselves by, you shudder, licking themselves. While dinner was for the most part very similar to a human dinner, you hope that Melanie has somewhere where you can wash in a manner you are accustomed to.
11321212111212222.title: Choice Cuts

113212121112122222.content:
As Melanie carries you up the stairs to the bathroom and sets you down on the counter. As your eyes look all over the bathroom you notice that their is not a shower in the room so you ask "Hey Melanie where is the shower."

She looks at you and tells you "Well since I am a tiger anthro I normally clean myself like all other felines do."

"But how am I supposed to clean myself then?" you ask Melanie.

"Well you can either use the sink or I could clean you up." says Melanie as she looks down at you.
113212121112122222.title: Melanie's family cleans like true felines.

1132121211121222222.content:
"Honestly Melanie, I think I prefer the sink." You tell her. The idea of having Melanie "clean you up" creeps you out. You and she have hit it off famously so far, especially given the difference in size and evolutionary ancestry, but still… you shudder. Looking up at her, you notice a little flash of something. Disappointment? Unfulfilled anticipation? You wonder. Whatever it is, it disappears and she nods:

“Okay.” You’re glad she didn’t argue. Reaching forward a story above your head, she turns a knob inset high up on the tiled wall. You hear the pipes in the wall give a tortured gasp and a shrill, high-pitched blast of air emerges from the sewer-outlet sized faucet on your right, but no water emerges. Frowning, she turns it left and right, her extended claws delicately slotted into the slots running all around the knob. Nothing but air emerges, so after a few moments she stops. She walks away from you, opening the door and yelling out:

“DAD! THE PIPES ARE SUCKING AIR AGAIN.” Her voice is enormous, and the acoustics of the bathroom make it physically painful to your relatively tiny ears. You miss his reply, but clearly he can’t do anything about it at this time of the evening. She comes back over, and you watch her apprehensively. Even for those few steps you see her walk is more... predatory, more aggressive. You swallow as, looking up past her expanse of striped fur and clothing towards her grinning face. She beams down at you:

"Well, it seems you get to try a new cultural experience, and I get to see what a human tastes like." Your heart flops in your chest and you take an involuntary step backwards. No way repeats over and over again in your head, but you force yourself to stay calm and reply:

”I don’t think so.” You try to sound firm and decisive, but your voice quavers. Noticing this she settles down onto her haunches, bringing her head down to your level. It’s meant to be reassuring, but it fails miserably as you are confronted with her wall-sized face, her mouth showing rows of very sharp teeth, which you saw tear through a chunk of meat five times your size at dinner. You watch, unmoving, as her nostrils flair and she takes in a theatrical sniff. Finally (even in your apprehension you manage to think Keep me waiting why don’t ya?) she speaks:

“John, you know that smelling fear thing? I wasn’t kidding, and it’s quite palpable around you. Wait,” she says, holding up a paw, “Now, kidding aside, we’re not animals, despite somewhat biased viewpoints on both sides.” She grins wryly, and you give her a wan smile, “Since we’re not animals, you’re not going to let your fear control you like your tiny prehistoric ape ancestors would, and I’m not going to eat you like my normal-sized cat ancestors would.” Finished, she looks down for a moment, probably embarrassed at giving a speech. Somewhat rattled yourself, you are still determined to break the tension:

“’Tiny apes’ and ‘normal-sized’ cats, eh? What was it you said about ‘biased viewpoints?’” You ask, smiling. Tension dropping, she stands back up:

“I don’t know what you’re talking about.” She says mock-huffily, producing a laugh from you. Then, more seriously: “You ready?”

“Be patient Melanie,” You chide her, “Good things come to those who wait.”

“Why put off to tomorrow what you can do today?” She replies. She brings a paw down and nudges that back of your legs insistently. You sigh, and acquiesce, sitting down carefully with your legs dangling over the sides of her paw. She carefully lifts you into the air, bringing you with her a few steps (to her) across the bathroom to the second counter you noticed earlier. As the coming ordeal draws nearer and your heart rate starts to speed up once more, you distract yourself by complaining:

“You always seem to get your way.” You manage to keep a whining tone from your voice, so Melanie simply lets you hop off her paw onto the counter (somewhat slipperier than the other) before turning around, placing her paws on the counter behind her for balance and hopping up on her butt onto the counter:

“Perhaps it has something to do with the fact that I’m ten times your size?” She suggests lightly, looking down sideways at you.

“Perhaps,” You concede taking in the enormity of her form, so quickly, dexterously and casually tossed about, “Although an argument could be made for those teeth.” you give a shudder which is only half faked. She grins down at you, displaying her full, extremely sharp set:

”I can see how someone the size of a large rat might see it that way.” She says, straight faced. You can’t let that go unchallenged:

“Hey, watch who you’re calling a rat, you big fur ball.” You both laugh and she gives you a comradely flick on the arm with a claw. She reaches over to a ledge above your head, grabbing a small paper cup filled with some kind of liquid. Noting your curious gaze, she lowers it down to you. Peering inside, you see a small pool of translucent, pale green liquid, which gives off a very subtle scent, a cross between antiseptic and mint. Comprehension dawns:

“Is this mouthwash?” You ask her. She shakes her head:

“More like tongue wash. Neither you nor I want to end up smelling like meat after this, so I’ll swirl this around my tongue to remove any lingering traces.” With that, she tosses the liquid into her mouth and commences swishing. Sounds like mouthwash to me, you think to yourself. She thoroughly swished the liquid around in her mouth, then spat it out into the kiddy-pool sized cup. Setting this aside, she swiftly and unceremoniously grabs you. With a small yelp you are brought before her face, her foreclaw hooked into the back of your shirt and you nearly vertical before her. You do your best to remain calm and not hyperventilate, despite your racing heartbeat. Grasping at anything to delay the upcoming ordeal, you blurt out:

"W-Wait, don't I need to take off my clothes?" You regret the words the instant they leave your mouth. Melanie pauses, then roles her eyes:

"Do you really want to get undressed?" She asks you pointedly

"Uh, no, not really."

"I wouldn’t like that either. Do remove your shoes, however" She says firmly. You obediently shuck them, and they fall through the air down to her waiting paw. Looking up, you see her face start to go through strange contortions: "I'll just have too," She murmurs thickly and slowly, "Use more spit than I usually do to get... through the cloth."

"Wait, more spit ..." Is all you can get out in a high-pitched voice before, seemingly satisfied with the volume of saliva in her mouth, she stops grimacing, leans forward, opens her mouth and smothers you with her tongue All you get is a brief impression of her yawning closet of a mouth and her flexible pink carpet of a tongue before it covers you like a very wet blanket. Her feline tongue, you know, is far larger proportionally than a human tongue, and it is just large enough to cover your entire body. You are instantly soaked in her slightly sticky spit, and she starts moving her tongue slimily up and down your body. Your involuntary struggles are, of course, meaningless to her, and she simply pins them with her tongue when she needs access. It seems to go on forever, the thick slab of muscle roving over your body for an eternity. You can't see anything and you can barely breathe, your mouth almost covered with saliva. At last, however, with a few more desultory licks, she lifts her tongue.

You look blearily out at her through your saliva-covered eyes. She merely grins at you, however, and deftly flips you over in her paw. This time, your face is not covered by the tongue, and she had mercifully positioned your head so that it was in the gap between two of her claws, along you to breathe, and to see a hazy-white light. She is just as thorough as before, and your body is repeatedly slammed into her palm, although thankfully not very hard. This time, once she is finished with her genera cleaning she goes after specific areas. The bottom of your feet- you half to laugh, even something as big as her tongue tickles there. The top of your head- your chin is slammed into the webbing between her claws. She then withdraws for a second, before delicately, with a hint of a chuckle coming from behind you, using the tip of her tongue to deliver an unreasonable (it seems to you) amount of her natural cleaning solution to areas she clearly thinks are most dirty. She starts with your hands, but then, to your chagrin, she gets behind your ears and at the back of your neck. Finally she finishes and lets you face her once more. You hang from her claw, limp.

"Squeaky clean now, and totally soaked," she says, trying and failing to hide a smirk. "Now we need to get you dry." She smothers you again, but this time is different. Her tongue, which before had been thoroughly lubricated, is now bone dry. You can feel the individual bumps of her taste buds, and on the few areas of exposed skin you have your skin feels almost abraded. She does one slow lick for your front, one for your back and one for your head. That hurt. Your hair feels like its getting pulled out of your scalp, and you yell in pain. She pauses for a second, then gently licks your hair back down onto your scalp. With that, she pulls back once more and examines you:

"Sorry about the hair." She says contritely. She leans over to her side and picks something up, out of your view. "For my ancestors, that would've been it, but thanks to the wonders of modern technology we can ensure..." She trails off as you cough something out, sputtering on her saliva. She turns her head so an ear faced you:

"What was that."

"I said," You say, coughing, "What's with this 'we'. This seems like a very one-sided process to me." That's all you have the energy for. She blinks once, slowly, than smiles appreciatively:

"Okay then, thanks to the wonders of technology I can ensure that you are totally dry." With that, she brings an enormous hairdryer into your view. You look at it in dread, its mouth alone could swallow you (widthwise) whole. She adjusts her drip so you are truly dangling in mid air, suspended by a claw (if you weren't so exhausted you would be terrified of a fall, surely your shirt can't take this type of punishment). She points the hairdryer at you and turns it on, full power. You are buffeted by hurricane force winds of a truly extreme heat, like in the middle of the desert. You are blown around on her claw, forced back and up like a pendulum. She rotates her paw so that you are entirely exposed, the heat just barely low enough so that you don't get burned. She finishes and shuts it off. She eyes you critically for a moment, before gently setting you on your feet next to her. You take a few wobbly steps before falling heavily over, only barely caught by her paw. She frowns at you for a moment, before lithely getting off the counter and opening the bathroom door. Stepping into the hallway, she sets you down on an end table across the hall from the bathroom door, arranging you so that your back is up against a table lamp. You sit there, with barely the energy to slowly move your head and look at her.

Melanie looks down at you with a grin, only slightly abashed by your bedraggled condition.

"The rat analogy continues, now you're like a drowned one." She grins at her own pun. You appreciate the humor, and grin slightly yourself. Encouraged, she continues: "Anyway, it turns out that you don't taste so bad, different from what I usually eat though, exotic."

"I'm glad I gave you the opportunity to expand your cuisine." You tell her hoarsely. She takes both the sarcasm and the truth in your comment, absorbing it. Then, quietly:

"Thanks John." You give her a weak thumbs-up sign. She steps back:

"I'm going to clean myself now, so don't you go anywhere." She calls back over her shoulder. There’s no real chance of that. You're not in pain, but you are entirely exhausted by the ordeal. You simply sit there, in a kind of haze, leaning up against the lamp which is almost blinding in intensity, you being directly under the shade. You can't sleep, so you just sit unmoving until...
1132121211121222222.title: A Spit Bath

11321212111212222221.content:
Eventually, you hear the door open across the hall and a dark mass looms up. You know it's Melanie, but the lamp's intense light has blinded your vision, so all you get is an impression of her size and shape. The monolithic figure hesitates for a second upon reaching the table and seeing you, but then she reaches forward and carefully picks you up in one paw. She walks into her room, closing the door behind her and setting you on her desk. You sit up and stretch, your exhaustion fading. It hadn't really come from exertion, after all, just a feeling of being overwhelmed. You blink rapidly as the spots disappear from your eyes, looking around. The dark grey tinge over everything slowly fades, leaving you able to see once more. Looking over at Melanie, you are confronted with the sight of a massive expanse of white. You blink again. are my eyes playing tricks on me? you wonder. Shaking your head and looking again, you crane your head up. Melanie is standing directly in front of her desk, her head far above yours. She's clutching a large, white, fuzzy towel around her body, and her head is darting around clearly looking for something. Eventually she looks down at you, something very much like consternation written on her face. You can't think of anything to say, and her eyes scan past you, settling on something behind you. She reaches down, her paw hovering over you for a second, blocking your sight. She moves it over behind you, and you here a click and a smooth whooshing sound. Looking behind you, you see a large section of the desk rising up, a panel the size of the outside cellar doors in a human house.

"What..." you ask, confused. Melanie glances at you swiftly,

"In you get." She tells you, "I need to change." You climb slowly to your feet, too wise to argue. Melanie, clearly impatient, “helps” you to the dark hole in the desk, essentially by putting her paw on your back and scooting you across her desk. You nearly go plummeting face first into the receptacle, only saved by two of her claws closing on the back of your shirt, brining you back up with a jerk. You look back up at her dubiously, the receptacle is barely illuminated. “In.” She says shortly. You raise your hands:

“All right, all right.” You take hold of the edge and swing yourself over. Your feet don’t touch bottom. Swallowing, you let go. You fall for less than a second before hitting the floor. The panel closes above you swiftly, leaving you in darkness. The wood isn’t thick, and you can here her moving around outside the desk. To amuse yourself, and relive your anxiety at being trapped, you carefully explore the space. It’s not very large, only a few paces in any direction, and you know the “ceiling” is only a little higher than your height with outstretched arms. You stumble over various objects, but you can’t identify them. Eventually, you settle for just sitting there, waiting and listening. You’re prepared for a long wait, since girls always seem to take a long time changing. Melanie is merciful, however, and long before you start to go stir crazy you hear the click again. The panel rises, letting in a blinding amount of light. You shield your eyes and feel Melanie pick you up again, placing your feet on her desk. When you can see again, you notice that your giant host is now seated so that she looms over you only slightly. She’s giving you an apologetic look:

“Sorry for being so abrupt.” The sincerity of her tone is obvious, so you let it pass:

“It’s alright.” You turn to the receptacle, contents more brightly illuminated now that Melanie has turned on all the room’s lights, “What is this place?” She peers over your head:

“Oh that? It’s where I keep my random electronic junk, portable storage, IDN connectors, spare…” She grins at you, “mice.” You glare at her, but she continues blithely, “Seems kind of appropriate now that I think about it.” You recall her rodent comments from before

“Ha ha, very funny.” You tell her flatly.

“I thought so.” She reaches over your head and uses a claw to press the wooden panel down. It sinks below the level of the desk, than comes back up and catches. She puts her elbows on the desk and crosses her fingers in the air above you, resting her chin on them. This forms a large, orange-colored arch, at the top of which her eyes stare down at you, considering.

“Well, now what?” She asks you. You shrug,

“I don’t know, it’s your house. What’s there to do?”

“Well, we could play a game, we’ve got some time before bed. Hmmm.” She scoots backwards and leans down. You are placed in the unique position of looking down at the broad expanse of Melanie’s back, covered now in a loose blue tee-shirt. Beyond that, you can make out the back of her chair, and past this you can just barely make out a glimpse of sinuous motion that can only be her tail.

With an "ahah!" Melanie jerks backwards, causing a cascade of other objects that you can feel through the desk's surface. She straightens up, showing you her prize. Clasped tight between her two paws is a large, white and black sphere:

“I thought we could try out some soccer!’ She informs you brightly.

“Great! I like soccer!”

“Cool, I guess we can…” She trails off, a thought clearly occurring to her. She looks between the ball and you, between you and the ball. She reaches forward and carefully sets the ball on the desk, with its distinct, if much amplified, rubbery sound. You see the problem at once. The ball is about two feet taller than you are, and you could easily fit inside it yourself. Heck, a third of my room could fit in there with room to spare you think to yourself. You step back hastily as the ball gives a slight movement and starts to roll in your direction. Melanie, seeing the danger, thankfully stabilizes before it had rolled more than a foot, her paw resting on top of it. You give her a relieved glance:

“Thanks, getting squashed by that ball probably wouldn’t kill me, but it sure would hurt.” She nods gravely:

"Soccer's definitely out." She says firmly, removing the ball. You breath easier with it gone. One slip on Melanie's part might've sent you to the hospital.

“How about a nice, safe game of chess?” She asks you. Her tone is over-bright, and you don’t quite like the way she used the word “safe” so…. condescendingly. However, it’s not like you have a choice, so you respond:

“Okay”. She nods and stands up, You watch her move off to another shelf in her room, whose contents you can’t see from your angle. She hesitates, than turns and gives you a mischievous grin, one that makes you gulp even across the not-inconsiderable distance of her room.

“Hold on, I just remembered….” She walks out of the room. You wait, frowning. From what you’ve seen of her so far, you know that Melanie is usually quite nice, but she doesn’t always handle disappointments as well as she should. You hope she isn’t planning an elaborate revenge for not being able to play soccer with you. These hopes are dashed when, upon her return, you see that Melanie is carrying a truly massive chess set. She is clearly struggling to lift it, it’s wider than her torso and she’s bowed awkwardly under its weight. Melanie stands there for a moment, panting, leaning the board on a bedpost. She hoists the chessboard up again and staggers towards her desk. As she looms closer and closer and the shadow of the board creeps over you, you realize you are in serious danger,. You scramble out of the way. You feel like you are creeping across the desk, the hairs on your head stand on end as Melanie reaches her desk and the board hovers over you. You know there is no way you would’ve made it if Melanie hadn’t halted the board’s downward motion, keeping it from squishing you. As it is, you are barely a foot away from the edge of the board as it SLAMMS down behind you. The rush of air nearly causes you to fall over, but you recover your balance. Turning, you see Melanie sit down heavily in her chair, looking pleased with herself. You take the opportunity to approach the board.

The height is considerable for such an object; you have to step high to reach the top. Once on top, you are looking out along a checkered vista, about ten yards by ten yards. Over at the far end, Melanie gazes down at the board for a moment before bringing up a large cloth bag. She fiddles with the tie for a moment, opening it and setting it on the board, where it covers most of the center squares. She reaches forward and carefully upends it on the board, Despite her care, a large number of the door-sized objects bounce across the board, and you hotfoot it to avoid them, When they finally settle down, you find yourself looking at a large number of sculptures of tigers in various getups, lying all askew. Clearly, these are the pieces. You here a few thunks from across the way. Turning, you see Melanie rapidly picking up, examining and placing the pieces. Her hand is so large and fast that you have a hard time following it, it resembles very much an industrial crane at this moment. Suddenly, you see her pick up a black piece and head towards you. You duck your head just in time from keeping it from getting knocked off as she sets a black rook (although it in fact is carved to resemble a tiger in inordinately large amounts of armor) on one side. You walk to the center of the board to keep out of the way. When she's finished, you can see two double lines of figures, all larger than you, facing each other. The white and black lines are quite far apart, but you still feel slightly claustrophobic, a deer in the headlights. Going over to one, you see (to your immense irritation) that even the pawns tower over you by a few inches. Behind them, the larger pieces loom still higher, the rooks, bishops and knights (although not resembling any human game pieces) easily one and a half times your height, while the king and queen reign over them all (and you) at twice your height. Your contemplation is cut abruptly short as you feel a pressure on your back. You turn in time to catch Melanie's sweeping pad in the front instead of the back. She hoists you effortlessly into the air, giving you a view of the entire board (which is clearly oversized, even to Melanie). She reaches forward with her other hand and picks up the black and white kings, setting them aside. Without a word she reaches forward and sets you in the black king's spot Your claustrophobia is magnified ten fold as the black queen on your left, a voluptuous tiger women with a crown and a massive sword, and a bishop (a robe-clad tiger) rise over you on either side. You can't even see the white lines well without moving, as you are staring at the back of the pawn in front of you. Your attention is torn by Melanie, who finally decides to speak:

"So, do you like your forces, little king?" She asks you. You glare at her, feeling a bit fed up at her elaborate attempts to make you feel small:

"Little king? Listen here Melanie, this is way over the top..." You Yell at her. She just wags a claw:
