"Now now, be nice. I could've made you a pawn." This does little to settle your discontent, but, deciding to mind your manners as a guest, you tolerate it. "Speaking of pawns..." her voice trails away as she grabs two pawns, a black in one hand and a white in the other, than moves them out of sight (in this case simply behind the white lines, which are impenetrable to your gaze at this distance) and shuffles them, then grabs them again. She leans forward enough so that each palm hovers over the black lines:

"Well, since you clearly can't do this, I'll offer you the pick of color. Pick a paw."

"The right one." You tell her.

"Your right or my right?" She asks you innocently.

"My right." You call back, annoyed.

"All right then, my right it is." She says decisively, opening the paw on your left.

"Okay then, you're playing...
11321212111212222221.title: Evening Activities

choices: ...“Sorry about the game. I might have gotten a little carried away.”
113212121112122222211.content:
“I guess you’re white.” She says. Before you know what is happening, she swiftly plucks you off the board, moves you to the other end and drops you in the white king’s space. You stumble dizzily for a moment before recovering. Turning, you see that Melanie has gripped the board on either end. With a powerful jerk she spins the board around so that she has the black end. Her room flashes by in front of you as you are knocked on your back by the powerful motion. Standing, you weave dizzily on your space as you try not to lose your very large dinner. When you recover, you look up at Melanie, who is looking very amused:

“Your move.” Deciding that there’s nothing to be done except let her have her fun, you grudgingly comply. You can still barely see anything, being surrounded by a mass of white wood is, if anything, even worse, as now as well as being cut off you are also blinded as Melanie’s desk lamp reflects off their gleaming surfaces. You decide to go with the classic opening, which will allow you to at least see the black end of the board:

“King’s pawn to D-5” you shout up at Melanie. She just looks down at you with a self-satisfied smirk on her face. The silence stretches for a moment, then you roll your eyes. I hope it’s not too heavy , you think as you step up to the pawn and brace yourself. With a heave, you push the pawn forward. Thankfully it’s not as heavy as it could be, given that its solid wood, and it whispers across the board on what appears to be a felt covering on its base. Still, it takes some effort to move it the requisite two spaces. You step backwards, looking around. The board remains as it was, but you hear a noise above you. Melanie is making a very half-hearted attempt to conceal her snickers with a paw. You glare at her, which sets her off again. Eventually, you wise up, turn your back on her and walk back to your space. You turn and wait, arms crossed over your chest.

"Are we playing chess or am I just doing this to amuse you?" You ask her, half rhetorically, half seriously. She regains her composure, looking a bit shamefaced, but still quite amused. She reaches down, and in a manner similar to that of an industrial crane lifts up her queen's knight and moves it to cover your pawn. With that, the game begins in earnest.

Considering the multitude of disadvantages you are faced with, you do rather well. Despite her playful attitude and her antics with the chess set, when Melanie settles down to play chess she is a skilled and ruthless player. She quickly seizes the initiative, placing her two bishops in the center of the board and using them to try and constrain your movement, then exploiting openings to get at your large(r) pieces. For your part, you have to play a defensive game, moving your pawns to try and protect your large pieces. The main difficulty is, of course, your inability to see the entire board. Even the pawns are slightly taller than you are, so your range of vision, especially as the game progresses and the board gets cluttered. You can see Melanie, of course, and her paw moving her pieces around, but identifying exactly which pieces those are, and where they’re going to and coming from is nearly impossible, you have to go and investigate.

In addition to having to run around the board, trying to keep a mental picture in your head of the action, you’re also kept on your toes. Melanie’s responses are quick and immediate, often you don’t even make it back to your space before she goes (which adds the problem of having your back turned when she moves). This is especially true when she’s exploiting openings you missed. Once, for instance, when you had just finished moving a rook she slams her bishop all the way across the board, sending your rook flying and knocking you onto your butt. She just barely missed your toes with the attack. She collects the piece and adds it to the dismal line on the side of the board (which you can just barely make out), and you stand up, brushing yourself off. The game continues, and you’re thankful that it isn’t timed. Melanie would be even more aggressive, and how would you ever manage to push the button on a clock scaled for anthros?

Moving the pieces around is, of course, your source of greatest difficulty. While the pawns are slightly bigger than you, they pose little challenge. The larger pieces, especially the knight, are far more serious problems. You greatest “joy” however, is the queen. Standing at twice your height, moving it around is damm near impossible. You have to lean it over onto your back and haul it around the board at a tortuously slow pace, often knocking other pieces off their spaces. Since it’s twice the size of the pawns, it’s also twice as heavy, and your exertions are so pronounced that you feel something like relief when she manages to rid you of it in a queen-bishop exchange. That’s the beginning of the end for you. Despite a coup you manage to pull off a few turns later, taking her other bishop through an opening that you didn’t even see until that turn, she slowly annihilates your defense and corners you-literally. As your forces are swept from the board, you run into more problems. Throughout the game, Melanie has tried to restrict your movement. Numerous times you would find your way between two pieces blocked by a white pillar topped by orange fur, Melanie’s foreclaw, a column of fur flesh extended by the conical, pointed claw itself, stuck into the board to cut you off, followed by a comment along the lines of

“I don’t need to move my paw all the way around the board on my turn, why should you need to move yourself?” You just ignore her on these occasions, and move around her claw. Unfortunately, sometimes she presses her “point” and tries to nab you off the board when you ignore her. You come up with a fairly simple counter-strategy. Whenever Melanie tries to grab you, you duck into a cluster of pieces and yell at her not to touch the pieces when it isn’t her turn. It is quite effective at first, but as the game goes on there are fewer and fewer pieces (especially white ones) that you can hide among, the consequence being that she can get you more and more. By then, however, it is far less important. The board is far more open now, and you are quite able to see your doom approaching in the corner that you’ve taken refuge in. At last, Melanie moves her queen into position, setting it down with a large thunk:

“Check.” You had expected the move, as it was obvious, putting the queen two spaces diagonally from you. You turn to your rook, which you had been using as a shield in front of you. You brace yourself against it to move it a space to the right, shielding you from the queen. When you start to push, however, you find that it is suddenly immovable. You strain for a while before realizing that something is up. Looking around the rook, you see that Melanie has placed her paw back on to the rook, pitting your strength against that of her paw. You lose, no question. By now you’re so tired that you can barely move, let alone yell loud enough to be heard, so you simply glare up at her in exasperation. She glances significantly down at the board. Turning, you see the foreeclaw of her other paw tapping her rook at the other end of the board. To your dismay, it’s covering your rook, so if you move it, you’ll put yourself in check, which is not permitted. You sigh, then turn and walk one space to the left of your original space, getting out of check. With an awful inevitability Melanie pounces, sliding her rook across the board slowly and carefully knocking your rook off the space. Now all you have is a few pawns and a knight on the other side of the board. It’s your turn, but you can’t move yourself as king, as you’re pinned by the rook, which is in turn covered by one of Melanie’s knights. You just stand there for a moment, than gather yourself together. Your doom is assured, but at least you can go out with some dignity. You turn to track wearily across the board to uselessly move one of your remaining pieces, but you are brought up short. Melanie has a claw hovering over your knight, a questioning look in her eyes. You nod, and she moves it for you, something she hasn’t done all game. Having moved you knight, Melanie her paw over to her queen. She picks it up her queen and sets it down a few spaces over with an air of finality:

“Checkmate.” It’s over is all you can think, relieved. Then, your back stiffens. Melanie, who had become far more somber and serious as the game wore on, is grinning. “You lost, so your king has to be knocked over.” She informs you, you back away, shaking your head, but of course there’s no where to go. The massive black queen rises into the air and then starts slowly swinging forward like a wrecking ball, heading straight for you!

“Oof” the base of the queen hits you in the chest. Melanie probably did everything possible to make it no more than a gentle tap, at least from her perspective, but it still lifts you off your feet and knocks you onto your butt. You lay on your back for a moment, gasping. You gently probe your chest with a free hand, discovering no broken ribs, and not even a very large bruise. Melanie had judged the amount of force to a tee. It didn’t even hurt that much. You push yourself up into a sitting position, just in time to see Melanie’s claws coming straight for you! She grabs you by the collar behind your neck, a spot she seems to prefer, and lifts you off the board. Depositing you on the other side in front of her monolithic black queen, she says:

“Now, kneel before the victorious queen.” Now, you know this game has entirely been about satisfying Melanie’s whims and you had resigned yourself to the fact, but this borders on the absurd. You consider refusing for a moment, but then a better idea strikes you. You kneel to the queen, which already towers over you, and thus by inference, since Melanie is directly behind her queen, to your giant, power-tripping host. After this, however, you take it farther, abasing yourself with your face on the board and your arms extended before you:

“Please accept, most glorious and large victor, my humblest praise. Clearly, you are the master of this game, nay this art. I never even had the shadow of a hope of victory, your mighty and gigantic form was simply overwhelming beyond words…”

“Uhh! Stop.” You look up, see that Melanie looks supremely uncomfortable and get to your feet, brushing the dust off your clothing.

“Should I go on?” You ask her, “Talk about how this humble worm is not fit to grovel in your majestic presence, perhaps?” Melanie is uncharacteristically silent, looking distinctly uncomfortable. Your point was made. She reaches forward again, but this time instead of picking you up she gently shepherds you off the board, than starts picking up the pieces, sticking them back in the cloth bag. When she’s finished, she stands, picks up the board and walks out of the room. Returning, she stands in front of her desk, an expanse of blue on orange and black, with a small sliver of navy towards the bottom where her sweats meet her loose blue t-shirt. Kneeling by her bed, she pulls something out of her backpack, then turns and offers it to you. It’s your backpack, and a large bag containing, among other things, your toothbrush, a change of clothes, your PJs and a duffel bag. Her giant voice rumbles from behind you while you’re rummaging through the bag...
113212121112122222211.title: White

1132121211121222222111.content:
“Sorry about the game. I might have gotten a little carried away.” You don’t turn, knowing that she is probably really embarrassed right now. You wave your hand idly:

Turning, you see that Melanie seems to have recovered her composure. You give a theatrical yawn:

“Man, it was fun but moving those pieces around wiped me out.” Melanie smiled and nodded her agreement:

“Yeah. I think it’s bedtime.” She nods to the PJs in your hand, “You need to get changed?” She asks. You nod, looking around. There’s no cover in sight:

“Uh, Melanie…”

“Relax, I’ve got you covered.” She pauses for a second, than:”No pun intended.” You groan, and she laughs. She bends over and opens up the same panel on her desk. She grabs you and lowers you inside:

“I’ll be back in three minutes.” She warns as she shuts the top. The darkness, your overactive imagination and your resulting clumsy, too quick movements nearly cause you to miss that deadline. You’re barely decent before the click comes again. Your super-dilated pupils can’t take the light, you flinch and shield them. You feel Melanie grab you and lift you up; when you can see again, you’re being held at arm’s length, gently turning as Melanie twists her paw around, inspecting you from all sides. You lower your arm and wait. Eventually, appearing satisfied, she looks at you solemnly:

“John…”

“Melanie?” She hesitates for a second, than, a grin breaking out: “You look like a black-striped red mouse!” Having expected something like this, you quickly return:

“And you look like a giant orange, blue, black…. thing.” You conclude lamely. She gives a bark of laughter, and you wobble uncontrollably, nearly losing your balance on her paw as it twitches.

“Nice comeback. Here, grab your toothbrush.” You do so, and she walks to the bathroom. Once there, she sets you down on the counter and reaches up, extracting her own, 4X4 length toothbrush from a niche that’s obscured from your sight because of the angle, as well as a tube of toothpaste and another of her seemingly infinite supply of small paper Dixie cups. Setting these aside and turning the knob for the sink, she is rewarded with a massive gush of super-pressurized water which falls almost your own height before reaching the drain and being sucked down. She fills the cup with water, and then offers both it and the toothpaste to you. You carefully swirl your toothbrush inside the opening of your tube, its large enough to accommodate your toothbrush, and then swish it in the water. You brush quickly, spit into the massive sink in a rather pathetic dribble, and then turn to watch Melanie.

She is in the process of carefully polishing her fangs, which make up the vast majority of her teeth except for a few flat molars you noticed in the back during your cleaning. She works quite industriously, creating quite a foam. You’re glad that you can’t see very well, even from here you can see some dried juices being swept away, giving a slight pink tinge to the paste. When she’s finished, she reaches down and grabs the Dixie cup, swirls the water in her mouth and spits it all out. Her output is far greater than your own, several gallons at least. She then breaks off a piece of floss and offers it to you. You shake your head:

“I don’t think that’ll work.” The floss she offered you was as thick as moderate rope, and would never fit between your teeth. She shrugs, then begins flossing. To distract yourself, you make conversation:

“So, you guys have red mice?” She nods:

“Yeah, and they’re about your size.” It’s difficult to make out her words, but you manage.

“I kind of got that. Anyway, we only have white, brown and black mice.”

“We have those to, but the red ones were considered delicacies to those of my ancestors who lived as desert nomads.” You nod; red mice would’ve had a camouflage advantage on the famously crimson sand of that desert. Melanie tosses her floss off to the side into a trash can below the counter, than grabs you again. Emerging from the bathroom, you both see two planks of wood leaning against Melanie’s doorframe.

She walks over to them and sets you on the floor. As she gets into position to lift the two pieces, you notice that the long one is actually taller than she is! The notion boggles your mind so much that you nearly get decapitated as the base of the long piece of wood sweeps across the floor as Melanie turns it into a horizontal position. You see the large base sweep barely a foot in front of your face. The rush of air following its displacement beats against your chest and tears at your hair. You smooth down your hair and straighten your clothes, heart pounding. Melanie appears not to have noticed, simply continuing the motion until she’s standing with the boards held horizontally in front of her. The boards hover in the air far above you, creating a small area of shadow and blocking out Melanie’s body and head. You try not to think about the consequences of her dropping those boards. Sensing movement, you turn and see Melanie inching forward her foot gingerly, carefully prodding the area in front of her. You move aside several times as she sweeps the floor around her. Eventually:

“Uh, John? I can’t see you, please touch my foot.” You comply, moving over to one of the tall structures and tapping. You feel a bit shorter just standing next to it; your head barely reaches halfway to her knee. “Thanks, follow me in but keep a wide berth.” She carefully lifts her foot up and over, using a single claw resting on your shoulder to keep you still. You flinch momentarily as it’s directly over you, but she quickly move sit, settling it down to your. She starts slowly sidling into the room sideways, moving slowly enough that even you can keep up with her, once more moving across the uneven floor. You have to jump to avoid her tail, though.

Once inside, she went through another complicated turning operation, admonishing you to “stay out of the way”. She is clearly tired and out of breath, and you note with concern that the boards are shaking somewhat. Apparently they’re very heavy. It also makes you wonder about the relative strength of humans and anthro tigers. You grimace. In actual strength you think to yourself wryly, she could toss me around this room, and I would need a crane to lift those boards. She sets the wood carefully down in front of her desk, and waits for a moment, massaging her biceps.

“Tired? They looked pretty heavy.” You tell her in a faux-sympathetic voice. She glares down and back at you, you having walked unnoticed up behind her, but says nothing. You gesture towards the pile of wood. “So, what’s all that for?” You ask. She considers for a moment, then that familiar grin appears:

“I’ll show you. In fact, you can help me test it.” You don’t like the sound of that and start to back away. You are brought up short, however, when you back into a thick, springy ropelike barrier. Looking over your shoulder, you see that Melanie has moved her long, thick tail to block your escape. She chuckles, and her tail applies pressure on your back, you are swept across the floor as Melanie swishes her tail around her body, causing you to smack straight into her waiting pad. She jerks you into the air and sets you down seconds later on one of the boards. “Hold on.” She advises you. She grabs the board, one hand grasping the closer edge in front of you, the other reaching across and grabbing the other edge behind you. With a grunt she jerks the board into the air. That alone nearly sends you flying off the board as the unstable surface wobbles, but after that as she lifts the board up past waist height to chest height she begins to tilt it. At first it is almost vertical as Melanie adjusts the board so that one edge is resting on top of her desk, and you have an unpleasant moment of near-freefall before impacting against Melanie’s wrist with a thud. You grab her fur and hang on grimly, wishing it was over. Once the board is firmly set, Melanie quickly moves the edge of the board on the floor, so that the angle is much less steep. You release your death grip on her arm.

“That about does it.” She tells you, frowning down at her wrist, where two spots of matted ad twisted fur are clearly visible. She licks and smoothes them, then prods you forward. You walk up the slope, glad that someone (probably Melanie’s dad) had sanded the wood to a degree that even human-scaled feet aren’t in danger of getting splinters. You ascend past Melanie’s face, with her scooting minutely sideways on her haunches to keep up with her progress. When you reach the top, you turn to survey your progress, pumping your hands in the air ironically. Melanie pulls out a gigantic roll of duct tape, pulls on the end and roughly places a length of sticky grey plastic over the end of the board, sheering it off with her claw. As she repeats the procedure at the other end of the board and sets up the other board so it goes between the desk and her nightstand, you examine the duct tape. It looks identical to the duct tape you use at home, if much, much bigger, but you find when you experimentally tug on a corner it’s much more adhesive at well. You can lift it, barely, but it takes a lot of effort.

“That’s one of you humans’ best inventions.” Melanie’s voice sounds like it’s right in your ear, and you jump. She chuckles, and turning you see that Melanie had indeed leaned forward so her face was right behind you. She withdraws her head and gestures to her nightstand. You grab your bag, backpack and sleeping bag, and then head over across the newly-installed bridge while Melanie takes the few steps required to move to her bed and sit down. .

You walk across the stand and approach Melanie’s bed. You set your stuff down close to the bed. A quick puff of air from Melanie makes you look at her closely, staring down at you, but any mirth there might have been was quickly wiped away, she just continues to examine you with interest. Your suspicions, honed by an evening of her devilish, if good-hearted, size pranks, are far from alleviated, so you remain tensed as you spread out your sleeping bag and pillow. Surprisingly, nothing happens. When you finish, she gently places your sloes, held incongruously by sticking the tip of her claw in the openings, next to your stuff:

“That setup is so you can, uh, use the bathroom during the night without needing to wake me up. Î tend to get grump when I am woken during the night.”

“I kind of figured.” She gives you a dirty look, your comment could have related to either point she made. Her arm hovers over you for a moment as she clicks on her lamp. You shade your eyes and turn your head, but the light is blinding, the nightstand being small enough that even at the end you are under the lampshade. You hear a few clicks and the rustling of large amounts of cloth, the creak of huge bedsprings, and then Melanie clicks off the lamp again. The darkness afterwards is impenetrable to your super-dilated pupils, but once your eyes adjust you stand on the edge for a moment, surveying Melanie’s bed. It’s a dark expanse that stretches away from you, with Melanie’s form rising up as a almost formless mass. After a few moments of looking, contemplating your truly unique situation, you turn and crawl into your sleeping bag. As your head hits the pillow, you hear Melanie, who you believe has been watching you with as much interest as you had of her, say:

“Good night John.”

“Good Night. Melanie.”


Once, during the night, you have occasion to be thankful for Melanie’s trouble. Feeling the urgent call of nature, you claw your way out of your entangling sleeping bag and head for the bathroom, Melanie’s sleeping on oblivious, her large presence seeming to hang in the air above you. You had discovered that Melanie doesn’t snore, thankfully, but she breathes very deeply when she sleeps, giving an unearthly quality to the room, as the sound of her breathing echoed through the room, never diminishing. Thankfully for your sleep addled mind, the planks are so wide, about the same as your hallways at home, that you can stumble across them without too much danger of falling to your death. You squeeze out of the small crack Melanie left in the door, than head for the bathroom. You have a bad moment when you find the bathroom door seemingly closed, but on closer examination you see that there is still a foot of clearance left, only a bit more than an inch for an anthro but easily sufficient for your needs. The darkness inside the bathroom, where the light from the small hallway lamp does not reach, is somewhat of a hindrance, but by now your eyes have adjusted and you finish rapidly. You return to Melanie’s room, stumbling over the uneven floor but not cursing, as you are now very afraid of Melanie’s preternatural hearing, even when asleep. You ascend the makeshift ramp once more, but you pause when you reach the top, a whim striking you. Seeing that Melanie is deeply, deeply asleep, you move stealthily over to the panel you had been dumped through several times before. Its position is hard to discern, especially in the dark, but by kneeling and rubbing your fingers over the wood you can discern the crack. It’s actually an excellent piece of craftsmanship; if the crack is fine and hardly discernable to you, than it must be totally invisible to an anthro without a magnifying glass.

You stand and set one foot on the panel, both hands on top of the connected leg. You push down with all your strength on the seemingly immovable desk. At first nothing happens, but as you bear down even more, muscles straining, you feel it begin to give. I’ve got it! you think exultantly. The panel sinks down into the desk on its hinge, which causes you to overbalance. Because of the additional pressure on your extended leg which comes as a result, the panel sinks even farther, enough so that a chilling click, more felt than heard, issues forth.

You do your best to scramble back, but in doing so your foot rises for a split second off the wood of the panel. It’s enough. The panel springs open, momentarily catching your leg and lifting you into the air upside down over the hole. You have only a moment to contemplate your stupidity before the angle becomes steep enough that your foot slips. You give a brief yelp as you plummet into the hole, one that is cut off abruptly as you land on your…
1132121211121222222111.title: Bedtime

11321212111212222221111.content:
You lay for a moment, panting, your stomach a solid ache. Groaning, you get to your feet, hobbling over to some unidentified object and sitting down. You massage your stomach and try to think. The panel is, thankfully, still open, and after a period of sitting and gasping your brain recovers enough to begin to plan a way out of this hole. The tiny amount of diffuse light provided by the cracked door all the way across the room is not enough to determine the contents of the whole, although you can see various shadows of objects. Although you’re very tired and in pain, the fear of getting stuck in that hole motivates you to hobble over to one wall and lift your hands over your head, sending a new flash of pain through your body. To your frustration, you can’t reach the edge, even standing on your toes. You start feeling around, almost completely blind, looking for something to boost yourself with. You first run into a bundle of cable, as thick as a telephone wire, as large as you are but which gives way when you try to stand on it, forcing you to extricate yourself. Next you try the cube like object in the middle, which is bigger than you, but you can’t move it, it seems to be attached to the bottom of the space. You are looking around for something else to try when you notice a sudden silence. Melanie’s loud but even breathing, which had filled the entire room, has stopped. You hear the creak of bedsprings and the sound of cloth rustling. You guess that Melanie is getting up for the same reason you did. You start yelling at the top of your lungs:

“Melanie! Melanie, in here! Melanie.” Your voice comes out raspy and barely audible. You clear it, but by the time you do you hear heavy steps padding out of the room. You wait impatiently for her to return, clearing your throat so you can speak, or rather yell, normally. After what seems like ages, although in reality it’s only a few minutes, you hear her steps once more.

“MELANIE!” You roar at the very top of your lungs when you judge she’s right in front of her desk. A pause, and then you hear an unintelligible mumbling. You hear her move off, and you are preparing to yell up the receptacle again when you finally hear something distinct:

“John? Where are you?”

“DOWN HERE!” You bellow. You are momentarily blinded as even the faint light produced when Melanie turns her desk lamp on, which is blocked from your line of sight, is enough to cause pain. From the sound of her gasp, you’re fairly sure the same thing is true with her. You blink and dimly make out the shape of Melanie’s paw reaching down into the receptacle. She feels around clumsily, movements uncoordinated. You are a bit wary of Melanie's hand as it feels around blindly on the bottom of the receptacle, but, as Melanie knows, you can't really avoid it. The rubbery flesh of her pad envelops you as she feels your body, and she wraps her claws around you roughly.
She lifts you out of the receptacle and looks at you blearily. You blanch inside, taking in her looks. Her face, usually so full of good humor, is practically expressionless. Her fur and whiskers are entirely disheveled, and her eyes are dead. It's like looking at a zombie.

"John..." her voice is monotone, her words slow, as if she is having a hard time thinking of words, "What were you doing in there?"

"Uh, I was.." you stammer, rubbing your hand behind your head sheepishly.

"Wait... how did you even get in there? It was closed I thought..." her voice trails off as she struggles to remember. She looks at the open lid for a second before slowly closing it.

"It was closed, I was just... experimenting." Your face turns red. She just looks at you:

"Experimenting. I see." Her voice is flat. You can't think of anything to say, but you feel like more explanation is required. However, when you open your mouth to talk she shakes a claw at you warningly: "Don't talk. We'll have a long conversation about this in the morning, but for now..." She shifts her grip on you so that your body is encircled and your limbs pinned. She moves to her nightstand. You try to see what she's doing, but she responds to your squirming around to see by tightening her grip. It becomes all too clear, however, when a moment later she holds your sleeping bag under you, spreading its opening with two claws. You struggle valiantly, but she has you trapped in her grip:

"STAY..." She lines you up with the opening while giving a loud whisper: "...PUT!!!" She stuffs you into the sleeping bag, pushing you down into the dark, fluffy space and holding you down with a claw on your head. She removes the claw, but only so that she can zip the bag closed over your head! Even as your heart races, you can't help but admire her dexterity. That zipper must be like the head of a pin to her! you think. She dangles the bag for a few moments, your skin crawling at the realization that only a few inches of cheap cloth protect you from a drop of over 40 feet.

Melanie shakes the sleeping bag a few times to make sure her point got across, than puts it down, none-to-gently (although she didn't slam it, that could kill you) back on the nightstand. You lay in the bag for a moment, trying to breath in the close atmosphere inside the bag and having a hard time doing so. You hear the bedsprings give a loud CREAK and the rushing of air as Melanie throws herself onto her bed, muttering imprecations:

"Idiot mousy behavior...so tired...idiot, could've gotten killed." You wince at the last one, knowing she has the full moral advantage. After a while, the muttering stops and regular breathing resumes. You carefully work open the zipper from the inside, not daring to make even the slightest noise for fear of waking Melanie. You manage it eventually, however, and you carefully adjust yourself so you're comfortable. You're quite tired, and the feeling of the pillow and sleeping bag is just...so...soft...


BANG!!BANG!!BANG!!BANG!!
A massive noise fills the air. You scream in wordless panic and try to leap to your feet, but become entangled in your sleeping bag, with the result being that you roll sideways instead.

"AAAH!" You scream as you go plummeting over the edge of the nightstand. You fall for barely a second, however, before you impact on Melanie's outstretched paw. You stare up at the ceiling for a few moments, far up in the sky and painted white, before a rumbling sound makes you turn your head. You look up the orange black ribbon of fur that is Melanie's arm up to her face. She's turned on her side so that her right arm was out to catch you, and now her other paw is covering her mouth, from which loud snickering still succeeds in emerging. It becomes full blown laughter and you stare at her, a dumb expression on your face. The incessant BANGING, unfortunately, continues to sound as you lie on her relatively soft pad. At last she is able to control herself, although amusement still dances in her green eyes. She rolls onto her back, closing her paw around you and keeping her arm straight, so that you are in the stomach-churning position of being held face over her prone body, the long expanse of white blanket illuminated by the morning light streaming in from the window over Melanie's desk. You're still trapped in your sleeping bag, so you're uncomfortably warm from her added body heat as well.

Melanie's mirth finally seems to fade enough to notice the horrible sound coming from her nightstand. She reaches over and shuts it off somehow. Craning your head around, you see her fiddling with a thin wooden structure rising from her nightstand. That wasn't there last night... You think to yourself. It's a weak thought, however, as most of your attention is being taken up with the effort not to barf. You're being held high up, and the vertiginous feeling this produces is making you nauseous and weak, an effect which is only increased when Melanie's blanket starts rippling as she shrugs it off.

"Melanie." You gasp, "Please put me down." Her gaze focuses on you momentarily, and she smirks:

"Oops." Her voice drips with insincerity, "Sorry about that." She turns you so that you're facing up, and then sets you on the nightstand. You scramble out of your sleeping bag, seeing now that the thin slab of wood in fact was a piece of the nightstand, coming up to your shoulders, which had risen silently on hinges, leaving a square section empty. On the surface of the wood you can see the time clearly displayed in ghostly characters.

Melanie swings herself out of bed so that she's facing the nightstand, paws on the floor. All in all, she cuts a very monolithic figure in the soft morning illumination, white tee shirt rising high into the air above you. You can look out straight into her stomach across her legs. Her tail swishes in the air behind her as she regards you, and it settles across her upper legs, orange on blue, as she starts to speak.


"I thought that you needed some perspective." She says, clearly referring to trapping you 25 feet in the air over her body. "So that perhaps next time you get it into your head to 'experiment', you realize how dangerous it can be when you're your size in a place that's..." she places a paw on her chest "...my size." You can't meet her eyes, so you instead stare fixedly at her tail, cursing your sleep-addled self. The silence stretches for a moment before Melanie breaks it with a cough.

You look at your giant feline friend again; having grown more used to her facial expressions; you can tell she's embarrassed. Grinning wryly, she says:

"Well, that's my moralizing speech of the morning. I'm really bad at them, so please stop getting yourself into trouble."

"I will." You promise, "Sorry about last night. You looked really..." You search for an adjective.

"Zombieish?"

"Yeah." Your acknowledgement is instinctive, and she laughs at the mortification on your face:

"It's okay. There's another reason not to repeat your escapade last night: I'm not at my best when suddenly awakened."

"You were already awake." You point out, "ouch." She flicks your arm as you point this out, but she smiles to take away the sting:

"True, but off topic." You rub your arm, and then remember her clock, clearly an alarm set by her:

"And this?" You wave your hand vaguely at the wood. She grins at you unabashed:

"No, I planned that last night. You were so funny when it went off, like a startled mouse."

"You're still on that I see."

"Yep." She nods happily, "You're still in those awesome red PJs, so the connection is still there in my mind." She taps her forehead with one claw.

"Yep." You say, nodding agreeably and circling your own head with your finger. She makes a face when she realizes what you're doing, and stops you with the simple expedient of grabbing you again. She sets you down on her desk, where the panel is still open from last night. She nudges you towards it, and you go reluctantly, dragging your feet. You're not really all that eager to get close to it again. Instead of making you go back down the hole, however, she points something out instead:

"I guess you didn't realize this last night, but you probably could’ve gotten out without my help." She informs you. You look at her incredulously:

"How? By using my newly discovered power of teleportation?" She shakes her head, fighting down a smile:

"No, by doing this." She puts you on the very edge of the receptacle, indicating that you should watch. You take a small, surreptitious step backwards as she reaches in and pushes down on the wooden cube in the middle of the space. To your surprise, it depresses down significantly, and the bottom of the space starts rising, whispering up the wood until it's at the level of the desk. You look at it in astonishment, Jaw literally hanging open.

"It's like an elevator!"

"Only made of wood and a lot smaller. Anyway, press once to go up, again to go down. Careful not to get caught on the rebound as you obviously did last night. Try it out." You comply, moving forward and repeating your actions from last night. This time you spring back in time, and the wooden cube rises without hitting you. The square quickly descends back into the receptacle. You marvel at the construction; it's an incredibly smooth ride, even for someone your scale. When it settles back down on the bottom, Melanie's paw appears above the opening, blocking out the light:

"Look out below!" She calls. You scramble out of the way as something falls from her paw into the receptacle. It turns out to be your bag. "Changing time." She tells you brightly, her face appearing above the opening. Before she can close the panel, however, you call out:

"Melanie, do you have to close that panel?" The paw stops, and then comes the inevitable comment:

"Ahhh, is the little mouse afraid of the dark?" She asks in a high pitched voice.

"No," you shoot back, "it's just hard to change with no light." Taking her silence for thought, you continue, "Besides, your privacy is assured even without closing the panel. I can't possibly see you down here." After a lengthy pause, the paw retreats. You're rooting through your bag when she brings you up short:

"Alright, but I know you can use the lift function now. If I hear it moving, you'll be in for it." Her warning is somewhat superfluous in your opinion, and you go on changing. At about the same time as you finish, she calls:

"Okay, you can come up now." Depressing the extended cube is harder than when it was flat, but you manage it by using both palms flat on the wood and bearing down with all your strength and weight. When you reach the top, you see Melanie dressed in jeans and a jacket over another tee-shirt. She examines you and says:

"Ah, I liked the PJ's better."

"I kind of got that." You tell her dryly. You grab your stuff, quite an armful, and she grabs you and heads into the bathroom. You both quickly brush your teeth. Finishing before Melanie once more, you examine yourself in the mirror. You’re tall enough to be visible from the waste up, and while you look slightly rumpled everywhere, your hair is the real problem. You have a serious case of bed head, hair sticking out in all directions. You try vainly to smooth it with a brush, but it’s stubborn. You fail to notice Melanie finishing her brushing and leaning down closer to you, so you are taken completely off guard when she says:

“Here, I’ll help you with that.” It’s over almost before it begins, hand shooting out to steady you and her mouth, which is now positioned directly over your head, opening. Her tongue quickly envelops your head, smearing your face with saliva while quickly moistening and flattening your hair. You sputter as she withdraws:

“Melanie!” You yell, coughing from saliva in your mouth. Her only response is to stick her tongue out at you. Ah man, now I smell like mint, you think to yourself. You pause, and admit grudgingly, it does look kind of cool this slick. You give her a dirty look as she proffers her palm, however, to show you won’t take this kind of thing lying down. Melanie then heads downstairs, shouldering her massive backpack as if it is nothing (to her, it is).

While you're on the stairs, you venture a comment:

"You seem to have a lot of panels and hidden stuff in your room..." Melanie lets the searching comment hang for a moment before giving a reply:

"Really? Well I guess we have more than most people, but I don't really think that it's abnormal..." This starts a discussion that lasts for quite a while, as you bounce around in her paw as she goes down the stairs, get tossed into the air (again) when Melanie gives her mother a cat equivalent of a peck on the cheek, and then get seated at the kitchen table. While Melanie's mother hovers in the background, giving Melanie eggs and sausage which she then redistributes via claw to you, and cleaning her own dishes, looking every inch the perfect housewife in her apron, you and Melanie continue to discuss it.

Apparently, that type of sliding and hidden technology, which borders on the fantastic for you, is quite commonplace with Anthros, although its popularity waxes and wanes. Melanie has liked it from childhood and gotten as much of her room as possible done up using that kind of thing. You ask her why, and she tells you simply: "I like the sound." You tell her that that type of technology is barely seen with humans, and it's the province of the rich in any case. "That's too bad." Replies Melanie, staring down at you as you clean your plate. The eggs and sausage were very good, and even with Melanie's generous (or rather, gluttonous) slicing you were hungry for more. You look up from this to see Melanie musing:

"Hmm." Her face is speculative, "You know, I've always wanted my room to be entirely sliding. Your guys' stuff is small enough; it might actually be possible for you..." Her daydream is interrupted by Melanie's father smacking her on the head lightly with a newspaper. You both jump. Neither of you had noticed him coming, despite Melanie's acute hearing and your small size.

"Melanie, please pay more attention to your guest." He tells her firmly, she glances at you. Seeing your very mixed feelings about her fantasy written on her face, she shrugs and smiles sheepishly. She looks at the last remaining sausage on the plate, a big link thicker than your arm and as long as your leg. She spears it with one claw, tosses it in the air above her upturned, yawning mouth. She gulps it down, making an audible, sound. This earns her a chuckle from you, but a reproachful look from her mother, although her father looks quietly amused. She stands:

"Well, I think its time to go." She tells you. She picks you up, and for once the experience is somewhat unpleasant. She had cutlery, but still opted to slice the sausage and eggs with her claws, which were now incredibly greasy, enough to make you gag. She doesn't notice, because she's at the time announcing to her parents:

"Well, we're off to school on....
11321212111212222221111.title: Breakfast with the Prustens

113212121112122222211111.content:
“Well, we’re off to school on my bike.” Melanie shoulders her backpack as her parents bid her farewell. You barely have time for a quick “Thank you for having me, Mrs. Prusten, Mr. Prusten” before she’s out the door and into the hall, with you clinging to her greasy claws. Melanie comes to an abrupt halt, however, when her father calls:

“Melanie, come back here.” Melanie, caught in the act of going out the front door, jerks to a halt (nearly sending you flying out of her paw). She turns slowly and returns, dragging her feet. She looks apprehensive, although it’s hard to tell, as you’re concentrating on not throwing up. Never before had the height seemed so nauseous. You point to Melanie’s claws, which are bathing you in the smell of rapidly-turning-stale grease, as the culprits. Your head is even starting to throb again, despite the fact that it hadn’t been bothering you all of yesterday. Melanie’s father appeared in the archway into the kitchen. Melanie’s dad is standing in the archway to the kitchen. He gives her a mildly reproving glance, than focuses his attention on you. Melanie lifts you higher, without being prompted, to the level of her face. Even so, you’re still only at shoulder level on the imposing figure in front of you. You’re slightly shaky, and still quite nauseous, but mustering an effort you stand straight. He proffers a claw, and you shake it formally, being careful of the sharp tip. His return shake is meant to be gently, but it’s still enough to nearly lift you off your feet. He clears his throat:

“Well John, it was nice to meet you, the first human in an anthro school. Please feel free to come over again any time you’d like.”

“Thank you.” You echo his grave tone, conscious of his and Melanie’s eyes on you. Mr. Prusten stares at you gravely for a moment, than a smile quirks across his face, making his whiskers twitch. Leaning forward, with one paw covering the side of his mouth and his face filling your vision, he faux whispers:

“And try to keep her,” He jerks a thumb in Melanie’s direction, “out of trouble.” The graveness in his voice is gone, replaced by humor. You reply solemnly:

“I’ll do my best, sir.” He looks at his daughter dubiously:

“Let’s just hope your best is enough.” Melanie breaks in:

“DAD!” Her voice rises to a high pitch, and you’re sure that under her fur she’s blushing. She whirls to go out the door (forcing you to cling to her stench-ridden claws), but is brought up short by her dad:

“Hey, don’t I get a hug?” Melanie pauses, and you see a strange expression cross her face. She carefully sets you down on a conveniently-placed table. She then whirls and hugs her dad fiercely. You wait for a few moments, and you notice him saying something into her ear. You don’t catch it however, and they break apart. The next few moments are a blur of motion that you can only reconstruct after she finishes. As far as you can tell, Melanie had given her dad a peck on the cheek, turned, and ran out the door, grabbing you in passing. You have a vague impression of being slammed into her oncoming pad, and as you come to your senses you find yourself face down on her pad. You find you’re nose buried in a coat of grease, and your nausea, which had been fading, returns full force, with the result that you find yourself unable to stand for several moments, When you recover enough to move, you see that Melanie is preoccupied, the paw holding you held safely off to one side as she deftly wrestles with her bike.

The bike itself is blue, and looks a lot like a human bike, except that the seat is oddly shaped, much narrower with a high area in the back, and the coverings on the handlebars are made of some fuzzy material instead of rubber. What really catches your eye, though is the basket attached in front of the handlebars. It is a large whicker basket, of a type which hadn’t existed in human lands for over thirty years. From the glare that she shoots you after she sees the object of your weak snickering, its clear that the same is true about anthro styles as well:

It’s a perfectly nice basket.” She tells you defensively. You just laugh, and she looks frustrated, “Fine, be that way”

“Oh, a sore spot.” You croak. She looks annoyed for a moment, but then she notices your debilitated state. She pauses in her struggling with the bike, which is caught on a bush, looking concerned. She cups her hands to better examine you, but this simply doubles the concentration of stale grease sent in the air, eliciting a groan from you. She begins to look alarmed:

“John? What’s wrong?”

“Melanie I…” you pause as she brings you closer to your face, your stomach reacting to being suddenly jerked ten feet farther into the air, “I feel sick.”

“Sick? Is it your head? Do you need to see a doctor?” She sounds like she’s close to panicking, her stream of babble coming at a fast rate, “An anthro doctor? I don’t know any human doctors… A small animal doctor?” Stung a bit by even her unthinking reference to a vet, you muster the strength to hold up your hand, forestalling her:

“Melanie, just put me down somewhere.” She complies immediately and gently, carefully moving to her bike, which is upright, if still entangled, and placing you in the basket. You sit for a moment, eyes closed, breathing heavily. After a little while, your stomach decides to remove itself from your throat and return to its normal position, and you open your eyes. You observe dispassionately the uniform, slightly rolling appearance of the area around you, the brown floor abruptly ending in the equally brown wall, undulating its way up on all four sides, shading the entirety of the bottom of the basket. You slowly become aware of a large shadow blocking out the moderate amount of light entering the basket. You wave at it, and Melanie nods, worry still written plain on her face, which fills about half of the visible sky:

“You okay?” You consider the question for a moment, mind still operating a bit slowly:

“Yeah, I’m fine.” Melanie nods, relieved. After a moment’s pause, she asks:

“What brought that on?”

“Your paws.”

“My paws?” She asks, baffled, bringing one of the offending appendages into view and looking at it front and back. You wave at her to get her attention again:

“Yeah, they’re covered with grease. It stinks to high heaven, which was bad enough, but it seemed to interact with my semi-concussion from the door yesterday. It made me feel really, really sick. You…” You pause to grunt as you heave yourself into a more upright position against the basket wall, “You might want to give a bit more consideration about what is on your paws when you’re going to be picking someone up.” You deliver the last remark in gently reproving tone, both because you don’t want to hurt her feelings and because you can’t seem to get up the energy to yell at her at the moment.

Melanie had listened to you with guilt playing across her face, actually wincing (which, interestingly enough, made the field of fur covering her cheeks and chin stand slightly on end) when you told her about your head. Now she looks at her paws as if she’d like nothing better than to chew them off. Slowly.

“I’m really sorry.” She tells you, voice close to cracking. Unable to think of anything to do help you, she instead begins to lick her paw, aggressively and with great force, as if she was using the act of cleaning her paw as a substitute for penitent self-flagellation. An idle thought crosses your mind, like a drunk staggering across a sidewalk, as she performs the strange feline drying process with equal vigor: That tongue could probably take off my skin if she licked me that hard. When she finishes, a guilty pause ensues as she searches for something to say. Then:

“John, why didn’t you say anything sooner, like when I picked you up? You might’ve gotten really sick…” She trails off. Drained you may be, but for this statement you muster the effort to lift your head and stare straight at her incredulously:

“Your parents would have heard.” You tell her simply, the statement, in your mind at least, sufficient to explain all. When this is greeted with a look of blank incomprehension, however, you explain it to her:

“If your parents had heard, you could’ve gotten into trouble. Big trouble, considering all the craziness about the whole ‘first human injured thing.’ Definitely not worth it.”

“But you must have been in pain…” You interrupt her weak objections:

“Friends don’t get friends in trouble with their parents, or with their teachers, or the principal. Period. That’s what friendship is.” She is silent for a moment, and you close your eyes in the face of another nausea attack. Over and above the waves of cramps affecting your stomach, you hear Melanie say quietly:

“Thank you.” A warm, living weight covers you, fur brushing softly across the skin of your face and arms. You blissfully allow the warmth of Melanie’s body heat to wash over you, too proud to refuse, especially as it soothes your muscle cramps. You continue like this for an indefinite, although probably short, period of time, but eventually a pressing concern pries its way into your mind. Opening your eyes, your field of vision is blocked by a fateful of soft fur. It tickles your eyes, and you reach forward, pushing her hand away. She quickly withdraws, and you look up at her, her face farther away and in a different position. She’s got her chin resting on an arm draped across the right (her left) handlebar. She puts her other arm on top and leans on them both, continuing to look at you with an expression which, now that you’re recovered, makes you uncomfortable. You push the thought you had out into the open:

“Melanie, don’t we need to get to school?” You ask her. She nods reluctantly. “Well then, let’s go.” Her expression changes to one of extreme reluctance, and she begins stammering a few worried exclamations about your health. You interrupt her:

“Melanie, I’m fine.” You hate being treated like a handicapped invalid by your giant4 friend, to whom you must already appear considerably handicapped, for obvious reasons. “We’re going to be late, so let’s get moving!” You say the last with what you hope is a commanding snap to your voice, which is sufficient to get her moving. She disappears from view.

Your claim that you are fine is slightly untrue, as evinced by the stab of nausea as your world is rocked when Melanie, with a grunt of effort, finally heaves the bike out of the entangling bushes. Your world goes green for a moment, and it takes a while for you to recover. Thankfully, however, Melanie was to busy to notice the first reaction, so you safely sit in the basket recovering while she pedals on her way to school. The sides of the basket are by no means impermeable, and the constant stream of fresh, cool air blowing across your body is quite helpful in your recuperation. When you recover once more, for good this time, you think, you work your way to your feet and cling to the tightly intertwined straw, trying to get used to the odd motion of being a passenger on a massive bicycle.

The motion is smooth at the times when you think Melanie is coasting or pedaling straight, with a slight, even roll. The yaw produced from Melanie’s minute adjustments to the handlebars, which of course the basket is attached to. Things get bumpy, however, whenever Melanie reaches an uneven section of ground, and things are really weird when Melanie hits a turn. She’s apparently fond of leaning into her turns, which means that you are unwillingly sent stumbling across the basket to slam into the other side as the bike becomes more and more horizontal.

When the bike levels out again, you feel up to trying to engage in conversation with Melanie. You let go of the wall, stagger a moment as you regain your equilibrium, and move to the side directly across from Melanie. Looking up, you see Melanie’s head floating in the air above the rim of the basket. Her fur, ear and whiskers are all blown back a little, making her look a trifle odd. She’s focusing on the road ahead of her, looking far past and above the basket, but you had noticed before every so often she looks down into the basket. When she next does this, you wave at her. She smiles at you, then straightens her head again while saying:

“Hey there john. I take it you’re out of your coma?” She asks lightly. You nod. She declines her head to look at you very rarely while she speaks, but since her eyes flick down towards you intermittently, or not, when you’re talking you can tell when she’s listening.

“Yup, I’m all better.” You have to yell, but not with extreme force do to her sharp ears, in order to be heard. For Melanie’s part, her words are oddly muffled, but she’s also understandable.And she doesn’t even have to yell, you think to yourself a bit sourly.

“That’s good. Hang on a second…” As she says these words the basket and bicycle start to wobble significantly. Well, significantly to Melanie, which means you’re sent teetering to and froe across the basket, crashing into the walls. You momentarily stumble into Melanie’s paw, which was in the basket for some reason. She rights you before she withdraws, and when the world stops spinning you call up to her:

“MELANIE!” You yell up at her in exasperation. She just grins and nods into the basket. Looking around, you see your bag and backpack, battered and a trifle deformed but otherwise fine. You feel a little heat on your cheeks: “Oh. Thank you.”

“No Problem.” She replies graciously, not looking down, with only a hint of a smile on her face. You recover your bags and wedge them safely in a corner, and as you do so a niggling little detail that had been bothering you in the back of your mind suddenly resolves itself into clarity:

“Melanie,” You call up to your giant, bare-headed friend, “where’s your helmet.”

“I don’t have one.” She replies casually,

“Well, shouldn’t you be wearing one? Aren’t there helmet laws?” You ask her.

“No, we Anthros don’t have helmet laws.” She tells you, taking the bike into a slow curve. You adjust your balance and continue:

“You should still be wearing one. It’s safer. If you crashed, you might crack your skull.” She lets the comment hang for a moment before replying:

“Well, I find them uncomfortable, especially on my ears. I’m a good rider. Besides,” She declines her entire head to look at you for a second, “You worry too much. It would take a lot more force to break my head than yours, don’t you think?” She lifts her head again. The last part was said in a tone that sounds very much like amused, gentle condescension, which seriously annoys you. Before you can argue further, however, or even get in a comeback centered on stubbornness, Melanie announces brightly:

“Here we are.” A massive sliding sound fills the air as Melanie applies her back, and you have to hang onto the wall tightly to resist the force of deceleration. The bike bumps to a stop, you feel Melanie engage the kickstand and get off the bike, leaving the floor at a moderate angle, and as you gather up your stuff you catch a glimpse of Melanie wrapping a high-voltage-line think lock around her wheel and a bike rack through the weaving. You shoulder your backpack and grab your bag, then carefully step onto Melanie’s proffered paw. As she heads up the steps to the school, which are scarcely populated with a variety Anthros, she tells you:

“Well, my-sorry our- first class is…”
113212121112122222211111.title: Bike Ride

choices: ..."Hey John, why does Paper beat Rock?"
..."Hey John, you want to raise the stakes?"
1132121211121222222111111.content:
"Our first class is geometry." Melanie repeats, as if she's not totally sure that she's right. She collects herself, "Yeah. Definitely geometry." She nods and reaches for the handle to the door- with the paw you're in! As she turns her paw, with the pad becoming more and more vertical, you look around wildly, close to panicking. Thankfully, you think fast for once (‘cause Melanie clearly is not). You run up the pad before it becomes too vertical and you fall off. You scramble onto the side of her paw, pulling hard on the thing fur covering the webbing between her foreclaw and thumb. You're just in time to; even as you swing your feet up so you're lying with you're body stretched out along her forefinger and she flinches from your abuse of her fur, nearly causing you to fall, the massive metal bar of the door handle thunks into her waiting pad. It's really cold; your right arm gets goosebumps from being in such close proximity. You're just glad it, and you, weren't crushed.

Melanie pulls open the door by reflex and walks through, while you hang on with all your might. She doesn't seem to notice at first, but after she brings her arm around in front of her again she absentmindedly lays her left paw on her right to rub away the pain. The result is that she grinds you into this very bony part of her paw, making it almost impossible to breathe, while at the same time she crumples the cloth of your clothes and stretches your skin and hair. The combination of the pressure on the back of your body and the hard surface beneath you is very uncomfortable, almost painful. With a growl you release your right arm's grip on her thumb, lean over into a precarious position and punch up into her pad with all your strength between one rub and the next.

"Ouch." She says. That hurt? You think to yourself in disbelief, It was like punching a stack of mattresses!. She stops, removes her paw and lifts you towards her face, leaning against a wall. The sight that is revealed, you clinging grimly to the side of her paw, legs wrapped around her foreclaw and arms wrapped around her thumb, trying to keep from falling from one side or another (your body is wider than the side of her paw) is enough to make her blink. Once. Twice. Then:

"Oops." She can't seem to think of anything else to say.

"Yeah, ‘oops'." You confirm. She's got a look of blank stupidity on her face, so you prod her along; "If you wouldn't mind..." you gesture towards yourself with your left hand and nearly fall off for your trouble. Her face fills with comprehension, and consternation, and she hastens to help you, doing so by closing her fist. You first hastily pull down your shirt, which her rubbing had pushed halfway up your back, and then you gratefully heave yourself up and sit cross-legged on the circle formed by her thumb and foreclaw.

Melanie again is at a loss for words, and clearly to give her some time to think she suggests that she continue on to your first class. You agree, and she pushes off the wall, heading down the hallway. She keeps the paw you're on close to her chest. The experience is vastly different from yesterday's; instead of scrambling around under a vast number of unaware Anthros, in constant danger of getting stomped and completely ignorant of what it is that's passing above you, you instead sit serenely forty feet above the floor as Melanie does the walking for you. It is, you reflect, a much more pleasant experience. The hallways are strangely depopulated, however; you can see only a few Anthros hanging around outside of doors. All of them look over casually at Melanie, than start staring at you perched on her paw. One, a lizard Anthro of some kind, even takes a few steps forward, yellow eyes fixed on you, but then he notices Melanie and retreats for some reason. You look up questioningly at Melanie, who shakes her head:

"Don't know him." She finally reaches your first class, which is deserted, and sits down in a desk near the window, in the middle row. Melanie sets her paw down and slowly opens her fist. You uncurl your legs and jump down to the floor through the opening, so that your body up to your lower chest is momentarily encircled in a column of her claws and paw, preventing you from moving off. She quickly releases you, however, and you take a look around as she gets settled. The desk itself is bland, a plain of wood with a dull grey grain running across it in stripes, ending abruptly in empty air on three sides, empty for twenty feet before, inevitably, it runs into another desk. All the way at the front of the classroom, half a football field away, you can see a desk, and the blank blackboard, stretching across the length of the room. All around the room are hung maps of all sorts, as well as posters showing renderings of various land features. Even the smallest of these is the same height as your house, and the largest could be posted to the front of a six-story block sided office building.

Along with a number of globes, which stood on various flat surfaces, and some full and half cabinets, this is what makes up this room, and probably every room in the school, although undoubtedly there are variations based on subject matter. The element needed to complete this picture, the 25 or so Anthros (and, as of yesterday, 1 human) that are supposed to populate the room, is strangely missing. Except, suspiciously, for you and Melanie. You turn around and cross your arms over your chest. Melanie has just finished sitting down, a procedure which seemed to require an inordinate number of loud bangs, thumps and squeals, which you had determined not to react to. You accomplished this, although the scrape of her scraping her chair out nearly made you jump out of your skin. She's watching me. If I jump, it might give her ideas. When you finally turn around, you see that she is indeed watching you. The desk edge comes up to the bottom of her rib cage, and you follow the expanse of her shirt all the way up to her face. It takes longer than usual, as she's sitting straight backed, as if rigidly at attention, with her two paws laid nervously flat on the wood. Your lips quirk in amusement:

"You afraid I'm going to arrest you?" You ask her archly. She blinks, looks down, and relaxes somewhat, leaning forward a bit and resting her upper arms on the table, paws turned sideways. You back up to try a better angle on Melanie's face, but even if you backed off the edge of the desk you still would have to crane your head significantly in order to hold conversation. She clears her throat nervously and begins to speak:

"Uhh, John, about earlier..." You watch her squirm expressionlessly. Inside, you want to let her off, but you know that she needs to apologize, for a multitude of very good reasons. She continues, looking at anything but you (which is fairly easy for her to do), "Well, earlier and the time before." She's very flustered, but at last she manages to get it out, "I'm so sorry. I might've killed you..." She looks ready to go on, but you forestall her with a hand:

"Apology accepted Melanie." You smile at her and say: "Just remember to watch out for who's in your paw next time, Okay?"

"Absolutely." She nods vigorously, and begins to babble about how she would never, ever do it again. Again, you cut her off gently:

"I imagine it must be really weird, having me around and having to watch your step all the time," You say the last a bit wryly and she giggles briefly, before she recalls herself and simply nods, "and I know it's weird being around a big hulk like you, trying not to get squashed. We've both screwed up, and we'll screw up again. The key is just to learn from our mistakes and not repeat them. Okay?" You're not as calm and unoffended as your words suggest, but you'd realized as Melanie walked that it would be better to act, and try to be, so. The calculating part of your mind didn't want to piss Melanie off, for one thing, but more importantly the rest of your mind didn't want to savage her feelings. Besides, you still feel a bit guilty about last night. Melanie looks moved by your words, and after contemplating them for a while, she says:

"Wow John, you can be pretty wise..." She pauses for a moment to let the seriousness of her words sink in, but then she lightens her tone, "...that is, when you're not too busy being dumb." She grins merrily and tweaks you with a claw. "Who do you think you're calling a hulk, tiny?" You pretend to consider for a moment, than grin:

"You." You inform her, at which point she promptly, and mercilessly, noogies you with the knuckle of one claw rubbing into the top of your head. You attempt to protect yourself with your hands, and surprisingly enough you succeed, forcing her claw away from your head and extracting yourself from the immediate reach of her paw. This, however, is due to the fact that you were only fighting her finger muscle. If she'd been using her arm or even her wrist muscle she could've easily overpowered you, but she would also have crushed you instantaneously. She doesn't pursue and both your laughter subsides. After rearranging your much-abused hair, you ask the real burning question in your mind:

"Melanie, where's everyone else?"

"Well, we're just a tad early." She replies. You look at her suspiciously:

"Just how early is a tad?" You ask.

"Oh, about forty minutes."

"Forty MINUTES!" You exclaim, "You told me we were going to be LATE!"

"I never said that," she points out smugly, "you did. I just kind of... went along with it." You change tacks:

"Why, exactly, did you feel it was necessary that we get here forty minutes early?" You demand. You're still put out about the way she had tricked you.

"Well, I usually like to get to school early, and today I thought we needed some time to get, you know, situated." She has a very reasonable tone to her voice, but you're still miffed. You acquiesce, however, seeing that this conversation can't go anywhere. To pass the time, as both of you are getting bored rapidly, you propose playing Rock-Paper-Scissors. When you discover that she doesn't know the game, you immediately insist that she learn. She picks it up quickly and you're both soon shouting "Rock Paper Scissors Shoot!" at each other. Well, you're shouting. She just needs to raise her voice slightly to surround you with noise. You win handily for quite a while, as she doesn't seem to realize that she's fallen into a pattern. This makes her quite frustrated, and she accuses you of using your "tiny little hand" to fudge the results. You don't take much offense; as you'd won five of the last seven rounds and you go on to win two more. After this, however, Melanie starts slamming her first down on the desk before shooting, instead of on her paw. It was unnerving enough to have those two walls of flesh slam into each other right above your head, but this shakes the desk. You bare with it for a while, but when a particularly violent smash knocks you over onto your back you relent:

"Hey Melanie," you call up to the large, frustrated feline face hovering above you, "I keep winning because I predict your moves, because..."

"Oh!" She interrupts, comprehension dancing across her face "I know! I keep getting into a pattern."

"Exactly." You affirm. Melanie helps you to your feet with a claw, and you continue, more amiably now that Melanie has started winning more often. In fact, she quickly starts threatening your lead. At one point, after one of your victories, you agree to take a pause. Looking at her paw, out flat in a long paper position and resting close above the table, you have an idea. You walk over to her paw, feeling Melanie's eyes following you. It's about at eye level, a furry platform close to your face. You smile up a Melanie:

"Hey Melanie, why do Scissors beat Paper?" You ask her. She smiles, going along:

"Why John?"

"Because Scissors Cut Paper!" You yell the last gleefully and attack her "paper" with your "scissors", thrusting your hand forward to try and "cut" her paw. Of course, you have no hope of fitting the massive girth of her pad between your fingers, but you manage to enclose a thick swath of fur and skin and squeeze. Melanie laughs at your antics, especially as you start with your left hand, both hands now hanging on to her paw. It could've have been more than a barrel noticeable pinch for her. Eventually your laughter subsides and with a wicked gleam in her eye she proposes another round. "Rock Paper Scissors Shoot!"

"Ah!" you cry, staring in dismay at her paper to your rock, "You've outthought me!" She nods, a satisfied look on her face, than asks...
1132121211121222222111111.title: Rock, Paper, Scissors Shoot!

11321212111212222221111111.content:
“Hey John, why does Paper beat Rock?” You gulp, seeing the trap, but you can’t see any way out of this:

“Why Melanie?” You ask, trying to back away slowly without her noticing. No such luck, and besides there’s no place to go. She holds her open paw up above you, blocking out the light, and says gleefully:

“Because Paper covers Rock.” Her paw comes down, covering you and bearing you to the ground. You hear her laughing and start laughing to, flat on you back covered by her paw. She leaves you in darkness for a while, restrained gently by her paw, but eventually you both stop laughing and she lets you up. By mutual, silent agreement, you stop (you won, but only by a few rounds). You both just lounge, you leaning back against Melanie’s forearm, hands behind your head, and Melanie resting her chin on her other paw, eyes far away. You rest uxoriously for a while against Melanie’s fur {you’re becoming quickly becoming used to using Melanie as a piece of furniture), while Melanie daydreams. Before either of you can get bored, a new distraction arrives: The teacher.

He (at least you think it’s a he; the deep pitch of his voice which you hear later seems to confirm this assumption) is a Zebra Anthro. He walks in when you have your back turned; you don’t even notice until Melanie gives a start and sits up straighter, removing her arm and unceremoniously dumping you on your back. You glare at her, and she nods towards the front of the room. You see the titanic, white black figure putting a briefcase down on his desk. You quickly get to your feet and try to look attentive. You and Melanie struggle to hold your respective attentive positions without cracking up, but it’s difficult: He trips no less than three times and somehow ends up facing a cabinet instead of his desk. Melanie lets loose one giggle, but maintains her composure. The teacher does make it to his desk, and after setting down his briefcase (thankfully without mishap), he glances around the room and spots Melanie. He starts to come over, then, with a bit of squinting, spots you. Now that he’s closer, you think for a moment he’s naked, as undulating white and black stripes go all the way up and down his body. You realize he’s wearing a zebra-colored shirt and pants, nearly indistinguishable from his clothes. Weird you think. He looks down at you, and then Melanie. He clears his throat:

“Ms. Prusten I presume, Mr…” He stops for a moment, befuddled.

“John.” You supply.

“Mr. John.” He nods to himself. “Anyway, I’m Mr. Grekela. I hope you’re accommodated sufficiently for your, uh… condition.” While he had been talking you had moved to the side and turned, so you could see both of them, perfectly positioning you to notice Melanie’s wince at the awkward word choice. Very satisfying you think to yourself. Your own polite “Yes, I’m fine.” is interrupted by Melanie:

“Well, there is a distinct lack of a chair or desk for John.” She says in a chilly voice. You smile inside; the teacher is as impervious to this as he is to running into hard objects, but it’s the thought that counts. You try to again to get in a pleasantry about being fine, but they talk, literally, over you. The circular, uncomfortable conversation which ensues, centering mainly around the fact that neither Melanie nor Mr. Grekela knows where to find any school furniture your size, thankfully comes to a quick end when another student, an Anthro Hawk, walks in and takes a seat somewhere else. Mr. Grekela returns to the front. Without taking her eyes of Mr. Grekela’s retreating back, she asks:

“So John, what is your last name?” She focuses on you.

“Well… That would be telling, wouldn’t it.”

“John!” She cries, her voice hitting an unusually high note. You just laugh. Further outrage on her part is curtailed by the arrival of a whole bunch of students, a mixed group of Anthros. They all take a seat on the other side of the classroom, talking amongst themselves. As more and more students walks in Melanie inspects them one by one as if looking for someone; a friend, you bet. She doesn’t find anyone, however, and finally the last seats near Melanie fill with more giant students as the bell rings. You take an instant dislike to the bell: it somehow manages to be annoyingly high pitched and grindingly deep at the same time, and loud enough to shake some of the glass on the window. You see the entire class give a simultaneous wince at the noise. Mr. Grekela stands to address the class:

“Hello, my name is Mr. Grekela. This is Geography.” As he talks, he paces back and forth in front of the class, all of his earlier clumsiness forgotten, “By the time you have finished this class you will have learned so much more than nations and cities.” He picks a globe up off the desk and holds it in front of him. You can’t make out much detail, “You will have learned map and globe reading, population densities, population distributions geographical features of all kinds, the basics of pre-GPS navigation…” He continues on, pacing back and forth, gesticulating with the globe, and often pointing it towards specific students as if he was trying to drive the point home with the fifteen-foot diameter globe as a hammer. It grows quite difficult to watch: he’s so big it’s like watching a hillside on the move, and as the white and black pictures undulate up and down, up and down, you find it hard to think…

Melanie nudges you:

“John.” She hisses, and then blocks your view with a paw:

“Huh?” You say stupidly. She gives you a sympathetic look and waits for you to regain your wits. When she sees you can think coherently again, she says:

“Zebras definitely should not wear color match clothing.” She informs you. She hides a grin and points. Turning, you see that half the class have dazed expressions on their faces (or beaks, or muzzles), sitting inertly in their chairs. Following the line of her claw, you see that a bird of some kind has its head on its talons. Even as you watch, it slips free and is startled momentarily into wakefulness before its eyes glaze over. You and Melanie laugh, but then the class is suddenly woken up by Mr. Grekela dropping the globe onto the desk with a massive thud:

“Now, to start with the most basic of geographical divisions we shall consider the obvious; that is, the geographical placement of Human and Anthro areas.” The entire class sits up and starts looking interested, with many a speculative glance in your direction. A few from neighboring desks look interested in whispering, but then Mr. Grekela suddenly snaps:
