“All of you, get out paper. Take notes.” The class gives a groan but complies. You move to the front of the desk as Melanie sets a massive sheet of paper, more like a lawn covering really, down on the desk in front of her and sets a pen to it. As noted earlier, you don’t have a desk, so you decide to lie down on your stomach on the desk and set your own, small piece of paper down in front of you. It’s not the ideal position, but sans a desk and chair it’ll have to do.

What you learn is actually quite interesting and far more comprehensible now that Mr. Grekela has, blessedly, stopped moving. With the aid of maps at the front, he explains that most human nations, or enclaves as he often refers to them, are located “behind” the ancestral lands of one or another particular type (species? race?) of Anthro. Furthermore, in the past they were all separated by significant natural boundaries. He refers specifically to one particular place where a river so wide that it stretches to the horizon for both Human and anthro, very deep and having an incredible strong current. However, strangely enough he doesn’t refer to the past boundary of your own nation before your ancestors had pushed beyond it in the last half-century. Weird you think to yourself as he drones on. The mountains are only 70 miles, 7 for an Anthro, from my house, which can’t be more than 220 miles from here.

You’re distracted momentarily by the arrival of a globe, which the class has been passing around. Melanie sets the stand down on the desk with a clunk. The fifteen foot diameter globe looks to you like it belongs in a planetarium rather than in a classroom, especially when Melanie gives it an idle spin and the countries and oceans move at a moderate speed across your vision. You wait for it to slow down a trifle, than reach out with both hands to try and stop it. You manage it, straining you muscles against the movement. When it does, you laboriously push against nations and oceans indiscriminately turning the globe slowly until you get to a satellite’s view of the area in which you live. You can see Felinton, located on the border of Striland and your own country, which is actually a third the size of Striland. Proving Mr. Grekela’s statement, it does indeed border only Striland, being located on a triangular peninsula. Weirdly, however, your nation is colored exactly the same as all the other human lands, a dull white, and there is very little detail besides the borders, not even the capitol city or the name! Considering the intricate detail of all the Anthro nations, enough that it looks like either someone your size or an OCD person with way two much time on there hands made it, the lack is glaring.

Melanie lifts the globe away and you return your attention to the teacher:

“There have been, of course, a few exceptions to this rule,” He continues, pulling out another map, historical, and pointing to thins strips of white surrounded by color, “As you probably know, however, most of them are gone, under… difficult circumstances.” I’ll say you think to yourself. Your teachers in elementary school had given long and grisly lectures on the subject- those were really some of the few times that Anthros ever figured significantly in your earlier education. One of the most recent incidents happened relatively close to here, actually. A few hundred years ago, there was a strip of human land that ran up the length of the coast of Striland to another human nation to he north. A bunch of Anthros, tigers, showed up one day, built a castle (they still had castles back then) and claimed lordship over the entire region. Things didn’t end well for the human population. You’re surprised that he doesn’t mention it, or really any details of any of this negative interaction. He just moves on to continents.

You dutifully take notes for the rest of class, mostly on continents, which you already know (your knowledge is in the context of humans instead of Anthros, however). At last, the bell rings, and the class gives a sigh of relief. Everyone starts reaching down to grab their backpacks and put away their notes, and you stand up to do the same. Just as you’d feared, there’s a massive cramp in your neck from the awkward position and you groan, massaging the back of your neck. Melanie spares a moment to give you a sympathetic glance before zipping up her bag. You put away your stuff and shoulder your backpack, overnight bag in your other hand. The bell rings and the class stands. It’s quite a sight, row after row of giants simultaneously adding another 20 feet to their height, rising into the air effortlessly. It’ll take a while to get used to that sight, you think. To your poorly hidden distress, a group of eager Anthros immediately comes over to congregate around Melanie’s desk. As they surround the desk a variety of “oohs”, “ahhs’ and other exclamations of delight and wonder issue forth far above your head, with the entire, enormous babble threatening to overwhelm your ears. They loom up around you, and when Melanie stands up to try and deal with them the light is almost completely blotted out. This leaves you standing in the middle of a circle of cloth, fur and scales, rising far into the sky.

Despite the fact that this resembles very much a recurring nightmare of yours, especially in the way that it’s very hard to identify the Anthros staring down at you since their faces are cast into shadow, you try to keep your cool. The noise is deafening as they resort to speaking even louder to try and be heard. You can’t here any individual questions or comments, although you can pick up a varying number of tones, mostly curious, a number excited, a minority disapproving. You circle in place slowly, thoroughly disoriented, looking for Melanie as Anthros jostle each other and peer around bodies to get a look at you. You swallow. You want to retreat to Melanie, you can see her trying to get them to calm down, but you know that these are your classmates, and you can’t look like a chicken, or like you need Melanie for everything. You need to get things calm down before the Anthros start getting violent, or before someone wants a “closer look” and snatches you up, and without running to Melanie. For lack of a better idea, you raise your hand and start waving weakly. This produces some reaction, but in the wrong direction: they start hurling even more questions. Finally, somewhat fed up and more than a little nervous of one shadowy monolithic figure in particular, which has been edging closer, you raise your hands to your lips and bellow:

“HEY!! BE QUIET!!” To your complete astonishment, it works. Your voice is audible, if not loud enough to really override their voices, and it cuts through the chatter. They settle down, but now they’re all watching you eagerly, a disconcerting experience when most of the eyes belong to mammalian predators, raptors or reptiles. You must your courage:

“Hello, yes I am a human,” (answering the most common question) “and my name is John. Could you please step back? It’s hard to see you all from down here with everyone standing so close.” With some jostling and a few heated exchanges, the mountain of fur and scales move back, like a tidal wave in reverse. You give a sigh of relief: some of them are leaving, now that their curiosity is satisfied. There’s still plenty left, however. Turning, you see Melanie, looking harassed and out of joint, fur and clothing somewhat askew from close proximity. She looks down at you gratefully:

“Thanks John.” She mouths. You give her a thumbs-up. But now another anthro, a male… Iguana? steps forward towards the table again, looking at you eagerly. When he speaks, however, it’s to Melanie, who’s somewhat distracted by trying to recover her backpack:

“Hey, he’s so cool. Can I hold him?” As you look on with apprehension and a surge of anger at being talked over, Melanie replies…
11321212111212222221111111.title: Geography for Anthros

choices: …“Five foot two.” You both reply simultaneously
…”Little Human Doll Sized!” A cruel voice shouts from the back
113212121112122222211111111.content:
“You’ll have to ask him.” Melanie’s chill, practically arctic tone froze the Iguana boy’s hand, which he had eagerly been thrusting towards you. You breathe a sigh of relief and slowly straighten, having crouched in preparation for taking evasive action. His hand is massive, but to you it looks skeletal, long thin fingers covered in scales tipped by a claw, with very large and bulging joints. The only hint of softness is the webbing between his fingers; all in all, it looks quite unpleasant to be grabbed by. His hand slowly withdraws, to your relief, and he looks at Melanie, and then after a while you, in evident confusion.

“But…” His confused objection comes to a halt in the face of Melanie’s glare. He scratches a loose scale on his neck. When he tries to talk again, Melanie forestalls him with a claw and points downward towards where you’re standing looking up at the giant encounter. It’s fascinating to watch the way his face moves in response to his emotions, it’s obvious that he’s experiencing a great deal of uncomfortable emotion, but his face lies so far out of the realm of your experience that you can’t really tell. Melanie’s own, once unknown face seems comfortably obvious and mammalian by comparison. You and Melanie wait patiently for a few moments, and eventually he seems to get it:

“Oh!,” He exclaims, seemingly astonished, “You mean I should ask the human if I can pick him up!!” Melanie replies seriously:

“Yes, that is the idea.” Her manner is grave, but you can tell that she’s suppressing a grin. He blinks, and looks down at you:

“Can I pick you up, uh…” He looks at Melanie:

“John.” She supplies

“…John.” He finishes, looking at you hopefully. You look him square in the face (not hard, really, considering it fills a large portion of the sky):

“No, you can not pick me up.” You tell him point-blank. His face falls and he starts to turn, looking dejected. You look at Melanie, who’s giving you an ambiguous expression, and raise your voice:

“You may, however,” he stops and looks back at you, suddenly hopeful, “set your hand down on the desk, and I’ll get on.” There’s no mistaking the expression on his face, whatever his species: he looks like a kid who’s been denied a treat who just got it back. Eyes wide, he slowly lowers his hand down to the desk, visibly hesitant and shaking slightly, in marked contrast to his earlier eagerness. You consider his hand, resting flat on the desk in front of you, with no little trepidation, considering this giant’s behavior so far, but realizing that you can’t back now and get any respect from your peers, which you desperately need as they’re all 10X your size, you walks over and step onto his hand. You struggle to maintain your balance as he lifts his shaking hand from his desk, his face filling more and more of your vision as you get higher and higher. Finally you reach the level of his chest, looking up at him looking down at you with wonder in his eyes. You let his breath roll over you for a few moments, he’s practically hyperventilating, It doesn’t smell too bad, but it’s still kind of unpleasant. To distract yourself, you introduce yourself:

“Hello, I’m John.” He just gapes at you. With a long suffering sigh, Melanie whispers theatrically:

“Tell him Your name.” He blinks and then gets it:

“Oh, uh, my name’s… Brad.”

“Nice to meet you Brad.” You tell him politely. He smiles and appears less nervous:

“Nice to meet you to. Sorry If I was a bit grabby earlier.”

“Just a misunderstanding. Still, you guys need to ask. Only Melanie gets to grab me, and then only when I’m about to get squashed or something.” Brad nods, eyes wide. He can’t seem to stop staring at you. Melanie clears her throat meaningfully:

“We’ve got to go; we’re going to be late.” She holds out her paw expectantly. Brad nods, dazed and hands you over. The audience in the background gives a disappointed sigh as you step onto Melanie’s (much softer) pad and she walks out the door. You walk along, well she walks and you just maintain your balance, through the crowded hallways. Melanie’s in a hurry, moving with as much speed as possible through the tight-packed crowd, which is quite a sight, a colorful, towering mass. After you get through the main mass, mostly unnoticed because the relative sizes of you and the dense pack, Melanie finds a secluded niche near your next class and looks down at you with an ambiguous expression. At last, she remarks:

“You know, I can think of a few occasions when I’ve grabbed you even though you weren’t going to get squashed.” Her tone is speculative. You grin wryly and call up over the noise of the hallway:

“Just trying to lay down some ground rules. It’s too late for you; you’ve got too many bad habits. The rest of them don’t need to know that, however.”

“So you don’t mind me...” You see a gleam in her eye and move to correct it:

“Oh no, you’re not going to get me that easily. Let’s just say that I deal with it when it’s not too unreasonable.” Melanie chuckles, clearly remembering a few ‘unreasonable’ moments, and forges a path across the hall into your next class.

It’s Math this time, taught by a giant, bespectacled Ostrich anthro. Her body looks normal, but her neck is highly elongated, jutting straight up into the air like a bizarre flagpole. You and Melanie introduce yourselves to Ms. Lizkit politely, with her bending her prodigious neck down nearly double in order to get a closer look at you, adjusting her spectacles to keep them on her face. Aside from the neck, the teacher looks pretty humanoid, differing only in the feathers which cover every exposed area of skin.

You and Melanie sit down in the front row, with you lacking a desk once more. `You get less attention this time as the class files in, mainly because Melanie's sitting in front. You're not sure if this is on purpose, but you are grateful. The few of your classmates who do spot you have little time to do anything but gape from afar, as Lizkit begins the class the instant the bell rings (or rather, the instant everyone recovers from said ringing). Mrs. Lizkit begins stalking slowly back and forth in front of the still-dazed class. Her neck is outstretched to its full length. This is so long, in fact, that, from your position on Melanie's desk, it is as if you're looking up at Melanie's or one of your classmates' heads from their feet. It is quite intimidating, even, you sense, to your classmates, for whom it obviously seems far less towering.

After surveying the class for a moment, Mrs. Lizkit begins speaking in a very loud, very high pitched voice:

"Hello class, my name is Mrs. Lizkit, and this is 7th grade Math. If you are not supposed to be here, speak up now. Anyone? Good. Now, I assume you all have your arithmetic?" The class gives a dazed, collective blink and shakes itself. Before the realization that a response is required sets in, the teacher storms: "You can all add, subtract, multiply, divide and the like?" You are first to give your assent, your pitifully feeble shout of assent readily overridden by some groans to the same affect from your classmates, including a tired rumble from Melanie. The teacher's speaking rhythm, as well as her high pitch, makes it very hard to tell when she's asking a question, a fact that you and your classmates will curse later on. She gets angry with students who don't answer promptly, giving them the bite of a harsh tongue, or even very occasionally detentions when she is in a particularly foul mood. At least her voice doesn’t have a soporific effect, like the droning of your previous teacher (although that was somewhat negated for you because his voice was low enough to actually shake your bones), as the keenest of attention is necessary to keep up with the furious pace of the notes Mrs. Lizkit begins drawing on the blackboard.

"Now," She begins, the high pitched whine of her voice easily audible when she's facing the blackboard, "our first subject is geometry, and I'll start by teaching you all about the geometry most important to our daily lives, dimension." She draws a point, a line, a square and a 'cube' on the board. "We all live in a four dimensional world, which is defined, as the name implies, by four dimensions, namely length width, depth and time." As she lists the first three, she traces the chalk along the lines of the cube, going in a different direction with each dimension. The class is scribbling like mad, copying down from the board as the lesson goes on.

Suddenly, a giant tiger paw appears beside you, interrupting your own note taking. Melanie sweeps all of our stuff up next to your body, than gently uses the back of her left paw to brush you and it smoothly across the desk to the other side. You're blinded for a moment as your head is enmeshed in soft orange fur. You don't struggle; it would be entirely useless, and besides you're sliding smoothly and painlessly. Even your note paper isn't getting messed up. You end up in the other corner of the desk, bag, backpack and notebooks jumbled in a heap but, more importantly, notes intact. You see Melanie smoothly laying her used note sheet where you were, to her upper right, while swiftly transitioning to a new sheet with barely a pause. Clearly, she has a system.

You watch the sapling sized pencil clenched in Melanie's paw move across her bed sheet of paper for a moment before looking back. Melanie, intent on her work, eyes far above screwed up in concentration, never-the-less spares a moment’s glance for you. You raise your eyebrows and look at her quizzically. She shrugs and gives you a wry grin. You roll your eyes and return your attention to the lesson. Mrs. Lizkit has drawn diagonals in the square and cube:

"To Reiterate," Good, you think, drawing what you missed, she's reiterating, "dimension determines how an object in space can move." She points to each line, the straight and the two diagonals, in turn: "With only one dimension an object can only go right or left. With each added dimension an object can travel in two more directions, so our real world has six directions and infinite combinations thereof. Time, of course, is needed so any of this movement can take place." She pauses, and abruptly sets the chalk down, turning to face the class. "Now, dimension gives direction, but magnitude, the amount of something, is also dependent on dimension. For your lesson on this, let's have a more practical, tangible demonstration." She turns towards yours and Melanie's desk with a strange glimmer in her eye: "John, Melanie, would you two please come to the front?"

Whispers sweep the classroom as those in back verify that there is no other John in the class and those in front tell them about you. Soon the whole class is looking over each others' shoulders to try and catch a glimpse of you. You and Melanie share a significant, apprehensive glance. This time it's your turn to shrug. Melanie gives you a considering look, than slowly scrapes her chair back and stands. She walks around the desk and pauses next to you, clearly waiting, so you scramble to your feet and hop without a pause over the edge of the desk. You hear gasps all around, and as you straighten up on Melanie’s waiting pad they turn to sighs of relief.

You’re quickly improving at maintaining you balance on Melanie’s paw, only wobbling slightly as she goes to the front and turns to face the class. You have their undivided attention, rows of giant, multicolored faces all with eyes fixed on you, or Melanie. Mrs. Lizkit begins speaking:

“Class, this is John and Melanie. John, as you may or may not know, is going to be studying with us this year. Melanie is his partner.” You raise your left hand and wave, Melanie does the same. Mrs. Lizkit leaves you hanging and goes to her desk t o retrieve some items. The instant she sets out the tape measure your heart sinks to the pit of your stomach. You can tell this will not be pleasant. Your human math teachers in elementary school had been fond of measuring their students for lessons as well; it had always been humiliating for anyone so measured.

Glancing at Melanie’s face you see a similar trepidation, but you’re fairly confident that it will be far worse for you, at your size. Mrs. Lizkit starts out with a simple question: “How much bigger are Anthros than humans?” Everyone’s hands shoots up, she calls on a bear: “Mark?”

“Ten times.”

“Yes, ten times. It varies of course, by species of Anthro and age, gender and genetics of either Anthro or human, of course. Now, John, Melanie, how tall are you?”…
113212121112122222211111111.title: Math for Anthros and humans

1132121211121222222111111111.content:
“Five foot two.” You both reply simultaneously, your response barely audible next to Melanie’s reply. You look at each other in surprise:

“You’re as tall as I am?” She asks unthinkingly. You hear a few sniggers from the first row. You theatrically look down at your feet resting on her pad, than lean over the edge of her the edge of her paw, looking first down the two blue columns of her jeans to her paws four stories below, than slowly up her body to her head hovering eight feet above you.
“Sure we’re the same height. Whatever you say.” You finally reply in your loudest shout. This earns laughter from the entire class, and you’re sure Melanie’s blushing. You can’t see color in her cheeks under the fur, but the minute movements of the face muscles which accompany it are not so minute in Melanie, and they interrupt the smooth pattern of her fur in a way that is quite obvious for someone your size. Mrs. Lizkit reclaims the class’ attention:

“Yes, as you can see there is an obvious disparity here. Let’s resolve it.” She hands Melanie the tape measure. Oh great, you think, hearing Melanie’s jokes about this already. She grabs the metal tab in her teeth and pulls out a length of tape. She sets the tab down next to you and nudges you onto it with her thumb. Your feet leave the ground several times as Melanie brings the measure down; your weight is insufficient to stabilize it. With surprising gentleness Melanie brings the tape measure down until it’s resting lightly on the top of your head. You step off and Melanie hands the measure to Mrs. Lizkit, who announces the verdict to the class: “Six inches and a little.” All your Anthro classmates, even Melanie, give a self-satisfied nod. You struggle to maintain a straight face, but it’s hard. You have always been aware of being small around Melanie, but hearing the cold, hard number mad you truly feel small. Mrs. Lizkit is oblivious; “Melanie, your turn.” She has Melanie stand on the metal tab than slowly pulls it up,. Melanie doesn’t have any trouble holding the tab down, you notice. Mrs. Lizkit carefully measures to the top of Melanie’s ear, than looks at the result:

“Melanie, congratulations.” Everyone looks her in confusion. She goes on: “You are a quite hulking 51 feet 8 inches tall.” Melanie appears quite flabbergasted, and the class seems to be at a loss for words. You straighten a bit, spirits rising. Nice to see that she’s fair with the size humiliation . The paw gives a little shake, Melanie trying to get your attention. Looking up you see her mouth something like Is that true?. She looks troubled

You nod slowly. She looks at you with dawning comprehension, and perhaps some sympathy:

“Now, this demonstration has shown that while there’s quite a difference between human and Anthro scale, we use the same units of measurement. Therefore, on all papers and test you must indicate the difference like so. She writes “in. A” and “in. h” on the board. You notice that she draws the uppercase A and lowercase h quite emphatically. “Now…” Melanie whispers to you: “She say’s ‘now’ a lot. Does she think we need to be reminded that it’s now?” You chuckle and nod in agreement. Back to Mrs. Lizkit: “Now, as our multi scaled measurements have shown, Anthros are ten times taller than humans. But the question was: ‘how much bigger are Anthros than humans?” Everyone looks at each other in confusion. What is she talking about? “Now, this relates back to dimension. ON this one line, height, the magnitude is ten times. If we were to measure width and depth, undoubtedly those to would be ten times on Melanie. But what about more than one dimension, with area and volume? Area is two dimensional, and reflects the amount that could fit on a surface, while volume is the amount that fitsin an object. Now, area is quite difficult to measure on a person. It’s skin of course, but measuring an Anthros entire surface area would be tedious in the extreme, so we’ll skip it.” You hear the last with relief, considering that she omitted humans from the tedium. You are struck with the highly unpleasant image of Melanie forcing you to lie on a paper while she traces your outline with a giant pencil, with everyone crowding around, watching. You shake yourself and return to the teacher. “Now, weight, or mass, is based on both volume, and density, how much matter an object contains and how tightly it’s packed. Melanie, how much do you weight?”

“122 pounds.” She replies, looking embarrassed.

“John?”

“124.” Mrs. Lizkit gestures towards something on her desk. As Melanie sets you down on the desk, you see to your disgust that it’s a kitchen stale. You step on without being bid. You begin to turn to glare up at the teacher: “John, please keep still.” At that, the class gives a collective snigger. You fume silently, keeping still. At least with your back turned they can’t see the heat burning in you cheeks. At last, the teacher picks you up, literally instead of offering a palm: “A little less than three ounces. Now, does the ten times ‘rule’ still apply? Jessie.” A deer Anthro:

“No. That would make a 2 pound 5 foot 2 Anthro.” Everyone laughs, even you. Mrs. Lizkit nods. “Quite, now by cube based volume, the appropriate conversion is ten times ten times ten, one thousand. However, it really is not correct. Does anyone know how much John would weigh under that conversion. Kim” A Panda Anthro:

“About 180 pounds.” Her soft spoken reply is repeated by Mrs. Lizkit, who appears to have forgotten about you, still clenched in her fist: “180 pounds, very good.” Now John here is five foot two and clearly not morbidly obese, so this is not accurate.” Not to mention the fact that I told you how much I weigh, to great embarrassment, You think crossly. Mrs. Lizkit turns to start writing on the board. You pound on her fingers just as she’s about to squash you in next to a piece of chalk, and Melanie, who had been following you with her eyes and looking very edgy while you were held by the teacher, quickly steps forward to receive you back in her paw. “Now, the fact of the matter is that humans are somewhat denser than Anthros. While the units of weight are called the same, their values are a result of the human or Anthro populations’ weights. The conversion is therefore somewhat less than one thousand times, six hundred and eighty times to be exact. However,” She turns to suddenly to the class, “That does not mean that this not a big difference. In fact, to give some perspective on the matter, our 51 foot tall friend Melanie,” She indicates Melanie, who starts squirming behind you, “weighs approximately 40 tons human, the weight of around 43 passenger cars.” The class laughs.

Suddenly, everything stops as the bell rings. While the class packs up she bars some instructions:

“Worksheet on arithmetic and textbooks by the door. Due next class.” Released, the class heads out the door, all talking about the demonstration. Melanie hurries to the desk and sets you down. You gather up your stuff and write down what you can of the notes you missed. As you head for the door, Mrs. Lizkit stops you:

“Both of you, see the principal after lunch. Don’t forget the textbooks or worksheets.” Melanie hurriedly grabs two books and sheets and hurries into the hall, getting while the getting’s good. As Melanie heads across the building towards lunch (your math was previously on the third floor, but the principal had made changes to your and Melanie’s combined schedule, probably because Mrs. Pasca was such a jerk)

“I wonder what the principal wants.” You remark.

“I dunno” Melanie replies distantly. Something appears to be troubling her. You wait patiently for her to get around to telling you about it. Finally, she fixes you with a somber eye: “Fifty one feet, huh.” She says quietly (well, quietly for her). You nod in agreement, keeping quite. She fumbles around some, “I mean,, I realized the size difference before, of course, it’s just hearing it those terms…” She takes a deep breath: “God, I must be so…” She struggles for the word, “intimidating to you. It’s, it’s.” She doesn’t tell you what it is, instead lapsing into depressed silence. You heave an inward sigh. Melanie has a tendency towards moroseness, you’ve noticed, when confronting these issues.

“Look, maybe that’s true, at some times. Certainly not now. But,” You lighten your tone, “It is true that you can be quite hulking at times.” Melanie seems downcast for a moment, but then she catches your reference. She lifts here head, a gleam of mischief in her eye:

“Well, it’s more likely that you simply don’t measure up. It’s okay, you always did seem a little dense”

“You know, I’d kind of like a passenger car right now. Could you pull one out of that massive gullet of yours for me?” You both laugh, enjoying the banter. Mission accomplished, you think with satisfaction as the conversation turns towards lighter subjects.

When you arrive at the lunchroom doors, Melanie is in excellent spirits, You can hear a sound like being next to 30 trains going by at the same time, the sound of several hundred Anthros talking all at once. Melanie talks loudly over the storm of conversation:

“Are you ready for your first all inclusive lunchroom experience?” She asks you. You ask what she means…
1132121211121222222111111111.title: Kitchen Scales and Passenger Cars

choices: … why don’t you guys pass me around?”
11321212111212222221111111111.content:
You do indeed, see. The cafeteria is a massive room with a high ceiling, packed to the gills with Anthros sitting around round tables scattered across the room. Large windows and skylights allow in a large amount of natural light, making the entire room seem airy and spacious, despite both the sheer mass of the giant seventh and eighth graders extending in every direction and the unbelievable amount of noise they are making.

Melanie’s arrival goes unnoticed as she slips through the doors, and you notice her taking unobtrusive, at least in her mind, steps to conceal you from view. She gradually cups her paw and raises her claws, creating a bowl which hides most of your body, and lowers her paw so that it’s at the level of her waist, making it less obvious that she’s carrying something valuable. You suppose she doesn’t want to be mobbed by hundreds of Anthros eager to see their first human. She probably knows best, so you take your cue from her, sitting down in her paw with only head visible. She touches you with her thumb in acknowledgement. This does limit your view, however, and mostly you see the furry, feathery or scaly backs of Anthro heads. Your patience is rewarded; however, as when Melanie reaches her destination you arrive unharassed and free to take it all in.

She sets you down and you can’t do anything but gawp. You’ve arrived at a clear area in the middle of the lunchroom, with Anthros surrounding no all sides. The sight of all those giant bodies would be stunning enough, but you also find yourself standing in front of table upon table of food of every shape and description. You’re standing at the tray, silverware, and napkin area for an enormous buffet, set upon a series of close packed tables, all heaped with food with large heating lamps suspended far above from metal structures. The smells surrounding you are intoxicating, and the sight is by turns absorbing and awe inspiring for someone your size. You’re so absorbed, in fact, that eventually the highly amused Melanie settles for the simple expedient of pushing her tray into the back of your legs, causing you to tumble backwards onto her tray with a startled yelp. You land on her napkin, the thought of which gives you a mental double-take, enough that you miss Melanie lifting the tray and heading off for food.

As you might have guessed, she makes a beeline straight for the meat. As she grabs three plates, of a size that you might just barely lie down on, filled with plain, “cooked” meat (just barely seared, really), she teases you gently:

“I see you’re impressed.”

“Oh I am.” You tell her earnestly, ignoring her humor. You look at the piles of gently steaming flesh in front of her:

“Does your mother know you’re eating like this?” You ask teasingly. She makes a face:

“Ha ha. Besides, some of this is for you.” You consider the meat, imagine taking a human sized potion out of it, then look at her skeptically. She clears her throat:

“Anyway,” she pushes forward, “I think I make up for it here.” She nods towards your next destination. Before (and below) you is a table covered with what looks like piles of green glop on those same small plates. There’s a banner above it (and above all the other table, although you didn’t notice.) This one reads: “VVEGETABLES: Carnivores.” Melanie notices your confusion and explains after setting down the tray: “There’s something very peculiar about us Anthros. You might’ve noticed it yesterday when I washed you. Here, look in the back.” Paying no mind to your strenuous protests, she grabs you and lifts you to her mouth. She tilts her head back and opens wide, then pulls out her cheek with her spare paw. Her breath isn’t too bad, considering her breakfast, but her fangs are still razor sharp and massive, so it’s with some effort that you look into the slimy cavern. At least her tongue remains where it is, lying like a huge slimy worm at the bottom of her mouth.

There, in the back, past the fangs you see four sets of molars, two on each side, which are quite flat, clearly used for grinding. You voice your discovery and Melanie blessedly closes her mouth and sets you down: “It’s weird, we carnivore Anthros have these molars in back for some reason, from when we evolved from animals to Anthros. We started needing a little green stuff in our diets. We eat this mushy stuff; we don’t have to chew it too much.” She reaches forward, and grabs a plate of a green mass she identifies as spinach.

You look at the pile dubiously:

“I hate spinach.” You complain. Melanie gives you a firm look:

“Uh uh uh.” She says as she heads towards the seats, “You’re a human. I know you guys are omnivores. You need this to be healthy even more than I do.” You just sigh and look longingly back at the berries, and the sweets Melanie passed without a glance. You try to put it out of your mind as Melanie weaves her way towards an empty table in a somewhat quieter spot.

“Quiet” Is a relative term, but it means that Melanie doesn’t have to shout to be heard and your own yelling is at least audible. You step off the tray and move a little ways towards the center of the table, away from the danger zone around the meat. You know, intellectually, that even when hungry and confronted with meat Melanie is careful around you, but still…. Melanie doesn’t notice, as she is absorbed in completely annihilating the first of her plates of meat, slicing and dicing it with practiced efficiency with her claws and then scooping great gobs into her mouth. It’s horrifying to watch, especially considering that some of the bigger pieces are just your size and all are dripping, but it’s also fascinating. She uses her claws much like chopsticks, using two or more to hold large chunks of meat without letting it touching her pad before tossing it back. You notice that despite her speed and ferocity, her method is far cleaner than one would think. Meat juices don’t go flying, instead dripping efficiently onto the plate (which, yes, Melanie does lick clean). Her face fur and whiskers remain clean and barely disturbed. If it wasn’t for her speed and gusto, you might even call it civilized, despite no utensils and her size.

Eventually, after thoroughly cleaning her plate, she leans back a bit and pays a more attention to you. Observing that you had backed away to the center of the table, she looks sheepish and beckons you closer:

“Sorry about that. I swear it runs in my family: when my mom’s relatives come over, it’s like we’ve all been starving. The younger ones even fight a bit. I’m okay now.” You come forward reluctantly, and keep well clear of her tray. She certainly wasn’t so voracious at home you think. As you come closer to the meat, which is still steaming and juicy, your mouth waters and stomach growls. You are incredibly hungry. Watching someone else eat, even a giant tiger, had increased your appetite. Melanie’s ears twitch:

“You hungry?” She asks:

“Very.” You reply in a shout. She gives a small grin:

“Good, that’ll help the spinach go down quicker.”

“MELANIE!” She laughs, but the looks he gives you is serious:

“I’m serious, John. As your Anthro helper, I have to make sure you eat right in your new, unfamiliar environment.” Her tone starts earnest, but ends quite condescending. You puncture her pompousness:

“I don’t recall any such concern when you sat down.” You point out. Her cheek fur fluffs out in a blush. She looks down at her tray, and tries to make nice, pinching off a seemingly small chunk of meat between two claws and nudges you forward, presenting it to you at head level. You look at it for a moment. While it smells and looks appetizing, the effect is ruined by the fact that, however small it might be to Melanie, it’s still the size of your foot, and you’re essentially being asked to eat out of someone’s hand:

“Melanie, aren’t you forgetting something.” She looks at you for a moment, than comprehension dawns:

“Oh! Oops! Sorry.” She quickly removes the meat, staring at it for a moment before hastily tossing it into her mouth. While she swallow, you ask:

“Melanie, you had plates and forks and knives for me at your house. Don’t they have them here?”

“I don’t know.” You both are silent for a moment, considering your dilemma. Suddenly, a soft, deep, oriental voice cuts in:

“If I might be of assistance.” The soft spoken words are gentle, and you turn as a shadow passes over you. You flinch reflexively, seeing a giant paw descending towards you, but you relax as it stops in front of you. A thick, squat paw covered with black and white fur, quite thick, holding a napkin and, to your amazement, a set of human-sized paltes, fork, knife and glass of water. You stare up at her, seeing a tall, thick-set Panda Anthro looking down at you gently. You collect your wits:

“Thank you.”

“It was my pleasure.” You swear she gives a bow as she sets the napkin down carefully on the table next to Melanie’s tray before setting her own tray down at the enxt seat, seating herself:

“I’m Kim.” She introduces herself.

“And your John and Melanie!” A new, bright voice interjects before any of you can say more. A giant Deer Anthro appears, a girl, slipping her slender form between Melanie and Kim and putting her hands down on the table. She stares almost directly down at you with large, liquid black eyes, wide with fascination and good humor: “I’m Jessie!” She informs you, sticking a platform of a hand, covered in brown fur with five squat fingers, out for you to shake. By her fascination you guess she’s just looking for an excuse to touch you, but you politely shake the tip of her index finger, feeling her smooth brown fur, different from Melanie’s, and warm skin:

“Awesome!” She breathes. You see Kim giver a nudge, and Jessie shakes herself: “Oh yeah! Hi Melanie.” Melanie grasps her entire hand and shake sit firmly, before using it to steer her and her tray towards the other seat next to her. From your position between Kim and Melanie, looming up on both sides, you can’t really see her. You take hold of the napkin and drag it towards the center of the table, seeing more and more of all three girls as you gain some distance. While this is going on, Kim says:

“That stuff was at the buffet. I saw that you forgot to take it and decided to help.” Her gentle voice takes on a tinge of irony: “Jessie just wanted to touch John.” Melanie chokes on the water she was drinking, and Jessie squeals in protest:

“KIM! That’s not fair!” Kim turns her head ponderously and looks at her:

“It’s true, isn’t it?” Jessie pauses:

“Well… Maybe a little.” She admits, staring at you raptly with those enormous eyes, “But that’s not all! I also wanted to meet you, Melanie!”

“Me? Why?” Melanie asks, surprised. Jessie pauses from eating a plateful of some shrub (sugar grass, you discover later) and smiles at you: “To learn how you got your paws on such a cute human, silly!” Melanie chokes again, and Kim pounds on her back with massive force, shaking the table, then looks at Jessie reproachfully. Jessie just smiles, clearly unabashed.

“Don’t mind Jessie.” She tells you and Melanie apologetically, “She really doesn’t know any better. But we were curious. How did you pair up with John?”

“I’d like to know that as well.” The girls’ heads come up and you whirl around at the familiar voice from behind you. There stands Brad, looking hesitant, table between him and Melanie. You smile and wave the massive Iguana over

“Hey Brad, have a seat.” He drags his feet, looking distressed:

“You sure. I mean, the way I acted earlier…” You roll your eyes. It’s like he’s just waiting to be rejected:

“Brad, I won’t hat you forever, or at all really, for that little gaff. I’ll only remember it if you keep reminding me! Now,” You swing dramatically and thrust a finger to the seat next to Kim, “Park it!” While this spectacle caused the girls behind you to burst out giggling (reflecting on it later, you have to admit that it was pretty funny, a tiny 6-inch human ordering around a lizard who could bat him around like a rag doll), it has the intended affect, as Brad quickly scurries over besides Kim and sits down. You maintain a dignified silence as the others finish their hilarity, then turn and observe as Brad gets acquainted. They seem to get along well enough, and as equilibrium is restored, each Anthro munching contently on their particular food, you grab Brad’s attention:

“Hey Brad, you were saying.” He swallows and nods:

“Yeah. How did end up here, and with Melanie. I mean, they told us that you’d be studying here in some kind of integration effort, but nothing really specific.” You and Melanie exchange a look, as Jessie and Brad look at you avidly and Kim looks on with interest, if a little more calmly. Melanie shrugs, so you launch into your tale:

“Well, it all started in the summer when I was informed I’d be coming to Eastpaw this year…” You and Melanie relate the tale, while they all look on, eating slowly. They were an excellent audience: attentive, interested and they gasped, laughed or hissed at all the right moments. Melanie took a large part of the speaking, after you’d done the first part, cuing you on just what to tell them. Some things she left out, obviously, but you were surprised with how much she included, especially her own screw-ups, about which she was brutally honest. While she was relating how she carried you home from school (during which time you were unconscious) she makes a motion towards you without pausing. When she has your attention at table-level, she crooks a finger slowly and insistently. You sigh, and grab your plates, walking over.

She gives you a large glob of spinach and a hunk of meat, both more than you can eat, and sends you back to your seat in the center of the table with a firm poke. Well, her message couldn’t be clearer, so you bravely force down some spinach while she watches you discretely from the corner of her eye. After what you judge is enough, you attack the meat, with almost the same level of ferocity as Melanie. After all, you’re a meat eater as well. You leave a lot on the plates, but after Melanie finishes bringing them up to date, with her setting you down on this very table, she leaves them in contemplative silence for a moment to quickly reach over with a paw, grab your plates and toss their contents into her mouth with a single motion. Catching the others’ astonished looks, she smiles:

“Well, one thing that’s nice about John: he’s sure easy to clean up after.” She catches your look: “Ooops, sorry John. I should’ve asked. You just looked like your done.” Considering that you’re sitting leaned back on your arms, legs splayed out, it was a reasonable enough assumption, so you let it pass. She explains to the others: “You see, unless we’re in a situation that requires an Anthro to take charge, we should probably respect John’s dignity and have the good manners to ask.” The others nod in agreement. You detect a large amount of wiggle room for Melanie, and the others, to use in that statement, but at least she got the message across, and believed it herself. You all sit in silence for a moment, mulling things over quietly, adjusting to each other. This gives you inspiration. Getting to your feet, you call out: “I have an idea,…
11321212111212222221111111111.title: Lunchtime, with some new friends

choices: ...the principal wants to show you some human-inclusive facilities
...the principal is sitting with a large number of officials
113212121112122222211111111112.content:
"Why don’t you guys all pass me around?" You propose. Four sets of giant eyes widen:

"You serious?" "Are you sure?" "Cool!" Come out simultaneously from Brad, Melanie and Jessie respectively. You nod, and Kim, who had been regarding you approvingly, rumbles:

"Thank you John. I know it's a big thing, trusting us like this" Her voice is sincere, and you smile as you reply:

"Well, I'm here to learn about, interact with and trust you guys, right? Maybe this will make humans seem a bit more real to you guys as well." This brings another chorus of approval from the Anthros. You stand and make your way closer to Jessie, who's positively quivering with excitement. You slow your step a little, nervous at the massive, quivering ball of fur and energy. She notices and looks at you with her enormous, quivering pools of eyes:

"Oh come on John, don't be nervous. Please?" Her plea is too much for you, and you resume your quick step. Kim observes:

"Forget puppydog eyes, they're amateurs compared to Jessie." Everyone laughs. Arriving at Jessie’s tray, you look over the detritus of her meal. There are several plates, with various types of large shrubs lying around, neglected in favor of the new entertainment- you. It appears that Deer Anthros do use utensils, as you spot a large fork leaning askew off a plate. Right near you there’s a large (taller than you) glass, with a milk residue coating the sides and bottom. So distracted are you, that you don't even notice as a shadow falls over you until it’s too late. Looking up, you See Jessie’s hand mere feet from your body, fingers extended in full grab position. You're frozen like a deer in the headlights (oh the irony), and you would surely have been snatched up if not for a timely intervention by Brad:

"Jessie, hold it!" Jessie freezes, to your intense relief: "Don't just grab John. Lay out your hand, and He'll get on." He sounds bossy and know-it all, and you and Melanie smother a matched pair of grins. Jessie complies, laying out her brown hand on the tray, and you carefully step up onto the unsteady surface. Unlike Brad, there's little hesitation or trepidation with Jessie. She raises you to head level and gazes at you raptly. She turns her paw this way and that, examining you from every angle. Finally, she brings up her other hand and, after giving you a pleading look and getting a nod in return, gently strokes you, feeling your skin an clothing. You suffer yourself to be thus touched with dignity. While Jessie clearly is loving just about everything about this experience, she is careful and considerate. The feel of her large, warm fingers is actually quite nice. Finally after getting her fill of touching you, she suddenly closes her fingers and momentarily encircles you with warmth. Your trapped, and at her mercy, but you trust her. Melanie is not quite so blithe, however, and draws breath to reprimand Jessie sharply. Jessie lets go quickly, however, and smile at you;

"Thanks. That was so totally cool. I just couldn't resist." She reluctantly hands you off to Melanie. As you step onto the familiar pad, Jessie leans over and addresses the group:

"He's so CUTE!" Everyone groans at this and you prudently duck as Brad and Kim start throwing balled up napkins and Jessie. After that dies down, Melanie holds you for a moment more, than gives you a smile and a nod and passes you to Kim.

Kim's paw is far larger than Melanie's, with thick, stubby digits tipped with longer claws. Kim takes you calmly, and you survey her, looking up her white/black arm to her stout body, and then up into her gentle face with its small brown nose and black eyes regarding you. You feel her move her arm up and down minutely, taking in your weight, and then you swear she gives you a formal nod. You can't help it: you bow back, from te waist. She gives you one final, apprising glance, and then, to your complete astonishment, a wink. With that, you go to Brad.

Brad’s hand is as hard, green and scaly as ever, but now that he’s already had one experience with you he stays calm. His hand is so steady, in fact, that you feel safe walking across his palms and looking down at his tray. He’s a herbivore to, you notice, with bits of flowers and some kind of fruit littering his plates. Straightening and looking up, you see that while he might not be nervous anymore, he’s still finds you fascinating, his eyes firmly fixed on your movements. You clear your throat:

“Had enough?” You ask. He blinks, than sighs. You notice that there’s a massive flap of skin under his chin, connecting with his neck, which seems to indicate his emotions. It relaxes from being taut as he nods and carefully sets you down. You hop off his hand and return to your place at the center of the table. You notice Melanie and Kim have their heads together, but you can’t hear what they’re saying. You wait patiently, and finally they both straighten and look at you:

“John.” Kim says, “Me and Melanie were just thinking. You clearly don’t have a lot of experience with Anthros.” You nod, wondering where this is going. “Well, as you’ve no doubt noticed, there are quite a few differences between us.” Everyone chuckles. “Well, besides the size difference, which you’re clearly handling, there’s also the fact that there are a lot of different kinds of Anthros, which all evolved from animals similar to the ones you know. But do you know all us Anthros by sight? It’s quite important. It’s considered insulting to get an Anthro race wrong, and some of the more… hotheaded ones often start fights over mislabeling.” You stammer, at a loss, as the others all nod sagely. “We might be able to forgive you for a slip-up, but you might not be so lucky with other people.”

“AFs.” Brad mutters darkly, stabbing a flower with excessive force. Kim nods, but doesn’t provide you with an explanation:

“Now, why don’t we have a little test of your knowledge? Let’s start with Brad.” You gather yourself and reply promptly:

“Brad’s an iguana.” Melanie cuts in:

“That’s a good start. What kind of Iguana?”

“Uh, uh…” You rack your brain and finally offer: “Um… Scaly Iguana?” Jessie snorts and Melanie gives a sigh of exasperation. Brad rolls his eyes:

“Scaly huh. Hmm. I personally prefer ‘Green’ Iguana, not to be confused with the ‘Gray’ Iguana.” You flush in embarrassment:

“That was my next guess.” He laughs. Melanie waves and points to Jessie:

“Jessie’s a Deer.” Jessie smiles and shakes her head, “Okay, not just Deer. Um… Brown Deer.” Jessie giggles:

“No silly. Red Deer!” You suddenly notice the slight reddish sheen to her brown fur and mentally kick yourself. Next, Melanie points to herself:

“Tiger.” Melanie nods:

“Good enough.” You breathe a sigh of relief as she moves o Kim:

“Panda.” Kim shakes her head:

“Giant Panda.” You stare. She snorts loudly: “No, it has nothing to do with me being an Anthro. It’s just to distinguish us from Brown Pandas.” She turns to Melanie:

“Well, how’d he do?” Melanie pauses than says dramatically:

“Drum roll please.” Jessie and Brad comply with clear enthusiasm, pounding the table rapidly with their hands. The shaking is so bad that it knocks you off your feet, rattling their own cups to an alarming degree, but they ignore both as Melanie gives her verdict:

“New Human Student John has officially,” She pauses for affect: “…failed First grade.” All four break out laughing at this as you climb back to your feet and regard them sourly. At last, their hilarity ends. Melanie apologizes, mirth still in her voice:

“Sorry John, we just couldn’t resist. We know it’s not your fault, but in elementary school we spend four of six years being constantly quizzed on this kind of thing, and they are brutal. We’ll help you learn in a shorter period, and maybe, if you ask nicely, a bit less brutally.” They all nod in unison I really wish they’d stop doing that you think. Just then the bell, as loud and screeching as ever, rings. Just as loud and screeching is the sound of hundreds of giant chair legs screeching along the floor as their owners scoot back. You stand well clear as Melanie and your new friends gather their belongings, large backpacks impacting the table before being shouldered, trays being grabbed. When they’re all ready, standing with backpacks properly on backs and trays held clear, you walk towards the edge of the table, where they’re all standing around waiting. You Melanie does a little juggling, than turns, presenting her profile. You step off of the edge of the table onto her proffered pad, and you all are off. They all drop their trays off, than join the general stream.

The other three huddle around Melanie, shielding you from the overly curious. Kim is particularly effective, walking in front to clear a path, while Jessie and Brad on either side chatter happily about you over your head. You don’t mind. You’re starting to get a hang of this whole Anthro school thing. The group breaks up in the hallway, none of them have the same class as you and Melanie, but they all looked distinctly queasy when Melanie, after consulting her schedule with one hand, with you looking on, announces:

“Literature, with Mrs. Gotec.” She looks up; “What?” They all shake their heads; expressing their sympathy, then head off. You and Melanie head for the office. On the way, As Melanie carefully forges a path, fending off curious Anthros, you ask:

“So. You never did tell me. What did you mean when you said an “all-inclusive” experience.” Melanie smiles as she heads down a side hallway, into less traffic.:

“Well, it’s kind of the way the school system works. There are quite a few different races of Anthro, all with their own special requirements. You see where this is going.” You nod, it’s obvious enough, considering the vast amount and variety of food you saw at lunch:

“They take care of each species individual needs.” To your surprise, Melanie shakes her head:

“Ah, not quite. There’s actually two ways they have of doing things. ‘All-inclusive’ is like you said, they accommodate everyone carnivores, herbivores, insectivores, whatever. But that’s actually pretty rare. For most things, there’s something else. They change the official name all the time, but we call it ‘none-inclusive’.”

“None inclusive?”

“That’s right. They managed to find a way to set things up so that no one benefits. Like these floors, made of tile, or the school-issued pencils, or just about anything else.”

“How’d they do that?”

“Simple. They copied the way you humans do it, except on our scale. Since there aren’t any Anthro Monkeys, everyone else suffers, even humans since you’re, well,” she gestures at you, “six inches tall.” You nod:

“I guess that would do it. So, it’s like that with almost everything?”

“Yeah. Only lunch and the bathrooms are all-inclusive. If it weren’t for our parents, even those wouldn’t be- what?” At the word “bathroom”, you suddenly became aware of a very urgent need, and it clearly showed on your face:

“Ash, Melanie, speaking of bathrooms…”

“Say no more.” It sounds more like a command than an assurance, but Melanie quickly changes directions, and you find yourself at two twin doors. Rather than a human man and woman stick figure, it instead had simply an empty dress and an empty tee-shirt and pants. You suddenly realize that there’s a fairly large problem here. Melanie looks at you apprehensively:

“I don’t suppose you could open that door, could you.” You take one look at the men’s room door and shake your head. It was over one hundred feet high, clearly designed with giraffes in mind. Considering your problem with Melanie’s door, which was only seventy feet high, there’s no way you can budge this one. Besides:

“Even if I did get inside, I wouldn’t be able to get out again. The handle’s too high up.” She nods glumly, and then squares here shoulders:

“You’ll just have to come into the Girl’s room then. Don’t you dare say a word about this to anyone.” She warns as she pushes open the door.” Inside it is fairly nice, and unbelievably large, with innumerable sinks and an bewildering number of stalls, all marked with various animal figures. She turns and locks the door, then heads down the stalls, then opens one up and sets you down. Without a word, she pulls the door closed and heads down a few stalls.

This is without a doubt one of the most embarrassing situations of your life. You are of course far shorter than the stall walls, and if you choose you could've easily looked left under the stalls. However, you don't, instead keeping your eyes fixed on the throne-toilet, identical to the one at the Prusten's. Thankfully, the end of the toilet paper reached down from on the stall wall, thirty feet over your head, to the floor. You would not have been able to stand it if you had to ask Melanie for help. You do your business quickly, trying to concentrate on the handle to the door, which of course is unlocked. After you finish, you wait for the sound of Melanie’s door opening before you leave the stall. You spot her at one of the sinks, washing visible, tail swishing a few feet above the floor, clearly tense. As you reach her feet she leans down without a word and picks you up. Thankfully, her hands smell only of incredibly powerful soap, which is itself enough to make you gag. You wash your own hands with some she dispenses for you, than leave the bathroom behind with intense relief. She walks quickly through the now-empty halls and arrives at a very official-looking door:: "MAIN OFFICE" Melanie regards you for a moment:

"Let's never talk about that. Ever." You acquiesce and you both silently walk into the office, where...
113212121112122222211111111112.title: All-inclusiveness

1132121211121222222111111111121.content:
"Ah, John, how're you settling in" the principal asked, seeming excited.

"Good enough" you answer, though you saw that this was still going to be a rough school year for you.

"Well, we've got a few surprises for you" the principal said, "we're working to make the building more 'human friendly' and a few scientists have made something for you. Unfortunately they didn't tell us what its supposed to be." the principal moved his hand and behind it was some sort of weird suit.

Looking at it, the suit was standing on its own, had a helmet with a visor and over all resembled some sort of anime space suit. You tapped on the black helmet glass and a pair of yellow 'eyes' appeared. "Stand by for neural uplink" the suit announced.

"What the he..." you started to say, but were cut off as you felt a sharp pain in your temples. The shoot had shot something at you!

"Neural uplink complete, system ready for secure command transfer" the suit announced, then just stood there, you looked to Melenie and the principle, "any idea what that means?"

Melanie shook her head, but the principle seemed to have some understanding of what was going on, "maybe its supposed to read your thoughts?"

"Worth a shot" you said, then thought about an explanation from the suit.

Suddenly information projected itself onto your eyes, apparently that neural link was two ways. Not only did you tell the suit things, it could answer them and show you things.

"Wow!" you say, taking a step back, "this is sooo cool."

"What?" Melanie asked, "what's it doing?"

"Somehow its projecting information onto my eyes, the suit was built to help me get around and survive easier here, its supposed to adapt to my needs.

"You'll look pretty stupid wearing that" Melanie said, afterall how many people went around wearing space suits to school.

"Its more than just a suit" you reply, concentrating on the rapid transportation, you watch the suit break up into several small parts, all of them having a bit of a glow as they shoot into the air and onto your back. Straps extend from a piece that holds on your back, other pieces stretch down your arms and legs. On your arms, the pieces come to a round thing resting in your palm, on your legs they go down to a pair of jets on the sides and behind your legs. Then, in back a part comes out and wings expand, its a jet pack of some sort. The projection on your eyes flashes for a second and begins to show information important to flight, but with a thought you can make it all dissappear as well.

"Wow" Melanie says, it was her turn to be surprised, "you guys are ingenious little people, that's for sure."

You smile and key the suit to take off, you shoot up and arch onto your back, a backwards flip and a roll leaves you hovering over Melanie's shoulder. "This thing is definitely cool" you say, "I wish you could see all the things it can do, and I haven't even gotten through all the stuff it started to show me."

"So far its a tiny air plane" Melanie said,sort of upset that you probably wouldn't need her as much anymore.

"Its a bit more" you say, "I'll show you after school."

"Maybe next class" Melanie replies, heading out the door, you follow her,

"where's our next class?"
1132121211121222222111111111121.title: ...the principal wants to show you some human-i...

11321212111212222221111111111211.content:
"You're gonna love this," Melanie answered, "Gym."

That was not the answer you'd hoped for, given how just getting around was such a challenge, Gym class could be enough to kill you. "Lovely, I'm gonna go get killed" you say uneasily, but hoping the suit of yours had something that'd help you live through this.

Melanie took you to the boy's locker room, though there certainly weren't any uniforms that'd fit you; much more likely was you'd get trampled in there. Not taking the chance of that, you kept airborne and buzzed inside to the gym teacher, well the male teacher; there was one for girls and one for guys.

"Excuse me" you called to the teacher, who just so happened to be a lion, "what'll I be doing."

"Well, somehow you'll be joining in" he answered, "you may not be able to wear any of our uniforms or participate the same as the rest, but somehow you will. Now get out there and wait for further instruction."

That was blunt, bland, and you really didn't think anyone could've given a more direct order or answer. With a kick backwards you shot yourself out level and into full flight, all of the Anthros in their uniforms were sitting on the Gym floor, legs crossed.

Spotting Melanie you blazed over and landed on her knee for now, it seemed the best place. "Now what?" you ask.

"From what I've heard, dodge ball" Melanie answered, then with a giggle, "maybe it'll be a game of cat and
mouse."

"We'll see" you answer, though it seemed more like it'd be a game of 'run for your life' mixed with a bit of avoiding getting stomped on.
11321212111212222221111111111211.title: Gym!

113212121112122222211111111112111.content:
Well, it really sucked sometimes when you were right, but others it was even worse when it was your giant anthro friend. Today was an even worse day for you.

The gym teachers marked out the border line, and head everyone from either side race to the wall while they brought out the balls. You stuck close to Melanie hoping that she'd be able to defend you at least for a short while, or until you had something better than flying between shots.

A whistle blew and total hell unleashed, the giants sieged forward and massive spheres went flying; it was nearly impossible to avoid them all. Buzzing up, down, left, right, forward and back, these things were coming from everywhere!

Then, out of the blue one was coming in and there wasn't a thing you could do to escape it. "ahh!" you screamed, watching it close in, envisioning your demise.

The ALSS suddenly came to the rescue, "ECS" flashed on the screen, you had no idea what it was, but it couldn't be any worse than being pulverized by a gigantic dodge ball. The wings retracted in, parts of the armor shot off into the air and latched onto you elsewhere.

You plummeted towards the ground, as you hit the ground your knees cave with the suit; next thing you know your kneeling there in something that looked like some kind of super hero suit from the comic books. Sleek metal plates covered your body, and somehow weaved inside of them an infinite number of mechanical parts making this tin can work.

"Time to fight back" you said to yourself, running towards an incoming ball, leaping up, boosters firing and catching it in mid air. All it did was push you back a bit! Holding it tightly you spun, as hard and fast as you could and hurled it across the lines to a lizard running for a ball. Your shot caught him in the hand, he was out.

The next shot on you was too fast, this time though, you had an alternative. Hovering in the air, you cut the jets in your boosts and dropped like a stone to the ground.

Luckily Melanie though was in a position to catch the ball, unfortunately for you, when she rank forward, she stepped on you! Her huge foot had you pinned to the ground, but that suit held together and kept her from crushing you; but she wasn't moving, at least not fast. On your back you figured to try and get her off, pushing up you found the suit actually had enough strength to pick her up!

As soon as your arms were fully extended you fired the boost jets and shot forward, then pushed upward and pulled yourself off the floor to be standing in front of Melanie. "Mind NOT stepping on me" you said, before ducking, spinning to hit a ball back to the enemy side.

Melanie was in total shock at what you just did, but there wasn't time for that now, both of you were in the middle of a game and had work to do, primarily work defending yourselves from the incoming balls and the people hurling them at you.

The rest of the class went pretty well, though as you went on you found this form was too heavily armored to do well with constant flight. For a lot of the class you wound up using your team mates as spring boards, but they didn't mind, a few even through you at high up balls to send them to the other side.
113212121112122222211111111112111.title: A Dodging We shall go!

1132121211121222222111111111121111.content:
Gym marked your last class of the day. You waited on the Gym bleachers for Melanie who'd gone off to take the ugly gym uniform off and put her regular clothes back on. The giants seemed to go streaming out while you sat there dangling your legs over the side of the huge bleachers. They were folded up and made one tall wall.

Finally, after what seemed an eternity, Melanie finally came out. In present form you couldn't sustain flight, but she was still willing to carry you, though for now you just sat on her shoulder; it certainly seemed preferable to being carried around on her hand.

"Hey John, wanna get some ice cream on the way home" Melanie asked.

This seemed odd, but it might be on the way to her house anyway; and ice cream did sound good, albeit you didn't know how you'd eat it all. "I guess" you say, then recalling some of the jokes earlier, "are you getting a car full or a truck full?"

"Don't fall in" Melanie replied laughing, "a small one's enough for you to swim in. That density of yours just might make you sink." She got a mischievious look in her eye, you weren't totally sure what she was thinking, but somehow you had a feeling you'd be getting wet.

"Why do I get the feeling this is going to be an enlightening trip?" you asked, fiddling with the armor and finally figuring out how to change it at will. With a boost from the boosters you shot up and off of Melanie's shoulders, doing a flip, parts started to shoot off the armor as it changed around. Short wings formed on your back, coming up about halfway up your back they were triangular, delta wings. The armored plating was pretty much gone, all that was left of that were a few underparts leading down to your legs and along or your arms to the repulsers and boosters on your legs.

Melanie kept walking as you hovered next to her, you eventually flipped onto your back and flew backwards, keeping up with her. Sometimes it was better to have a face to talk to than just a wall of fur, "So, where is this place?" you asked.

"Not too far" Melanie answered, though not exactly giving you an exact enough answer to get there on your own. The suit had a navigational system, but that did you little good if you didn't know which if the various ice cream joints she was headed for. "Race ya"

"How'm I gonna win? I don't even know where we're going" you reply, but it was too late, the tigress was already rocketing ahead. "Ah great, just great"

You going into a roll and a dive, shooting forward low to the ground, you keep pace with the fast feline, waiting until your destination is in view. Then you'd pick up the pace and shoot past her.
1132121211121222222111111111121111.title: After School

11321212111212222221111111111211111.content:
Melanie sure was fast, she kept going and going and going. Of course, her mile was a couple of yours and she had a much bigger stride; still though, she was no match for your rockets.

You stayed at her side along the sidewalk, keeping a good enough distance to make sure you didn't get trampled again. Shooting along you had to duck, roll and dive to avoid some unexpected obstacles; anthros, grass, trees, mail boxes, telephone poles and much more. In this competition size was Melanie's only advantage and unfortunately that meant you had to weave and dive, she didn't.

Then, up ahead you saw what you appeared to be your destination, a tall building built to serve people outside, so there was a counter and windows. You couldn't make out what the name was, but there was a fairly decent crowd of Anthro's gathered around it. "That'd better be it" you tell yourself.

Melanie's hand was right in front in your path, but not for long. Arms straight back you angled the repulsers in your hands and started a roll, which dropped you under her hand as you shot to full speed. Around you pressure built up, the suit started to expand an armor coating to protect you from it. Suddenly you felt something weird and heard a massive bang. You'd gone super sonic!

Melanie was left in your dust as you shot at the building, a tiny missile; there was just one problem. How the hell were you gonna stop! You flipped yourself around, head first and fired everything you had to full. The wall of fur, scales and skin though was still in your way and you were still going too fast. Rotating thrust around you moved left and right between their legs like water ski-ing.

Finally you reached the wall, which you slammed into with a pretty loud thud. The back thruster kept you aloft for now, you pushed off the wall and let your jet boots and hand repulsers take over in keeping you hovering. With a slight increase in power you floated up to the counter and touched down right against the wall.

"Now just to wait on Melanie" you told yourself, walking towards the edge, armor retreating as you went. In the end you sat on the ledge, dangling your legs over. The wings for now had receeded to a much smaller pair with a smaller thruster on your back and an angle one on either side of you.

Melanie walked up and got in line, her orange fur stuck out amidst the mess of other anthros. It took a while, but eventually she made it to the front of your line, "fast little toy you've got there" she said, a tad upset at loosing the race to little you.

"I don't think I'll use it as much" you admit, "I'm here to get used to living around anthros, not play with an ultra advanced suit." Melanie perked up a bit at that, as it meant you'd still be relying on her, "that doesn't mean I'm totally done with it How else am I gonna keep up in a race."

"By getting faster" Melanie answered. You hear someone coming up behind you, these anthros weren't all quiet, turning you see a deer has come to take your order, "what do you want John?"

"Mind sharing?" you reply, "unless they sell ice cream about in a dish about a couple centimeters tall." The thought of a full thing of ice cream was rather entertaining for you, that'd be a swimming pool worth of ice cream. You shook for a second at the realization of how cold that'd be.

"Medium vanilla in a dish" Melanie told the deer, the anthro behind the counter went to get the order, you stood up climbed up on Melanie's paw, then climbed up and sat on her shoulder.

"Cat carrying a mouse" Melanie said, turning her head to look down at you. It wasn't exactly the most entertaining idea, especially with this being a bad place to be if you ever ticked her off; which at some point during the school year you undoubtably would.

"How many mice do you know that fly?" you reply, now you'd never seen a mouse fly, but that certainly didn't mean Melanie hadn't.

"Several" Melanie answered, "of course they needed a little help." Just then the server came back with what to you was several tons of ice cream; Melanie paid her with a dollar at least as big as you were, if not a bit bigger. Melanie turned, nearly throwing you off, luckily you didn't as she headed back to her house, eating on the way. Every now and then she brought the spoon up to you, and you'd scoop a bit out in your hand; that was a LOT of ice cream.
11321212111212222221111111111211111.title: Ice scream

113212121112122222211111111112111111.content:
The trip back to Melanie's house was uneventful, by the time you got there it was pretty much dinner time. Melanie took the books and homework upstairs, while you headed for the table with the suit of yours (called ALSS).

"Hey dad! Can we have friends for dinner!" Melanie called from upstairs. You had been sitting down on the table, when you heard Melanie yell down, two meanings came to mind; having friends OVER for dinner and EATING friends. That tiger was definitely saying thing's that'd freak you out, now if only you had something to fire back, of course a verbal fight with a giant tiger might not be wise either.

"Sure" Melanie's dad answered, as he walked in, "hello John, how was school."

You stand up and take off, flying up to eye level, "good, I got this to help me get around." you answer, eager to show off what for you was a new toy. "This thing can do anything."

"There must be something it can't do" the tiger said as he sat down, "everything has it flaws."

"Well, its gotta be pretty close" you reply, then concentrating on some of the suits other forms transform it to show some of the things it'd done earlier. First you made it into that other, high speed flight mode, with and without armor, then that super hero thing from gym class. Then it surprised you by suggesting another form, which you except and tried.

In mid air just about every part of it shot off and formed a hover board under your feet. It was just slightly under so you fell down onto it, then another form came up on the display, this one was another flight set up, but no back boosters, just the legs and arm repulsors; it also displayed a variant with armor on it as well.

Just then the doorbell rings, no don't Melanie's friends coming over...
113212121112122222211111111112111111.title: Friends for Dinner

1132121211121222222111111111121111112.content:
Dinner was fast and uneventful, it was indeed your friends from the lunch table who'd come over. Brad, Jess and Kim; right after dinner they headed up to Melanie's room while your giant friend stayed behind and picked up. It was quite tempting to just fly up, but you'd told yourself you'd stick to what anyone else would deal with and what you'd come here to do.

Melanie finished picking up pretty quickly, moving tons of food in a few minutes; there was still enough to feed an army as far as you were concerned. She walked over and held her hand out, you jumped up on, then climbed up to her shoulder; which she wasn't expecting. The tigress's shoulder though was a better spot, her hands were free and you were less of a distraction to others.

"Well that's new" she said, walking over to the stairs, "looking for a higher spot? And I always thought rats preferred to hang low.

"Well, with me here, it leaves your hands free" you explain, "better than going around one handed isn't it?" She started up the stairs, a bumper trip and you did have to hold onto a big of her fur to avoid falling off; that wasn't much of a problem though, you'd certainly be holding on if you were in her hands.

At the top of the stairs she rounded the corner and walked into her room, everyone was sitting on the floor tackling their daily dose of homework. From here it looked to be an overdose, then again, the books were somewhere around ten or more times bigger than any you'd ever had. Even the 'books' you used this year. To get around one of the size barriers, you'd be given an ebook reader with all the electronic forms of your books on it.

Melanie sat down cross legged next to Kim, her arm hand was resting on your knee, a perfect route down for you. Sitting down you slid down to her knee and jumped over the edge to the ground, rolling on contact to dissipate your momentum. That was a tiny distance to an anthro, but a big enough fall to kill you if the landing wasn't just right.

"So, what's everyone working on?" you called up to your giant friends.

"Math, science, social studies" came the replies from everyone, working on something different, though Melanie had yet to start, she was still rumaging in her back pack. While at it, she handed you yours so you could get to work, then she passed down some of the giant papers from the classes that hadn't given you an assignment to scale.

"Oh boy," you said, looking at the lawn of paper, "normally we mow the yard, not write on it." This earned you a few laughs from your friends as they watched you attempt to find a way to work on this. Eventually you just passed up on the giant papers for now and headed over to the scaled down ones, which would be much, much easier to work on.

You layed on your belly there, put your earbuds in and listend to music while working; what better way to make time fly than with a sub-concious distraction going on in the background. The work on your scale was pretty easy and the material seemed dated, this was stuff you'd covered a long, long, while ago. For now you dismissed this as just a result of different curiculums.
