15321.content:
As a fervent supporter of the human/anthro integration movement, you enthusiastically volunteered to teach grade school in an anthro community. You feel like you are well suited for the job, because everyone you know tells you that you handle stress very well, and you have even talked on the phone many times with the anthros themselves. They have had nothing but support for your decision, but of course those anthros were also part of the human/anthro integration movement.

As you drive across the imaginary border set between the human and anthro worlds, you notice that the anthro world is quite larger than the human world. In fact, everything seems to be bigger by...
15321.title: Teacher Transfer

choices: The school year has not started yet.
You are taken to see your class for the first time.
153212.content:
Everything is absolutely huge. Even the average mailbox is the size of a skyscraper, maybe larger. You wonder how you are going to maintain control of your students. The small ones should still be tall enough to make your own home seem smaller than a doll house.

In fact, you get a good view of an anthro playing in her yard as you drive along. It is an intimidating thing to see a massive raven child playing with a ball while her even larger father sits on a porch watching her play. You have a couple of second thoughts about teaching at your new school, but you quickly stuff them away. This needs to be done and you have to start with the young. The world simply can’t keep going on the way it is, with the anthros and the humans living separately. Everyone was going to have to learn to live together eventually or only bad things could happen in the future.

You are happy you do not have to drive too far into the anthro community though. It seems like it would be an accident waiting to happen if you had to drive through this giant neighborhood. And it would take an incredibly long time to drive to the school. The school was only two miles from where you currently were to the anthros, but to you it was about 600 miles away. Even if there was never any traffic on the road, the thought of which really scared you, it would take a few hours to get to school every day.

All you had to do was drive to the principal’s house which was right next to the raven child’s house. The drive up the driveway took longer than you had expected it to, but that was the only complication. Next, you followed the instructions you had been given and drove along the sidewalk to the steps leading up to the house of your new school’s principal. You were not expected to climb up the steps to the house since it would take you the better part of a day to climb those steps even if you knew how to climb those steps. On those steps was a little button meant for you to press. You had been told that the button had been wired to the principal’s doorbell and that he would be here to answer it when you arrived.

You were a little nervous as you pressed the button. This would be your first time meeting an anthro up close. Even the size of the raven child had been enough to intimidate you from a distance. Now you were going to meet a full grown anthro and be handled by that same anthro. You had also heard he was tall even for an anthro. The sound of the doorbell ringing sounded like one of those huge church bells and it was easy to tell when the principal approached the door. There were small tremors in the ground even before you heard the gigantic mechanisms that made up the lock on the door moving. Then the door whose top you could not see swung open and you were greeted by the smiling face of an incredibly large ocelot. “Greetings human, I’m pleased to meet you.”

153221.content:
He was very large, even for an alien. That's what Gordon had been told. He wouldn't mention that, however, if it was never brought up. Ever since the first contact size had been a pretty sore subject between the people of Earth and the intergalactic community. Humans were used to being the biggest beings on the block, after all, and it was a severe shock to find out they weren't even close to it once you got off good old terra firma.

Gordon was in a waiting room that looked like any other. It had white walls with pastel green flowers patterned on the paper, matching chairs that you didn't want to sit in for very long, a modest coffee table with old copies of news and education magazines. There was no one else in the room, not even the secretary. She had gone to make sure that Chlik was ready to receive company. Neither of them had any expectations that someone would show up in her absence.

He sat there, on one of three chairs in front of the coffee table, purposefully ignoring the magazines. All of them featured the aliens prominently on the cover, either in photographs or in artist's renderings. And all of them, consciously or not, emphasized the vast difference in size. One featured a being that looked like a perfect blend of man and fox leaning against a building and smiling roguishly at the photographer. Another showed a human being craning his head back to look up past the frame of the picture. He was next to an enormous, furred foot.

The articles inside would talk about the aliens and their impact on human culture since the arrival. Cities were being refitted to allow them to visit, movies and television shows were scrambling to add them to casts, the world's governments were scrambling to put up a united diplomatic front to a cosmic civilization that just became a reality for them a year ago. This didn't even mention the vast scientific, philosophical and theological debates that were storming through their respective communities. These were perhaps the most uncertain times in human history. One thing, however, was for sure – nothing would ever be the same, and humanity needed people to step up and be the trailblazers that were so desperately needed.

Gordon considered himself just such a man. When the call went out for humans to travel the galaxy and become a part of the very first knowledge exchange program between Earth and other planets, he was one of the first to sign up. The screening process was intense, and it took the better part of a year to make it through. All the pain and effort had lead up to this moment, however; he was about to meet his very first alien, something that only a few thousand people had ever done.

The door to the meeting area swung open, and the secretary entered. She looked around briefly before she found him. “Gordon,” she said, and gave him a rather shy grin. “Are you ready?”

He looked her over once, and deduced that she hadn't had much contacts with aliens either. You can always tell, he'd learned, by the flushed faces and slight breathlessness people always had from the encounter.

“As ready as I'll ever be, I guess.” He smiled back, sure he must have looked nervous.

The secretary nodded. “Then Chlik will see you now. You remember the protocol?”

“Of course.”

“Excellent. All you need to do is step into the decontamination room, wait five seconds for the light above the door to turn green, and then step forward. You'll step out onto his table.”

Gordon nodded. “Great. Thanks so much.”

The secretary ducked her head and stepped aside. “No problem, Mr. Shumway. Enjoy the meeting, and buzz me any time if you need anything.”

He stepped into the decontamination room, his heart pounding. The door shut behind him, and the entire room buzzed. Five seconds later, millions of nanites had removed all harmful pathogens from his body. Just one of the many breakthroughs in technology humanity has enjoyed since the aliens came. The light turned green. He took a couple of deep breaths, and tried to steady his hand as he reached for the doorknob. He gave it a short twist, and it swung open.

A vast concrete surface spread out before him, extending from the door for about fifty feet. It looked off to him for some reason, and he couldn't quite figure why until he noticed the oversized silverware scattered about. There was a plate the size of a carousel off to his left, and a matching teacup to his right. There were forks and knives the size of small hills scattered close to them.

“Hello,” thundered a voice inside his head. Even though he had been trained to expect this, he jumped. He hadn't even noticed the alien yet, but it already knew he was here. Something outside of his field of vision moved, and the table darkened.

Gordon looked up to see the biggest...
153221.title: The New Teacher: First Meeting

choices: ...would love to get out of these stuffy clothes."
1532211.content:
You can always understand a concept, theoretically. The sun is extraordinarily hot for example. Nazis are evil. And aliens are usually very large. We learn these things as more or less universal truths. When we come face to face with the reality of these facts, however, it always ends up surprising us how true these truths really are.

Chlik was very, very large. The enormous teacup to Gordon's right was about the right size for an immense hot tub, and the rabbit-like alien could only fit one furry finger through the handle the human was sure he could fit his entire body through. The waiting room and meeting area was on the sixth floor of a skyscraper that had been retro-fitted for alien contact, but he found himself face to face with the bottom of a truly gigantic chest while Chlik was sitting down. If the giant got up, he was sure that he'd be staring at thighs wider than some buildings.

For that brief moment, Gordon had forgotten all of his training. He had been told about this, that he should expect awe to wash over him, that his mind would go blank just like this, that his jaw would go slack without him even realizing it. His heart would start to hammer in his chest. He would feel the wild, instinctive need to run, his brain hijacked by the lizard-like portion only concerned with food, sex and survival. These facts had been hammered into him again and again during his training and screening, reinforced with the pop culture articles he had read, cemented by the more scientific studies. And yet, here he was, experiencing it despite the defenses and workarounds he had developed. He could only look up and stare while his mind cast about for something, anything that would help him cope with the situation he found himself in.

The alien, for his part, seemed perfectly content to wait for the human to gather himself together. He looked down at Gordon with clear amusement, whiskers as thick as bridge cables bobbing around a disarmingly cute (there was no other word for it) pink nose. His eyes were large and brown, spaced a bit far apart, his ears sail-like appendages that could probably hide small houses underneath them. The parts of him that weren't covered by clothing were covered in a layer of thick, tan fur. When Gordon could manage to look up that far, Chlik smiled, revealing those ubiquitous wide, flat buck teeth. He was a cartoon character made real and blown up to ridiculous proportions.

Chlik's choice in wardrobe only added to the surreality. Most of him was covered in a suit that looked like it had been inspired by a Dickens novel – a starched, tailored white shirt underneath a grey herringbone vest, which itself was underneath a black jacket. The material, which seemed to go on for acres, actually stretched and strained around the alien's barreled chest and wide shoulders. The intensely civilized shell covered something powerful, mind-bogglingly physical. Once Gordon's brain had flushed itself of most alarms and reason began creeping back in shamefully, he found himself struck by the strange juxtaposition. Besides his overwhelming size and power, the alien gave no indication of being a danger. He merely fixed him with that amused, benevolent grin, waiting patiently for his greeting to be returned. He hadn't even moved since Gordon had arrived.

Even still, it took a few more moments for the human to be able to hear himself over the beating of his own heart. He nodded, slowly, and swallowed hard just to make sure his voice wouldn't waver. “Hello,” he said, hoarsely.

Chlik nodded, slowly. “How are you?” His voice was quiet but bassy, his tone light, conversational, genial. He was obviously trained for this moment as well. He was doing quite a bit better with remembering.

“I'm fine.” Gordon had said it before remembering he was supposed to think it. He repeated himself mentally. “I'm just fine.”

The giant rabbit chuckled and nodded again. “Very good. I am fine as well.”

It was odd to Gordon, hearing the voice inside his head while Chlik's muzzle did entirely different things. Right now his nose was twitching rapidly, pointed down, no doubt taking in the human's scent to help him read the shift in mood. Those tremendous brown eyes were pointed in his direction, daunting in their size, reassuring in their tone.

“I have to admit, you're a lot bigger than I thought you would be.”

Chlik laughed, a high chirp that nonetheless rattled the windows and table he was standing on. “I get that a lot. We've been working on holographic models that might better prepare you for the difference in scale.”

“That would be lovely.”

“Yes, I'm sure it would be. Though it's always amusing watching the looks on your faces for those first few seconds. It sets the tone for the rest of the
conversation, and lays the groundwork for our working relationship. We like having a slight upper hand in these things.” Chlik finally removed his eyes from Gordon, flicking to the teacup and back to the human. It was a subtle request for permission to move. The human, surprised, nodded, and the rabbit deftly lifted his enormous teacup.

Gordon didn't quite know what to make of that. He admired the honesty, but he wasn't sure he liked the tone it pointed to. Was this how they were seen? As amusing little things that were easy to manipulate? Maybe this was the alien's way of sounding him out, getting a better idea of his personality.

“I suppose that's true. You are on our turf, after all, and I understand how daunting it can be to get used to a completely new civilization and set of rules. It can't be easy having to be so careful all of the time.” When in doubt, go with the answer that's most compassionate. He couldn't resist getting in a subtle dig though.

Chlik smiled and nodded, taking a long draw from his tea before setting the cup back down. “Exactly so. The clothes are a little tough to get used to as well.” He stuck a thick, furry finger down his collar for emphasis. Now Gordon laughed.

“You don't wear clothing?” He was intrigued; this was something they didn't really talk about in training.

The giant shrugged. “Not quite so many. We care about modesty, as you do, but anything more than the most basic cover is unnecessary at best, impractical at worst.”

Gordon thought about that for a moment. The aliens gave off an awful lot of heat – the human felt his temperature rising just being near the enormous rabbit – and he could only imagine the thick coat of fur kept him well insulated. Considering that their home planet was quite a bit cooler than Earth, he could only imagine that the giant was baking inside that suit.

“If you're uncomfortable with what you have on, there's no need to be modest on my account. Take off what you need to, I won't mind.”

Chlik grinned broadly, his buck teeth looming over Gordon. It would have been cute if he hadn't been so close and so large. “That's very kind of you. I...
1532211.title: New Teacher: Meeting Chlik

15322112.content:
"I would love to take off my jacket and collar, at least." Chlik made a move to unbutton his coat, then looked down to Gordon. "You truly don't mind, do you? I appreciate it if you're only being polite, but I would prefer you to be honest."

Gordon blinked. Why would he prefer for someone to bake in a suit they obviously weren't built for? "No, it's really OK. If I have a problem or anything, I'll let you know."

The giant rabbit breathed a sigh of relief that blasted Gordon's hair back, even where he was. It smelled of tea, mostly, but also sweet-grass. He was surprised that it was as pleasant as it was -- he was expecting aliens in general to be a lot smellier than they were. Like real animals, perhaps.

Chlik quickly shuffled off his coat and flopped it over the building-sized chair he was sitting in, then made short work of his starched collar. That he laid on the table a fair distance away from Gordon, but his paw blotted out the light for a brief moment just the same. The giant sat down again with a long, relaxed sigh that melted into a table-quaking rumble.

"I can't tell you how good it feels to be out of that stuffy jacket. I thought I would bake alive in there." He grinned down at Gordon, slowly putting his other hand on the table. The alien was well within striking distance, something that the human had never considered before. With nothing more than a quick movement, Gordon's life could be over. "Thank you again for allowing me to be so informal."

"Don't mention it." Gordon grinned back at him, trying to make his heart stop beating quite so fast. "If we're going to be working together, we're bound to be informal sooner or later, right?"

"Right," Chlik rumbled, reaching to grab his teacup. The giant rabbit had been using exaggeratedly slow movements up until now, but his fatigue with being careful was already starting to show. A forearm covered in thick white fur whipped by Gordon's spot on the table, buffeting him with a stiff breeze. It was as big as an 18-wheeler if anything. He couldn't imagine how much it must weigh. "I suppose we'd better get down to business, then. Obviously you know you're being strongly considered for the position. Otherwise you wouldn't even be here."

Gordon blinked. "Actually, no. I knew I had a good shot at it. This is my third round of interviews. But I thought there was still a pretty big pool to wade through before the company had made their decision."

Chlik winked at him over the rim of his teacup. "You're the first of only three humans I'll be meeting today. They wanted me to see you ahead of the others so that if I like you we can cancel the other appointments and not waste anyone else's time."

Gordon's heart leapt up into his throat. "I...see. That's pretty thoughtful of you. And the company."

The rabbit chuckled and shrugged. Gordon could see the fabric shifting around impossibly-sized muscle and fur that must be thick enough to wade in. "We're nothing if not efficient, Mr. Shumway. Given the considerable effort involved in establishing contact between our two races, we've had to be."

"Man. I can only imagine." Gordon smiled and looked at the platform he was on. Chlik was essentially sitting on a retro-fitted building inside a vacant lot designed for just this purpose. There were so many new laws, so many protocols, so many advances in technology that had sprung up just so that he and this visitor from another planet could meet this way. And it was only the tip of the iceberg. If he was allowed into the teaching program, he would have access to so much more. It really would be beyond his wildest dreams. "What I can't imagine is how you guys make the program work with the others."

Chlik's ears perked. "That's another matter entirely. If you think I'm big, you'll be shocked by the Elentine. We...are even smaller to them than you are to us, and that's saying something. Our scientists believe that they're essentially an ancestor race, unevolved versions of ourselves. Much like your monkeys are to you."

"I don't think I've ever heard it described that way. Do you mean to say they're unintelligent?"

Chlik chirped. "Good heavens, no. I don't mean that at all. They're quite...sentient, I believe is the word that you use. But their technology is quite a bit behind ours. It's quite a bit behind even yours. We know quite a bit more about mechanics and physics, but you know so much more about botany, biology -- what you refer to as the life sciences. And that's why we need you."

Gordon nodded. He had heard this before. "Right; I'd be the one who taught the Elentine about basic biology, botany, chemistry. All of the sciences that dealt with the small stuff, you would say."

The giant rabbit chuckled. "Just so. And we would take care of the stuff that they could...well, perhaps practice on their level. They're more inclined to believe you over us because you're so much smaller." His ears dipped a little, and he smiled again. Gordon could just see his oversized front teeth between his lips. "If you'll pardon me for saying so."

"That's a little weird, though, don't you think? Just because we're smaller than all of you doesn't mean we would necessarily know a lot more about atomic particles."

Chlik nodded. "This is true -- correlation does not imply causation. But you have to admit, it's a lot easier for you to notice something imperceptibly small than it is for us. And certainly for the Elentine. They have neither the technology or the deductive capabilities to understand the concepts of microbiology. It will be my job to give them one. It's your job to give them the other."

Gordon couldn't help but grin. "My job. Does that mean I've officially been hired on?"

Chlik perked his ears and grinned right back at him. "Yes. Yes, I suppose it does. If you'll see the secretary inside, I believe she'll have the necessary paperwork waiting for you. We'll meet at the launching site in two weeks' time after that, and then we're off."

The human whistled. "That's a pretty tight timetable to get my affairs in order."

Chlik's ears dipped. "We assumed that most applicants who've made it this far would have started their preparations already. It'll be quite a long trip, so we'd like to get started as soon as possible. The window for the most favorable launch conditions is narrowing quickly."

"I see." Still, Gordon's mind whirled. This morning he thought it'd be another month of interviews at least before the company had made a decision. Now, he's gotten the job and will have to leave his planet for the first time ever in two weeks. Who knew when he would be back? The contract was for a full year, but he could easily see himself staying on much longer than that.

"Congratulations to you, Mr. Shumway." Chlik moved his paw slowly and extended a single finger about the size of a felled tree. "I look forward to working with you."

Gordon took the digit in both hands and shook as vigorously as he could. "Thank you very much, Chlik. The pleasure will be all mine, I'm sure."

The giant rabbit nodded, then turned his attention back to his building-sized tea cup. Gordon turned around and headed back to the office. He could scarcely believe what was happening. He would be one of the first humans ever to live on an alien planet.
15322112.title: A Relaxed Interview

15512.content:
Its a day til' school starts and for now your shuttle is in your hosts backyard, but to you its stretching for miles, bigger than the forests you'd run through back home.

Your host was in front of you, you had to stare up just to see his toes, then again he was wearing flip flops, but still he was enormous. Back home he'd be a gigantic wrecking ball.

"Hi, I'm Jack" he said, bending down and offering a hand for you to climb up on. It was absolutely enormous, but you reluctantly climbed up and sat down in the center as your new found friend lifted you up hundreds of feet off the ground. It was somewhat daunting and extremely scary for you, the drop was far more than enough to kill you and yet you weren't even up to the giant's head, "we've got an area for you set up in my room, shall we head in?"

You nod your consent to get going, and hopefully at some point wake up from this nightmare. You weren't the happiest to board that shuttle anyway.

For a while the giant was actually going down, he reached down and grabbed your shuttle. It seemed weightless in his hands, it weighed tons for you much more and for him it was the easiest thing to move.
15512.title: Little Lion

15513.content: They're bigger than you thought, but just how much?
15513.title: Wow! Some big people..

155131.content: They are big! is it 100o or 10,000 times your size?
155131.title: 1000 or 10,000X

choices: He Bends Down to Pick You Up
Naw...he just leaves you there,and talks to you from high above.
1551312.content:
You looked around,not really knowing where you were.Your shuttle had landed on a huge plain,with strange-colored mountains.You really didn't know how Earth mountains were supposed to look,so you guessed they were normal."Man....I'm pretty nervous...."You say to yourself,chewing the longer whiskers on your face.This had been a nervous habit of yours ever since you were a little lion cub.

After waiting for nearly thirty minutes,still no sign of a human coming to greet you.You actually sighed.From reports on the TV,to reading books,and even articles on the internet,you've heard that the humans were....big.Really big.The entire definition of big itself.

Suddenly,the entire landscape seemed to come alive and shift,creating violent tremors and even more violent earthquakes.The ground beneath you was black,and it seemed to stretch and mold.The monolithic mountains in the distance wiggled.They actually WIGGLED.Suddenly,it came to you.The mountains were tanned,the color of human skin.

The massive 'plain' you were standing on was the end tips of a humans black flip-flop.The mountains were toes.Humans were easily 10 thousand times your size.
1551312.title: 10,000X

choices: The tiny lion straightens up, calling up 'Chibale'.
The little fox's tail twitches even as he replies 'Tod'.
15513122.content:
You can't help but gape, slack jawed, at the enormity of the being before you, looming overhead like a living collossus. You stagger out the door of your shuttle, craning your neck to look upwards at your greeter, ears folding back into your mane as you try to come to grips with just how big he is. . .

Your original estimate of 10,000 times your scale couldn't have possibly been right, that would only make them fifteen miles or so tall. . . this being was at least ten fold that, so big that you're little more than a microorganism in comparison. The fact was so stunning that you almost didn't realize that the thundering sound overhead was the giant addressing you, a warm smile turning up the corners of his muzzle.

"Ah, there you are! I was worried you weren't going to show up, welcome to earth, my little friend. I'm Baxter, the school asked me to be here to greet you when you arrived. I run the guidance office here, it's my job to ensure the students are getting all the help they need. . . and by the look of things, you could use some help." The titan's eyes shine behind his wire-rimmed glasses, his long, greying pony tail flopping over one shoulder as he tries to look down at you without stooping TOO much. "What can I call you, while you're here with us?"
15513122.title: Naw...he just leaves you there,and talks to you...

15523221.content:
A spaceship enters the Solar System. It is vast. Larger than Jupiter, very nearly the size of the Sun. It begins exploring around.

Humans look on in awe. Such a ship must have literally trillions of people in it. Or, one kid jokes, a few people as tall as The Moon. Everyone laughs at the joke. Turns out that was too small. A couple of creatures come out a door almost the size of Saturn and begin running around.

One seems like a human-shaped alligator, and by the clothes is dressed like a young boy. The other a rather normal-looking monkey girl, except for having two tails and being all purple. They both become fascinated by the little balls they see. Ranging from large beachballs, down to marbles.

Earth, to them, is about the size of a baseball. Eventually of course, one finds our Planet.
15523221.title: The Visitor

15523222.content: Maybe it's a junior high school?
15523222.title: Junior High School

155232221.content:
You are filled with many emotions as as you stare out the window of the space ship. Even from Earth, the planet Phayenos looked massive, taking up half of the sky and often blocking out the sun's rays. You could even see individual cities during the daytime, and at night the sky lit up with bright artificial light that rivaled that of the stars. Now, however, you can even see individual buildings, and your trip is just half over!

You are going to be the first Earthling ever to set foot on Phayenosian soil, and the first human to meet a Phayenosian in real life! Before, humans and anthros contacted each other through radio signals both verbally and visually, and while this helped bring the two races together a bit, technology just cannot replace the reality of actually being in the same room with one of these friendly giants.

Your remote-controlled ship is starting to enter the atmosphere now, so you fasten your safety belt for landing. The surface does resemble that of your home planet, although everything is extremely large, of course. You notice that as your descent start to slow, your rocket is headed for a landing site right on the roof of a tall building, where an enormous coyote anthro is waiting. You can actually see miles of brown fur out the window pass by as the ship comes in for a landing on a little table. Once the ship stops, you get step out of the ship and greet the enormous coyote, who is apparently...
155232221.title: On a Rocket

Since you've gone this far, I can only assume that you're either in high school or college.

155232222.title: High School or College

info.brief_description: You are the first human in history to go to a school for giant anthros.
info.description:
This interactive starts with you, the main character, about to go to your first day at what was originally an all giant anthro school. You will be the only human in the school, but what happens is pretty open. There are some rules:

-No material that is inappropriate for anything above a 13+ rated story.
-No killing of any characters, and no intentional harming of characters either.
-No reference to any type of sex, unless you decide that the kind of school is a college. Then, you may make some reference, but do not use too much
-At least one of the giant characters must be gentle
-No ending the story

One other thing about this story is that it should be set in an alternate universe. Humans should be aware of the existence of giant anthros, and vice versa.

Thank you, and have fun!
